DIVISION 2. - THEFT OR FRAUD 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Larceny, MCL 750.356 et seq.; false pretenses and false representations, MCL 750.217a et seq.; gross frauds and cheats at common law, MCL 750.280. (Back)
Sec. 15-101. - Obtaining money, goods, services by fraud. 
    No person shall obtain or attempt to obtain money, goods, or services by fraud, trick, or false pretenses. 
(Ord. No. 151, eff. 9-10-76; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.251(40)) 
State law reference- False pretenses and false representations, MCL 750.217a et seq. 
Sec. 15-102. - Possessing stolen property. 
    No person shall possess stolen property with the knowledge that such property is stolen. 
(Ord. No. 151, eff. 9-10-76; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.251(42)) 
State law reference- Receiving, concealing, etc., stolen, embezzled or converted property, MCL 750.535. 
Sec. 15-103. - Failing to timely return rented property. 
    Any person to whom a motor vehicle, trailer or other tangible property is delivered on a rental or leased basis under any agreement in writing providing for its return to a particular place at a particular time who, with intent to defraud the lessor, refuses or willfully neglects to return such vehicle, trailer or other tangible property, after the expiration of the time stated in a notice in writing proved to have been duly mailed by registered or certified mail addressed to the last known address of the person who rented or leased the motor vehicle, trailer or other tangible property, is guilty of a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 165, § 2, eff. 11-6-81) 
Sec. 15-104. - Checks drawn without sufficient funds. 
(a)	No person shall with intent to defraud, make, draw, utter or deliver any check, draft or order for the payment of money, to apply on account or otherwise, upon any bank or other depository, knowing at the time of the making, drawing, uttering or delivering, that the maker or drawer, does not have sufficient funds in or credit with the bank or other depository, for the payment of the check, draft, or order, in full upon its presentation, if the amount payable in such check, draft or order is less than two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(b)	No person shall with intent to defraud make, draw, utter or deliver any check, draft or order for the payment of money to apply on account or otherwise, upon any bank, or other depository, unless the person has sufficient funds for payment for same when presentment is due to the drawee, except where the lack of funds is due to garnishment, attachment, levy, or other lawful cause, and such fact was not known to the person who made, drew, uttered or delivered the instrument at the time of so doing, if the amount payable in such check, draft or order is less than two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(c)	As against the maker or drawer thereof, the making, drawing, uttering or delivering, of a check, draft or order, payment of which is refused by the drawee, when presented in the usual course of business, shall be prima facie evidence of intent to defraud and of knowledge of insufficient funds in or credit with such bank or other depository, provided such maker or drawer shall not have paid the drawee thereof the amount due thereon, together with all costs and protest fees, within five (5) days after receiving notice that such check, draft or order has not been paid by the drawee. 
(d)	Where such check, draft or order is protested on the ground of insufficiency of funds or credit, the notice of protest thereof shall be admissible as proof of presentation, nonpayment and protest, and shall be prima facie evidence of intent to defraud and of knowledge of insufficient funds or credit with such bank or other depository. 
(e)	A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable as follows:
(1)	If the amount payable in the check, draft, or order is fifty dollars ($50.00) or less, as follows: 
a.	For a first offense, by imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days, or a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), or both. 
b.	For a second offense which is charged as a second offense, by imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days, or a fine of not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), or both. 
c.	For a third or subsequent offense which is charged as a third or subsequent offense, by imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days, or a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or both. 
(2)	If the amount payable in the check, draft, or order is more than fifty dollars ($50.00) but less than two hundred dollars ($200.00), by imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days, or a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or both. 
(Ord. No. 144, eff. 12-10-73; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.224; Ord. No. 189, § 1; eff. 6-28-92) 
State law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.131 et seq. 
Sec. 15-105. - Retail fraud. 
    A person who does any of the following in a store or in its immediate vicinity is guilty of retail fraud, a misdemeanor: 
(1)	While a store is open to the public, alters, transfers, removes and replaces, conceals, or otherwise misrepresents the price at which property is offered for sale, with the intent not to pay for the property or to pay less than the price at which the property is offered for sale. 
(2)	While a store is open to the public, steals property of the store that is offered for sale. 
(3)	With intent to defraud, obtains or attempts to obtain money or property from the store as a refund or exchange for property that was not paid for and belongs to the store. 
(Ord. No. 193, § 1, eff. 8-26-93) 
Sec. 15-106. - Embezzlement. 
(a)	A person who as the agent, servant, or employee or another person, governmental entity, or other legal entity or who as the trustee, bailee, or custodian of the property of another person, governmental entity, or other legal entity fraudulently disposes of or converts to his or her own use, or takes or secretes with the intent to convert to his or her own use without the consent of his or her principal, any money or other personal property of his or her principal that has come to that person's possession or that is under his or her charge or control by virtue of his or her being an agent, servant, employee, trustee, bailee, or custodian, is guilty of embezzlement. 
(b)	Any person who violates subsection (a) shall be punished by imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days or a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by both such imprisonment and fine. 
(Ord. No. 242, § 1, 8-24-2000) 
Sec. 15-107. - Defrauding of hotel, inn, restaurant, or cafe operators. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful for any person who is a guest at any hotel, motel, inn, bed and breakfast, restaurant or cafe to procure any food, beverage, entertainment or accommodation without paying therefor, except when credit is given by express agreement, with intent to defraud the operator out of payment therefor, or, with intent to defraud the operator out of the payment, to obtain credit at any hotel, motel, inn, bed and breakfast, restaurant or cafe for food, entertainment or accommodation, by means of any false show of baggage or effects. No conviction shall be had under the provisions of this section unless complaint is made within sixty (60) days of the time of the violation hereof. 
(b)	Prima facie evidence. Obtaining such food, beverage, lodging or accommodations by false pretense, or by false or fictitious show of baggage or other property, or refusal or neglect to pay therefor on demand, or payment thereof with check, draft or order upon a bank or other depository or a credit card on which payment was refused, or absconding without paying or offering to pay therefor, or surreptitiously removing or attempting to remove baggage, shall be prima facie evidence of such intent to defraud for purposes of subsection (a) above. 
(Ord. No. 241, § 1, 4-28-2000) 
Editor's note- 
Ord. No. 241, § 1, eff. Apr. 28, 2000 did not specify manner of codification, hence; inclusion of these provisions as § 15-107 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 15-108. - Fraudulent nonpayment for taxicab services. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit and receive the services of any taxicab within the city without paying therefore, with the intent to defraud the owner or operator of such taxicab of payment for the services rendered. Proof that any person refused and neglected to pay for such services on demand, or left the taxicab without paying or offering to pay for such service, shall be prima facie proof of fraudulent intent. 
(Ord. No. 246, § 1, 2-18-2003) 
Sec. 15-109. - Prohibition of manufacture, sale, possession, or use of a device or object designed or used to defeat or remove theft detection devices. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)	Possess a laminated or coated bag or device that is intended to shield merchandise from detection by an electronic or magnetic theft detection device with the intent to commit or attempt to commit larceny, retail fraud, or embezzlement. 
(2)	Manufacture, sell, offer for sale, or distribute, or attempt to manufacture, sell, offer for sale, or distribute, a laminated or coated bag or device that is intended to shield merchandise from detection by an electronic or magnetic theft detection device knowing or reasonably believing that the bag or device will be used to commit or attempt to commit larceny, retail fraud, or embezzlement. 
(3)	Possess a tool or device designed to allow the deactivation or removal of a theft detection device from any merchandise with the intent to use the tool or device to deactivate a theft detection device on, or remove a theft detection device from, any merchandise without the permission of the merchant or person owning or lawfully holding that merchandise with the intent to commit or attempt to commit larceny, retail fraud, or embezzlement. 
(4)	Manufacture, sell, offer for sale, or distribute a tool or device designed to allow the deactivation or removal of a theft detection device from any merchandise without the permission of the merchant or person owning or lawfully holding that merchandise knowing or reasonably believing the tool or device will be used to commit or attempt to commit larceny, retail fraud, or embezzlement. 
(5)	Deactivate a theft detection device or remove a theft detection device from any merchandise in a retail establishment prior to purchasing the merchandise with the intent to commit or the attempt to commit larceny, retail fraud, or embezzlement. 
(6)	Violation of this section shall be a misdemeanor with penalties as set forth in section 1-9(b) of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 260, § 1, eff. 8-21-2003) 
DIVISION 3. - DISHONORED CHECK COST RECOVERY 

Sec. 15-110. - Purpose. 
    The City of Grandville finds that a significant number of checks are written and dishonored within its geographical boundaries causing serious financial loss and hardship to citizens and merchants therein. In addition, the city finds that the financial loss and hardship incurred by its citizens and merchants seriously impacts on the stream of commerce and the general public by causing increases in the costs of goods and services. As a result of these determinations, a greater operational and financial burden is placed upon the city's police and legal services by persons who are placing dishonored checks into the stream of commerce. 
(Ord. No. 195, § 1, eff. 11-28-93) 
Sec. 15-111. - Definitions. 
    When used in this division, the following terms shall have the following meanings: 
    Address of record shall mean: The address that appears on the check or the last known address of record with the secretary of state at the time the check was presented for payment of goods or services. 
    Check shall mean: Any check, draft or order for the payment of money, to apply on account or otherwise, upon any bank or other depository, 
    Dishonored shall mean: 
(1)	Any check, draft or order drawn or written on any account, or otherwise, upon any bank or other depository, without sufficient funds for the payment of same when presentation is made to the drawee. 
(2)	Any check, draft or order drawn or written on any account which has been closed with or by the bank or other depository upon which it is drawn. 
    Expenses of dishonored check response shall mean: The direct and reasonable cost incurred by the city or to a private person or corporation operating at the request or direction of the city when responding to a reported dishonored check, including the cost of providing police, city attorney and/or administrative services in response to any reported dishonored check. These costs further include all of the salaries and wages of the city personnel and/or contractors engaged in investigation, supervision and report preparation, and all costs connected with the administration and provision of any prosecution of the person responsible for the dishonored check. 
(Ord. No. 195, § 1, eff. 11-28-93) 
Sec. 15-112. - Liability for expense of dishonored check responses. 
(a)	Person responsible: Any person is liable for the expense of a dishonored check response, if such person proximately causes any incident resulting in a dishonored check response. 
(b)	Presumption: For the purpose of this division, a person is presumed to be the proximate cause of an incident if said person makes, draws, utters or delivers any dishonored check or causes directly or indirectly a check to become dishonored. 
(c)	Charges against person: The expenses of a dishonored check response shall be a charge against the person liable for the expense under this division. The charge constitutes a debt of that person and is collectible by the city for incurring those costs in the same manner as in the case of an obligation under a contract, expressed or implied. 
(d)	Cost recovery schedule: The city council shall, by resolution, adopt a schedule of cost included within the expense of a dishonored check response. This schedule shall be available to the public from either the city clerk, treasurer, or the police department. 
(e)	Billing: The city manager, or his or her designee, may submit a bill for the dishonored check response by first-class mail to the last known address of record or personal service to the person liable for the expenses as enumerated under this division. The bill(s) shall require full payment within thirty (30) consecutive days from the date of service. Service by mail shall be effective upon depositing said bill in a United States Postal Service receptacle. In no event shall billing be permitted after one (1) year from the last expense incurred. 
(f)	Failure to pay; procedure to recover cost: Any failure by the person described in this division as liable for the expense of a dishonored check response, to pay the bill within thirty (30) consecutive days of service shall be considered in default. In case of default, the City of Grandville may commence civil suit to recover the expenses and any costs allowed by the law. 
(Ord. No. 195, § 1, eff. 11-28-93; Ord. No. 214, § 1, 5-26-95) 
Secs. 15-113-15-125. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC PEACE 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Disorderly conduct in parks, § 17-49. (Back)
Sec. 15-126. - Disturbance or fight in public places. 
    No person shall create or engage in a disturbance or fight in any public place. 
(Ord. No. 151, eff. 9-10-76; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.251(20); Ord. No. 213, § 9, eff. 5-26-95) 
Sec. 15-127. - Language or gestures causing public disorder. 
    A person shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor if, with the purpose of causing public danger, alarm, disorder or nuisance, or if his or her conduct is likely to cause public danger, alarm, disorder or nuisance, such person willfully uses abusive or obscene language or makes an obscene gesture to any other person when such words by their very utterance inflict injury or tend to incite an immediate breach of the peace. 
(Ord. No. 151, eff. 9-10-76; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.251(43)) 
State law reference- Indecent language in presence of woman or child, MCL 750.337; disorderly persons, MCL 750.167; cursing and swearing, MCL 750.103. 
Sec. 15-128. - Collecting crowds in public places for illegal or mischievous purposes. 
    No person shall collect or stand in crowds, or arrange, encourage or abet the collection of persons in crowds for illegal or mischievous purposes in any public place. 
(Ord. No. 151, eff. 9-10-76; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.251(21)) 
State law reference- Riots and unlawful assemblies, MCL 752.541 et seq. 
Sec. 15-129. - Jostling, crowding persons in public places. 
    No person shall jostle or roughly crowd persons in any public place. 
(Ord. No. 151, eff. 9-10-76; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.251(22)) 
State law reference- Such person defined as a disorderly person, MCL 750.167(1)(l). 
Sec. 15-130. - Loitering. 
    No person shall loiter on any street or sidewalk or any park or public buildings or on the grounds adjacent to any public buildings or to conduct oneself in any public place so as to obstruct the free and uninterrupted passage of the public after having been told to move on by a police officer. 
(Ord. No. 151, eff. 9-10-76; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.251(23)) 
State law reference- Certain loiterers deemed disorderly persons, MCL 750.167(1)(i-k). 
Sec. 15-131. - Being under influence of narcotic drug or controlled substance in public places. 
    No person shall be under the influence of any narcotic drug or controlled substance in any public place.

State law reference- Such person defined as a disorderly person, MCL 750.167(1)(e). 
Sec. 15-132. - Permitting disorderly persons to congregate. 
    No person shall permit or suffer any place occupied or controlled by him to be a resort of disorderly persons. 
(Ord. No. 151, eff. 9-10-76; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.251(30)) 
Sec. 15-133. - Disturbing, disrupting assemblies, meetings, schools. 
    No person shall disturb, disrupt, or interfere with, without lawful authority, any lawful assembly or meeting of persons or any school. 
(Ord. No. 151, eff. 9-10-76; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.251(11)) 
State law reference- Disturbing meetings, MCL 750.169 et seq. 
Sec. 15-134. - Quarrelling; violation as civil infraction; authorized official. 
(a)	No person shall engage in a quarrel in public place so as to create or tend to cause a breach of the peace. 
(b)	A person who violates any provision of this section is responsible for a municipal civil infraction in accordance with section 1-9 of this Code; and subject to payment of a civil fine, plus costs and other sanctions, for each infraction or repeat offense, as provided by section 1-9(c) of this Code. 
(c)	The officers of the police department are hereby designated as the authorized city official to issue municipal civil infraction citations (directing alleged violators to appear in court) or municipal civil infraction violation notices (directing the alleged violator to appear at the municipal ordinance violation bureau) as provided in this Code. 
(Ord. No. 213, § 10, eff. 5-26-95) 
Sec. 15-135. - Disturbing the peace. 
    No person shall disturb the peace and quiet of the city or its neighborhoods by loud, boisterous or disruptive conduct or language. 
(Ord. No. 299, § 1, eff. 1-3-2015 )

ARTICLE VI. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC MORALS 
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Alcoholic liquors generally, Ch. 3. (Back)
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 15-151. - Indecent, obscene conduct in public places. 
    No person shall engage in any indecent or obscene conduct in any public place. 
(Ord. No. 151, eff. 9-10-76; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.251(13)) 
State law reference- Such person defined as a disorderly person, MCL 750.167(1)(f). 
Sec. 15-152. - Indecent exposure. 
    No person shall make any indecent exposure of his person or of the person of another in a public place. 
(Ord. No. 151, eff. 9-10-76; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.251(4)) 
State law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.335a. 
Sec. 15-153. - Committing prostitution; soliciting person for illegal act. 
    No person shall engage in the act of prostitution or solicit or accost any person for the purpose of inducing the commission of any illegal act. 
(Ord. No. 151, eff. 9-10-76; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.251(24)) 
State law reference- Common prostitute deemed a disorderly person, MCL 750.167(1)(b); prostitution generally, MCL 750.448 et seq. 
Sec. 15-154. - Attend, frequent, operate places where illegal occupations are conducted. 
    No person shall attend, frequent, operate or be an occupant or an inmate of any place where prostitution, illegal gambling, illegal sale of alcoholic liquor, or where any other illegal business or occupation is permitted or conducted. 
(Ord. No. 151, eff. 9-10-76; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.251(25)) 
Sec. 15-155. - Transporting persons to places where prostitution or illegal gambling takes place. 
    No person shall knowingly transport any person to a place where prostitution or illegal gambling is practiced, encouraged, or allowed for the purpose of enabling such a person to engage in gambling or in any illegal act. 
(Ord. No. 151, eff. 9-10-76; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.251(27)) 
State law reference- Transporting person for prostitution, MCL 750.459. 
Sec. 15-156. - Gambling. 
    No person shall keep or maintain or permit the use of a gambling room, table, or equipment, or any policy or pool tickets to be used for gambling on any premises occupied or controlled by him; or place, receive, or transmit any bet on the outcome of any race, contest, or game or any kind whatsoever, except to the extent that any of the above facilities or activities may be permitted by the laws of the state. 
(Ord. No. 151, eff. 9-10-76; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.251(28)) 
Cross reference- Gambling prohibited in parks, § 15-50. 
State law reference- Gambling, MCL 750.301 et seq. 
Sec. 15-157. - Inhaling toxic fumes. 
    No person shall intentionally smell or inhale the fumes of any substance which releases toxic vapors for the purpose of creating or causing a condition of euphoria, excitement, exhilaration, stupefaction, or dulled senses, or to possess, buy, or supply any such substance for the purpose of violating this section. 
(Ord. No. 151, eff. 9-10-76; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.251(47)) 
State law reference- Use of chemical agents, MCL 752.271 et seq. 
Sec. 15-158. - Nudity prohibited. 
(a)	No person shall engage in public nudity.
(b)	No person shall hire, employ or procure any other person to engage in public nudity.
(c)	No business establishment or the owners, officers, agents, and employees of the business establishment shall allow any person to engage in public nudity in or upon the premises of such establishment. 
(d)	For purposes of this section "public nudity" means knowingly or intentionally displaying in a public place, or for payment or promise of payment by any person, including, but not limited to, payment or promise of payment of an admission fee, any individual's genitals or anus with less than a fully opaque covering, or a female individual's breast with less than a fully opaque covering of the nipple and areola. 
    A woman's breast-feeding of a baby does not under any circumstances constitute public nudity irrespective of whether or not the nipple is covering during or incidental to the feeding. Public nudity also does not include "material" as defined in section 2 of Act No. 343 of the Public Acts of 1984, being MCL 752.362, or "sexually explicit visual material" as defined in section 3 of Act No. 33 of the Public Acts of 1978, being MCL 722.673. 
(e)	A violation of any provision of this section is a misdemeanor punishable by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) (plus costs of prosecution) or by imprisonment not to exceed ninety (90) days, or by both a fine and imprisonment. Each day on which a violation continues constitutes a separate offense. In addition, the city may bring an action for an injunction or other process against a person to restrain, prevent, or abate any violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 231, § 2, eff. 4-2-98) 
Secs. 15-159-15-175. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Controlled substances, MCL 333.7101 et seq. (Back)
Sec. 15-176. - Possession and sale prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use, possess, sell, or offer to sell, distribute, administer, dispense, prescribe or give away any controlled substance as defined in Act No. 368 of the Public Acts of Michigan 1978 (MCL 333.7101 et seq.), as amended, provided that nothing contained in this section shall be deemed to prohibit the use, possession, sale, offer for sale, distributing, administering, dispensing or prescribing of any of the drugs or their derivatives mentioned in this section in the manner and under such circumstances provided in this division. 
(Comp. Ords. 1977, §§ 20.281-20.283; Ord. No. 234, § 1, 2-26-99; Ord. No. 261, § 1, eff. 2-5-2004) 
Sec. 15-177. - Dispensing by authorized persons. 
    A manufacturer, wholesaler, apothecary, medical doctor, osteopathic physician, dentist, veterinarian, chiropodist, public or private hospital, sanitarium or institution maintained or conducted in whole or in part for the treatment of disability, disease, inebriety or drug addiction, may purchase, receive, possess, sell, distribute, prescribe, administer or dispense any controlled substance described in section 15-176; provided they shall have complied with all provisions as required by Act No. 368 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1978 (MCL 333.7101 et seq.), as amended, provided further that no medical doctor, osteopathic physician or other person specified in this section in any manner authorized to prescribe any controlled substance shall prescribe such controlled substance for his own use, nor shall any druggist honor such a prescription; provided, further, that all controlled substances obtained pursuant to this section shall be kept in the original package or container in which they were received; provided, that this requirement should not be construed to apply to any duly licensed medical doctor, osteopathic physician, dentist, veterinarian or chiropodist, or to any authorized person acting directly under their supervision or control. 
(Comp. Ords. 1977, §§ 20.281-20.283) 
Sec. 15-178. - Hypodermic syringes, needles, other instruments. 
(a)	No person shall at any time have or possess a hypodermic syringe or needle or any other instrument or implement adapted for the use of controlled substances by subcutaneous injection or intracutaneous injection or any other manner or method of introduction and which is possessed for that purpose, unless such possession is authorized by the certificate of a licensed medical doctor or osteopathic physician issued within the period of one (1) year; provided, that the prohibition contained in this section shall not apply to manufacturers, wholesalers, jobbers, licensed medical technicians, technologists, nurses, hospitals, research teaching institutions, clinical laboratories, medical doctors, osteopathic physicians, dentists, chiropodists, veterinarians, pharmacists and embalmers in the normal legal course of their respective business or profession, nor to persons suffering from diabetes, asthma or any other medical condition requiring self-injection. 
(b)	It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, furnish, supply or give away any empty gelatin capsules or hypodermic syringe or needle or other instrument or implement adapted for the use of controlled substances by subcutaneous injection or intracutaneous injection or any other manner or method of introduction to any person known to be a nonmedical habitual user of controlled substances. For the purpose of this subsection, a "nonmedical habitual user of controlled substances" shall mean any person who uses controlled substances merely to satisfy a craving for such substances and who does not have a legitimate medical need for controlled substances. 
(Comp. Ords. 1977, §§ 20.281-20.283) 
Sec. 15-179. - Fraud and deceit. 
(a)	Any fraud, deceit, misrepresentation, subterfuge, concealment of a material fact, or the use of a false name or the giving of a false address for the purpose of obtaining any controlled substances or barbituric acid or any derivative, compound, preparation or mixture thereof, or hypodermic syringe or needle or other instrument or implement or empty gelatin capsules or false statement on any prescription blank shall be deemed a violation of this section. No person who shall have obtained the possession of controlled substances, hypodermic syringes, needles or other instruments or implements adapted for the use of such substances or empty gelatin capsules pursuant to the terms of this division shall use the same or permit or authorize their use for any purpose other than that specifically authorized in the prescription or order by means of which such possession was obtained. 
(b)	Any fraud, scheme, device, trick, deceit, misrepresentation, subterfuge or any other form of concealment for the purpose of obtaining money or any other thing of value by the sale, furnishing, supplying or giving away of any substance represented to be a controlled substance as described in section 15-176, when the same may or may not be the same, shall be deemed a violation of this section. 
(Comp. Ords. 1977, §§ 20.281-20.283) 
Sec. 15-180. - Exemption for common carriers, public officers while engaged in lawful transportation or performance of duties. 
    The provisions of this division restricting the possession of controlled substances or barbituric acid or any derivative, compound, preparation or mixture thereof, or hypodermic syringes, needles or other implements or instruments adapted to the use of such substances by means of subcutaneous injection or intracutaneous injection or any other manner or method of introduction or empty gelatin capsules shall not apply to common carriers or warehouses or their employees engaged in the lawful transportation or storage of such drugs, syringes, needles or capsules, or to public officers or employees while engaged in the performance of their official duties, nor to temporary incidental possession on the part of employees or agents of persons lawfully entitled to possession. 
(Comp. Ords. 1977, §§ 20.281-20.283) 
Sec. 15-181. - Commitment of addicts. 
(a)	No person shall unlawfully use or be addicted to the unlawful use of controlled substances or their derivatives or barbituric acid or derivative or mixtures, compound or preparation thereof. Any nonmedical habitual user of controlled substances, as defined in section 15-178(b), who shall make voluntary application to the judge of the district court may, upon the presentment of a certificate executed by a practicing physician in the state stating that he is a nonmedical habitual user of controlled substances, be committed, at the discretion of the court, to any correctional or charitable institution, hospital, sanitarium or institution authorized for the treatment of disease or inebriety or drug addiction. Whenever the medical officer or head of such institution shall certify to the committing judge or court that any person so committed has been sufficiently treated or gives any other reason which is deemed by such judge or court to be adequate and sufficient, the court may, in accordance with the terms of commitment, discharge the person so committed or return him to await further action of the court. 
(b)	Any addicted person who does not make voluntary application for treatment as provided in this section shall be deemed to be in violation of this section. 
(Comp. Ords. 1977, §§ 20.281-20.283) 
Secs. 15-182-15-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC SAFETY 

Sec. 15-201. - Throwing objects from moving vehicles. 
    No person shall throw or propel any snowball, missile, or object from any moving vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 151, eff. 9-10-76; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.251(36)) 
Cross reference- Traffic and motor vehicles generally, Ch. 25. 
Sec. 15-202. - Throwing objects toward vehicles or persons. 
    No person shall wrongfully throw or propel any snowball, missile, or object toward any person or vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 151, eff. 9-10-76; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.251(37)) 
Cross reference- Traffic and motor vehicles generally, Ch. 25. 
State law reference- Throwing stone or missile at train, automobile, etc., MCL 750.394. 
Sec. 15-203. - Discharging weapons in public places. 
(a)	For purposes of this chapter, the word "firearm" shall mean any weapon or device from which is propelled any missile, projectile, bullet, shot, pellet or other mass by means of explosives, compressed air or gas or by means of springs, levers or other mechanical device which weapon or device shall be capable by the discharge of any such propelled missile, projectile, bullet, shot, pellet or other mass capable of inflicting personal injury or death upon any person. 
(b)	No person shall fire, discharge, flourish, or otherwise use any firearm, air rifle, air pistol, bow and arrow, sling shot, or other dangerous weapon or instrument in any street, avenue, alley, public place, or any place in such manner as to endanger or to be likely to endanger any person or property or cause alarm to any person except as provided in subsections (c)-(e) of this section 15-203 
(c)	This section 15-203 shall not be construed to prohibit carp bowfishing in accordance with the requirements of this section 15-203 
(d)	The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section 15-203, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
(1)	Carp bowfishing. A method of fishing that utilizes customized archery equipment to shoot and retrieve carp species of fish in ponds and lakes within the city. 
(2)	Draw-locking mechanism. A mechanism designed to allow one to draw their bow back and lock it in the fully drawn, ready to shoot position. 
(3)	Test-strength. The pounds of force required to break a particular type of fishing line. 
(e)	Carp bowfishing shall not be a violation of the prohibitions set forth in this section 15-203 so long as all of the following conditions are met: 
(1)	Any individual carp bowfishing (A) has received a carp bowfishing permit from the city; (B) has obtained the approval in writing of seventy (70) percent of the riparian owners of the lake in question; (C) has passed a hunter's safety course and possesses a valid Michigan fishing license; (D) is at least sixteen (16) years old, or is between twelve (12) years old and sixteen (16) years old and is accompanied by an adult; and (E) shall have in their possession while actively carp bowfishing a copy of the requirements imposed by this section 15-203(e)(1). 
(2)	Any activity in connection with carp bowfishing is otherwise authorized under Michigan law. 
(3)	Any individual carp bowfishing shall provide notice to all riparian owners of the lake at which he or she is carp bowfishing at least eighteen (18) hours prior to the date or dates of all planned carp bowfishing events. 
(4)	Carp bowfishing may only be conducted at lakes and ponds within the city during the months of April, May, and June, on any day of the week. Carp bowfishing is prohibited at lakes within the city at all other times. 
(5)	Carp bowfishing shall only be conducted at a distance of one hundred (100) feet or greater from any child, marked swimming or picnic area, or restricted areas. 
(6)	The equipment used by a person to propel any arrow used for carp bowfishing shall be hand-pulled and hand-released. The use of a crossbow or draw-locking mechanism for carp bowfishing is hereby prohibited. 
(7)	Any ammunition used for carp bowfishing shall be constructed of a solid shaft and equipped with a heavy tethered fishing point, including a downward angle arrow point. The use of arrows designed for flight through the air for carp bowfishing is hereby prohibited. 
(8)	A line or cord having a length less than or equal to forty (40) feet and a test-strength greater than or equal to forty (40) pounds shall be attached to any arrow used for carp bowfishing. 
(9)	Any person catching or taking a carp by carp bowfishing shall remove those fish from the lake and dispose of them in a manner authorized by law. 
(Ord. No. 151, eff. 9-10-76; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.251(5); Ord. No. 273, § 1, eff. 10-6-2005; Ord. No. 293, § 1, eff. 5-2-2013) 
State law reference- Reckless use of firearms, MCL 752.863a. 
Sec. 15-204. - License required for use, display, possession of weapons. 
    No person shall display, possess, or otherwise utilize any firearm, air rifle, air pistol, or other weapon within the city unless they are licensed, as required by law. 
(Ord. No. 151, eff. 9-10-76; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.251(6)) 
State law reference- Licensing of pistols, MCL 28.422 et seq. 
Secs. 15-205-15-225. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - OFFENSES ON SCHOOL GROUNDS 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference- Offenses pertaining to minors, § 15-251 et seq. (Back)
Sec. 15-226. - Trespassing. 
    No person who is not a regularly enrolled student or parent or guardian thereof or school official, teacher, or other public or school employee shall enter upon or remain upon the premises of any public, private, or parochial school after being notified not to enter the premises or to leave the premises by the principal, any person designated by the principal, or a duly authorized police officer of this city. 
(Ord. No. 151, eff. 9-10-76; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.254) 
State law reference- Trespassing, MCL 750.546 et seq. 
Sec. 15-227. - Disturbing the peace. 
    No person shall willfully or maliciously make or assist in making any noise, disturbance or improper diversion by which the peace, quietude or good order of any public, private or parochial school is disturbed. 
(Ord. No. 151, eff. 9-10-76; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.255) 
State law reference- Disturbing public places, MCL 750.170. 
Sec. 15-228. - Creating, participating in disturbance or riot. 
    No person, whether lawfully or unlawfully in or upon any public, private or parochial school premises, shall willfully create a disturbance or riot or take part in or engage in any disturbance or riot while remaining on such public, private, or parochial school premises. 
(Ord. No. 151, eff. 9-10-76; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.256) 
State law reference- Disturbing public plans, MCL 750.170. 
Sec. 15-229. - Extortion. 
    No person shall by violence, threats of violence, or other form of coercion, force or attempt to force any public, private, or parochial school student or other person to give or to lend any money or thing of value to any person at any time. 
(Ord. No. 151, eff. 9-10-76; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.257) 
State law reference- Extortion, MCL 750.213. 
Sec. 15-230. - Damaging, destroying, defacing property. 
    No person shall damage, destroy, or deface any public, private, or parochial school building or grounds, outbuildings, fences, trees or other appurtenances or fixtures belonging thereto. 
(Ord. No. 151, eff. 9-10-76; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.258) 
State law reference- Malicious mischief, MCL 750.377 et seq. 
Secs. 15-231-15-250. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - OFFENSES PERTAINING TO MINORS 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (9) --- 
Cross reference- Transportation or possession in motor vehicle of alcoholic liquors by persons under twenty-one years of age, § 3-5; purchase, consumption, possession of alcoholic liquor by persons under twenty-one years of age, § 3-6; persons under seventeen years of age in dance halls, § 4-29; age limitation for purchase or sale of fireworks, § 10-70; age limitation for use, display or possession of fireworks, § 10-71; child neglect, § 15-69; offenses on school grounds, § 15-226 et seq. (Back)
Sec. 15-251. - Curfew. 
    No minor under the age of twelve (12) years shall loiter, idle, congregate, traverse, or remain in or upon any public street, highway, alley, park, or other public place between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., and no minor under the age of fifteen (15) years shall loiter, idle, congregate, traverse, or remain in or upon any public street, highway, alley, park, or other public place between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., and no minor under the age of seventeen (17) years shall loiter, idle, congregate, traverse, or remain in or upon any public street, highway, alley, park, or other public place between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m., except where the minor is accompanied by a parent or guardian, or some adult over the age of twenty-one (21) years delegated by the parent or guardian of the minor to accompany the minor child, or where the minor is upon an errand or other legitimate business directed by his parent or guardian. No person of the age of seventeen (17) years or over shall assist, aid, abet, or encourage any minor under the age of seventeen (17) years to violate the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 151, eff. 9-10-76; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.259) 
State law reference- Curfew for minors, MCL 722.751 et seq. 
Sec. 15-252. - Tobacco products. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, give to, or in any way furnish cigarettes or other products containing tobacco to any person under the age of eighteen (18) years within the limits of the city. 
(b)	It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of eighteen (18) years to smoke, use or possess cigarettes or other products containing tobacco on any public highway, street, alley, park, or other lands used for public purposes, or in any public place of business or amusement within the limits of the city. 
(c)	It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly harbor any person under the age of eighteen (18) years or to grant to such person the privilege of gathering or frequenting any property or lands held by him for the purpose of indulging in the use of cigarettes or other products containing tobacco within the limits of the city. 
(d)	No part of this section shall be construed so as to interfere with the rights of parents or lawful guardians in the rearing and management of their minor children or wards within the bounds of their private premises. 
(Comp. Ords. 1977, §§ 20.271-20.274; Ord. No. 235, § 1, 2-26-99) 
State law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 722.641 et seq. 
Sec. 15-253. - Violation of offenses pertaining to minor as civil infraction; authorized official. 
(a)	A person who violates any provision of this article is responsible for a municipal civil infraction in accordance with section 1-9 of this Code; and subject to payment of a civil fine, plus costs and other sanctions, for each infraction or repeat offense, as provided by section 1-9(c) of this Code. 
(b)	The officers of the police department are hereby designated as the authorized city official to issue municipal civil infraction citations (directing alleged violators to appear in court) or municipal civil infraction violation notices (directing the alleged violator to appear at the municipal ordinance violation bureau) as provided in this Code. 
(Ord. No. 213, § 11, eff. 5-26-95) 
Chapter 16 - OIL AND GAS WELLS 
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Oil, gas and minerals, MCL 319.1 et seq., MSA 13.139(1) et seq. (Back)
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 16-1-16-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PERMIT 

Sec. 16-26. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drill any well for the purpose of securing oil or gas within the confines of the city without first obtaining from the city council a permit to do so. 
(Ord. No. 44, eff. 4-13-39; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 27.021) 
Sec. 16-27. - Application-Contents. 
    Every person desiring to drill any well for the purpose of securing oil or gas within the confines of the city shall, before commencing the drilling of any well, apply in writing to the city council for permission so to do. The application shall be addressed to the city council and shall contain full information as to the exact location desired to be drilled upon, the proximity of such location to the nearest buildings, the size of the property, the method to be followed in the drilling operations, and in the storage and handling of gas or oil if secured, and such other information as the city council shall require. 
(Ord. No. 44, eff. 4-13-39; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 27.022) 
Sec. 16-28. - Same-Consideration by city council; acceptance, rejection, restrictions. 
(a)	After receipt of an application for the permit required by this article the city council shall consider the same within a reasonable time and each such application shall be considered on its own merits and without regard to other applications. 
(b)	The city council shall have the power to accept or reject any application so presented to it and it shall have further right and power to impose such restrictions, conditions, and limitations on all permits granted as it in its own discretion may deem necessary for the protection of health, happiness and property of the residents of the city. 
(Ord. No. 44, eff. 4-13-76; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 27.023) 
Chapter 17 - PARKS AND RECREATION 
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Community development, Ch. 7; planning, Ch. 18; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 23; vegetation, Ch. 27. (Back)
State Law reference- Authority to operate recreation and playgrounds, MCL 123.51 et seq. (Back)
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 17-1. - Purpose, interpretation and application. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall be the minimum requirements for the promotion of the public health, safety and general welfare of the people of the city. Among other purposes such provisions are intended to authorize the promulgation of rules and regulations relative to the use of the public parks, playgrounds, and the facilities therein and to provide a penalty for the violation thereof. It is not intended by this chapter to repeal, abrogate, annul or in any way impair or interfere with existing provisions of other laws or ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 146, eff. 4-7-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.402) 
Sec. 17-2. - Enforcement. 
    The responsibility for the operation of the park system and the enforcement of this chapter, including the rules and regulations as set out in article II of this chapter, shall be vested in the city manager and his duly authorized assistants or agents. 
(Ord. No. 146, eff. 4-7-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.403) 
Sec. 17-3. - Jurisdiction. 
    The city manager shall have jurisdiction over all areas and their facilities which are declared recreational areas in the master plan as adopted by the planning commission and certified to the city council, and the maintenance and operations of public parks, the recreational facilities therein, the playgrounds, and such other areas and/or facilities as may be designated by the city council. All of such areas and facilities are referred to in this chapter as the "park system." 
(Ord. No. 146, eff. 4-7-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.404) 
Sec. 17-4. - Preparation, adoption of rules and regulations. 
    The city manager is hereby authorized and directed to prepare necessary rules and regulations relative to the use of the park system. Copies of the rules and regulations promulgated pursuant to this chapter shall be kept on file at the office of the city clerk for inspection by and/or distribution to interested parties. Any change or alteration in the rules and regulations in the future shall be submitted to the city council for approval. No rule or regulation shall become effective until approved by resolution of the city council. The current rules and regulations which have been approved by the city council are set forth in article II of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 146, eff. 4-7-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.405) 
Sec. 17-5. - Modification of rules and regulations. 
    The city manager and his agents are authorized to modify the strict letter of any rule or regulation promulgated pursuant to this chapter where practical difficulties in carrying out the strict letter of such rule or regulation would result in hardship to a particular person or the public; provided, however, that neither the city manager nor his agents shall make modification or take any action which permits the sale or purchase within the park system of any alcoholic liquors. Any authorized modifications must be of a character which will not impair the purposes and intent of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 146, eff. 4-7-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.406; Ord. No. 146-A, § 1, eff. 11-26-82) 
Sec. 17-6. - Appeal from order. 
    If any person shall feel aggrieved by any order or decision pertaining to the park system made by the city manager or his agents, he may, within ten (10) days after receipt of such order or decision, appeal in writing to the city council. The city council may take such action on such appeal as it deems just, and may vary the terms of such order or decision or rule and regulation as it determines is in the public interest. 
(Ord. No. 146, eff. 4-7-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.407) 
Secs. 17-7-17-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RULES AND REGULATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 17-31. - Authority of city manager to supervise employees, visitors, designate uniforms of employees, erect signs. 
    The city manager or his representatives shall have complete charge of the supervision of the park system subject to the rules and regulations of the park system as approved from time to time by the city council. He shall supervise all workers, visitors and drivers in the parks. Employees of the department of public works designated by the city manager shall wear a uniform of a kind and color to be prescribed by him and the uniform shall be worn at all times while on duty. The city manager is, by approval of these rules and regulations, authorized to place and erect signs and notices within the scope thereof, for the protection and preservation of persons, property and animals within the park system, and for the proper regulation and supervision of activities therein. Such signs and notices shall have the force and effect of rules and regulations and violation thereof shall be deemed to be a misdemeanor and a violation of these rules and regulations. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.422) 
Sec. 17-32. - Opening and closing hours. 
    The public parks and playgrounds belonging to the city shall be open to the public only between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. of each and every day, provided that the city council by resolution or the city manager by order, may suspend opening of the parks or playgrounds for a specific period of time, as it or he deems to be in the best interest of the city. It shall not be lawful for any person, except employees working in such park or playground to enter therein after the hour above named for the opening or remain therein after the hour above named for the closing thereof; provided, however, that the city manager may grant permission to any person to enter into and remain within a public park or playground until not later than 12:00 midnight where it appears that such closing hour will be beneficial to the city and its inhabitants, and where the public peace, safety and welfare may be promoted. Any person entering into or remaining within the parks or playgrounds in accordance with such permission shall not be deemed unlawfully therein. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.421) 
Sec. 17-33. - Expulsion or exclusion of violators from park system. 
    The city manager, police officers, and authorized personnel shall have the authority and power to exclude and expel any person from any public park, playground or recreation area or facility, when such person violates any of the provisions or requirements of applicable ordinances, or rules and regulations. Such expulsion or exclusion shall be for a period not to exceed ten (10) days. The refusal or failure of any person to leave the park system when ordered so to do by the city manager, police officers, authorized personnel or the return to the park system by the person so expelled or excluded before the expiration of the period of expulsion or exclusion shall be deemed to be a violation of these rules and regulations. The provisions as set forth in this rule shall be construed to be cumulative to all penalties provided. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.423) 
Sec. 17-34. - Authority to charge fee for use of facilities. 
    The department of public works shall be entitled to charge a fee for use of the park or park lodge and other department of public works facilities if such use results in an added expense to the city. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.440) 
Sec. 17-35. - Authority to require bond for use of facilities. 
    Where there is a risk of public injury or property damage, the city manager may require any person, group or organization desiring to make use of the city park lodges or other park system facilities to furnish bonds or insurance of amounts and types satisfactory to him, to hold the city harmless from injuries or damage resulting from activities engaged in by such person, group or organization. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.441) 
Sec. 17-36. - Admission charges for activities. 
    No admission charge for any activity within the park system may be made without the express prior permission of the city manager or the city council. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.437) 
Sec. 17-37. - Permit required for advertisements, sales. 
(a)	No person shall post any advertisement, circular or handbill within the park system nor shall any peddler or dealer sell or in any manner dispose of any article in public parks or playgrounds unless he shall first obtain express permission to do so from the city manager. 
(b)	No permission shall be given to any vendor or peddler of beverages, food or refreshments unless permission is received from the city manager. 
(c)	The license required by subsection (b) of this section may only be granted for a specified period not exceeding three (3) days. Any permit extending beyond three (3) days, or of a repetitive or permanent nature, must be obtained from the city manager. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.431-20.433) 
Sec. 17-38. - Permit required for large picnics. 
    A permit for large picnics (twenty-five (25) persons) must be obtained from the city manager if the group or organization intends to bring food or beverages into the park system either from a caterer or other commercial supply sources. This permit shall only be issued if all the requirements of the county health department and other agencies concerned are complied with. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.434) 
Sec. 17-39. - Sales by nonprofit organizations. 
    Church bazaars, rummage sales and other sales by nonprofit organizations may be permitted by the city manager if he finds, after review of the proposed activity, that the same will not interfere with the use of the park system by the public. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.436) 
Sec. 17-40. - Commercial activities; private business. 
    No promotional or commercial activity shall be permitted within the park system, unless special permission has been first obtained from the city manager, except as allowed by sections 17-36, 17-39 and 17-41. It is intended by this section to prohibit the promotion of commercial products and the conduct of private business within the park system. Picnics and social parties by commercial and private organizations, limited to their members, employees and families are permitted, subject to this division, particularly sections 17-35, 17-43, 17-44, 17-53 and 17-57. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.435) 
Sec. 17-41. - Political activities. 
    No gatherings, meetings, banquets or other activities of a political nature shall be permitted in the park system, except at such places therein as shall be designated by the city manager. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.438) 
Sec. 17-42. - Religious, other noncommercial meetings. 
    Religious and other noncommercial meetings may be conducted in such areas or buildings and at such time as may from time to time be designated by the city manager. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.439) 
Sec. 17-43. - Picnics and social parties. 
(a)	Picnics and social parties may be allowed in such portions of any park as shall be designated and set apart on request. 
(b)	Reservations for picnics and social parties may be made for certain designated areas by groups of over twenty (20) persons. No reservations will be made in any park for more people than the facilities within the respective park will permit. These reservations are for picnic tables only and not for the area. It will be the responsibility of the person or organization that makes the reservation to arrange to have the picnic tables occupied at the appointed hour. Under no condition will the department of public works be responsible for reserving tables beyond the hour for which the reservation was made. There will be no charge for reservations, except for additional expenses incurred. No reservations will be made in any park on Saturdays, Sundays, or holidays except as otherwise provided by division 2 of this article. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § § 20.442, 20.443) 
Sec. 17-44. - Use of facilities by public or semi-public organizations. 
    Any governmental, military, emergency preparedness or similar public or semipublic organization which wishes to make use of park facilities or park areas other than lodges or swimming pools for either social activities, shows, demonstrations, parades, meetings or similar purposes must obtain permission from the city manager. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.444) 
Sec. 17-45. - Uses of recreation areas by organized groups. 
    Among other functions as stated, the city manager may schedule and allocate to organized groups, such outside active recreational facilities as softball diamonds, baseball diamonds, tennis courts, basketball courts, court game areas, swimming pool activities and events, and all other activities considered to be part of the park system. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.479) 
Sec. 17-46. - Speeches, public meetings. 
    No person shall deliver any oration, address, speech, sermon or lecture therein unless he shall first have received permission from the city manager, nor shall any public meeting or concert be held therein unless such leave is first obtained. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.455) 
Sec. 17-47. - Rental of facilities. 
    Park buildings may be leased by a person, group or organization for the purposes permitted in this chapter. The cost of such rental of buildings or facilities will be according to the fee schedule approved by the city council. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.451) 
Sec. 17-48. - Damaging property prohibited. 
    No person shall cut, mutilate, injure, overturn, remove, carry away or in any other way damage any personal or real property of whatsoever nature belonging to the park system of the city or under its jurisdiction. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.424) 
Cross reference- Offenses against property generally, § 15-86 et seq. 
State law reference- Malicious mischief, MCL 750.377 et seq. 
Sec. 17-49. - Boisterous or threatening language, disorderly or indecent conduct, intoxicated persons prohibited. 
    No person shall use any boisterous or threatening language in the park system or cause any unusual noise to be made therein, or engage in any disorderly or indecent conduct; nor shall any intoxicated person be in any such place. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.425) 
Cross reference- Offenses against public peace generally, § 15-126 et seq. 
Sec. 17-50. - Gambling prohibited. 
    No person shall engage or participate in any gambling, game of change or game at which a prize is given for a consideration in the park system. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.427; Res. No. 1085, § 1, eff. 11-8-82) 
Cross reference- Gambling generally, § 15-156. 
Sec. 17-51. - Alcoholic liquors prohibited. 
    No person shall bring into or sell, purchase, consume or dispense any alcoholic liquors or controlled substances within the park system. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.427; Res. No. 1085, § 1, eff. 11-8-82) 
Cross reference- Alcoholic liquors generally, Ch. 3. 
Sec. 17-52. - Littering prohibited. 
    No person shall deposit any rubbish, refuse or litter in or upon the park system, except as the same shall be deposited in receptacles provided for that purpose by the department of public works. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.428) 
State law reference- Littering, MCL 752.901 et seq. 
Sec. 17-53. - Camping, overnight outings, tents, trailers prohibited. 
    Camping, tents, trailers, overnight outings and similar activities are not permitted in the park system. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.445) 
Sec. 17-54. - Fouling of waters prohibited. 
    No basin, pool, lake or fountain shall be fouled by stone, wood or any other substance; nor shall they be bathed in or waded in unless specially set apart for that purpose. Any body of water which is set aside and designated as a wading pool, tank or swimming pool within the aforesaid limits shall not be fouled by any person and it shall be unlawful for any person to expectorate in such water or spit tobacco juice in the same, or blow his nose therein, or commit any nuisance therein, or within the bathhouse enclosures, and before any person shall bathe in any of the places within the limits aforesaid, the officers or attendants having charge of such places are hereby empowered to cause the person to thoroughly cleanse their bodies by the use of shower baths or such other methods as may be provided. The city manager shall regulate the hours of bathing, and make all rules and regulations necessary for the protection of the public. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.456) 
Sec. 17-55. - Hunting, trapping prohibited. 
    Hunting and trapping of any animal is not permitted in the park system. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.447) 
Cross reference- Animals generally, Ch. 5. 
Sec. 17-56. - Killing, molesting animals prohibited. 
    No person shall kill, disturb or molest any birds or birds' nests or any fish or animal within, belonging to or being in the parks or playgrounds. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.454) 
Cross reference- Animals generally, Ch. 5. 
Sec. 17-57. - Fishing. 
(a)	Fishing in accordance with state rules and regulations is permitted in Buck Creek and such other areas as may be designated. 
(b)	Ice fishing may be permitted in such areas and at such times as may be designated by state rules and regulations. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, §§ 20.446, 20.448) 
Sec. 17-58. - Boating. 
    Boating may be permitted in such areas as may be designated by the city manager. No power boats are permissible in park lagoons. Power boats may be launched at the designated launching site for use on the Grand River and must comply with all rules and regulations pertaining to the use of power boats in inland rivers or lakes. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.449) 
Sec. 17-59. - Winter sports. 
    Skating, skiing, sliding, tobogganing and similar winter sports are permitted in the park system in those areas and times designated for these activities. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.450) 
Sec. 17-60. - Domestic animals. 
    No person shall permit any domestic animal to be or run at large within the park system. No dogs shall be permitted in the park system unless on a leash not over eight (8) feet long and in areas permitted and designated by the city manager. Owners of dogs shall be held responsible for the presence of their dogs in the park system. Any person owning or harboring a dog which is permitted to be in the park system and which shall disturb any birds or animals therein shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this chapter and the rules and regulations. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.426) 
Cross reference- Animals generally, Ch. 5. 
Sec. 17-61. - Riding, driving vehicles and animals. 
    No person shall ride or drive any animal or vehicle in any public park or playground except upon the proper roadways, avenues and drives, and shall not drive therein at a speed exceeding ten (10) miles an hour or such speed as may be designated. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.453) 
Cross reference- Animals generally, Ch. 5; traffic and motor vehicles generally, Ch. 25. 
Sec. 17-62. - Fires. 
    No fires shall be built in the park system excepting in places provided for that purpose by the department of public works or as designated and under the direction and control of the city manager. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.457) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection generally, Ch. 10. 
State law reference- Fire prevention act, MCL 29.1 et seq. 
Sec. 17-63. - Fireworks. 
    No person shall fire, discharge or set off any rocket, crackers, torpedoes, squibs or other fireworks or things containing any substance of an explosive nature in a city park, unless that person has received permits from the Michigan State Police Fire Marshal Division after approval by the city council. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.429; Ord. No. 287, § 1, eff. 2-4-2011) 
Cross reference- Fireworks generally, § 10-66 et seq. 
State law reference- Fireworks, MCL 750.243 et seq. 
Sec. 17-64. - Begging, soliciting. 
    No person shall publicly beg, solicit any subscriptions, or take up collections for any purpose whatsoever in the park system without first receiving written permission from the city manager to do so. 
(Res. No. 620, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.430) 
Cross reference- Begging generally, § 15-4. 
State law reference- Persons found begging in a public place defined as disorderly persons, MCL 750.167(1)(h). 
Sec. 17-65. - Prohibition of dumping in city parks. 
(a)	No person shall dispose of or direct others to dispose of any garbage or rubbish in any park container for garbage or rubbish unless such garbage or rubbish resulted or was generated from a picnic or other activity while using such park. 
(b)	Violation of this section shall be a misdemeanor pursuant to section 1-26 of this Code. 
(c)	Rubbish or garbage shall be as defined in section 21-26 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 262, § 1, eff. 2-5-2004) 
Secs. 17-66-17-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PARK LODGES 

Sec. 17-81. - Exceptions. 
    Exceptions to the provisions of this division may be made by only the city manager or the city council and must be obtained in advance. 
(Res. No. 621, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.463) 
Sec. 17-82. - Principal use. 
    The principal use of park lodges is to be for nonprofit social, recreational, educational activities and family gatherings. 
(Res. No. 621, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.461) 
Sec. 17-83. - Prohibited activities. 
    Activities not permitted in park lodges are functions of a political nature, commercial exhibits, commercial shows, product advertising, activities which may be considered profit-making or activities to which entrance fees are charged, tickets are sold at the gate or presold or where subscriptions, pledges or solicitations are made. 
(Res. No. 621, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.462) 
Sec. 17-84. - Rental in advance required. 
    Park lodges or structures must be rented in advance and will be reserved for the date requested unless prior requests for rentals have been made. 
(Res. No. 621, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.464) 
Sec. 17-85. - Deadline for reservations. 
    Reservations of park lodges must be made at least one (1) week before use and the fee for rental must be paid on the date indicated on the agreement. 
(Res. No. 621, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.466) 
Sec. 17-86. - Reservations limited. 
    The city reserves the right not to accept reservations of park lodges for more than six (6) months in advance or for more than four (4) future occasions by the same person or organization. 
(Res. No. 621, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.465) 
Sec. 17-87. - Rental periods. 
    Park lodges may be rented from 9:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m., 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. and 5:00 p.m. to 11:00 p.m. or any portion thereof. 
(Res. No. 621, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.470) 
Sec. 17-88. - Renting on Sundays and holidays. 
    Park lodges may not be rented on Sundays or holidays except by special permission of the city manager. 
(Res. No. 621, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.469) 
Sec. 17-89. - Fees and charges. 
    The basic charge for park lodges shall be as prescribed by resolution of the city council. All fees for special cases will be determined by the city manager. Additional fees may be charged for services by city personnel. A deposit may be required by the city manager if he deems it necessary. All fees are payable to the city treasurer and all permits are available at the offices of the city manager or his representatives at the city offices. 
(Res. No. 621, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.479) 
Sec. 17-90. - Name and address of person responsible for fee required. 
    Any person, group or organization renting the park lodges or structures must indicate on the rental agreement the name and address of the person who assumes responsibility for the payment of the fee and the proper use of the lodge. 
(Res. No. 621, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.475) 
Sec. 17-91. - Cancellation of reservation. 
    If cancellation is made by a renter of a park lodge, the full fee will not be refunded unless notice of cancellation is received by the city three (3) days prior to the date for which use of the lodge was reserved. The city reserves the further right to cancel any reservation for cause, up to one (1) week prior to the date reserved. The city further reserves the right to cancel any reservations even while the function is in progress, if such function has been misrepresented or does not comply with this chapter, or is against the public interest. 
(Res. No. 621, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.467) 
Sec. 17-92. - Precedence of recreation and park commission over other renters. 
    Activities of the recreation and park commission or activities sponsored by the commission and the necessity of using the park lodges and structures for election or other essential governmental activities will always have precedence over rentals by private groups. 
(Res. No. 621, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.468) 
Sec. 17-93. - Kitchen facilities, tables, hotplates. 
(a)	Park lodges may be rented either with or without kitchen facilities where available. Lodges may be rented with or without tables or other available equipment. 
(b)	Park lodges which have no fully equipped kitchen facilities, but have a hotplate, may be used without an additional charge for warming up or preparing coffee, tea, hot chocolate or similar beverages or washing dishes. 
(Res. No. 621, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, §§ 20.471, 20.472) 
Sec. 17-94. - Decorations. 
    Decoration equipment may be brought into the park lodge and installed, provided that it is in compliance with the fire laws and health and safety ordinances. A detailed description of the contemplated decorations and a list of the type of appurtenances or other appliances and the manner of their installation and use must be submitted to the city manager prior to the use or installation. 
(Res. No. 621, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.478) 
Sec. 17-95. - Cleaning, restoration of premises by renter. 
    The renter of the park lodge is solely responsible for cleaning up and putting the premises in the same condition as they were at the beginning of the time of use. The renter may be held responsible for any charges if he neglects his obligation to cleanup. This does not include removal of chairs, tables, or platform, if the lodge was rented with these items included. It does, however, include all items brought in by the renter, such as table covers, decorations and other objects not present when the use of the premises commenced. 
(Res. No. 621, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.476) 
Sec. 17-96. - Renter responsible for damage. 
    The renter of the park lodge will be held liable for all damages over and above those which may be considered normal wear and which occur during his occupancy. If the city manager feels it necessary that insurance be furnished for public liability or property damage, such insurance must be furnished. 
(Res. No. 621, eff. 6-10-74; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.477)

ARTICLE II. - PLANNING COMMISSION 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Planning commission, § 6.18. (Back)
Cross reference- Boards and commissions generally, Ch. 2, Art. IV. (Back)
State Law reference- Authority to create a planning commission, MCL 125.32. (Back)
Sec. 18-26. - Construction and interpretation. 
    It is the intention of the city council that this article shall be construed with the zoning ordinance and the subdivisions and utility extensions ordinance, included in this volume as chapter 24, as a part of the master plan for the city, and that the provisions of each shall be interpreted so as to give consistent and uniform meaning to all of these provisions. 
(Ord. No. 113, eff. 2-7-63; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 15.055) 
Sec. 18-27. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created a city planning commission which shall be known as the Planning Commission of the City of Grandville. The planning commission is created pursuant to Section 6.18 of the Charter of the city. 
(Ord. No. 113, eff. 2-7-63; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 15.051) 
State law reference- Authority to create a planning commission, MCL 125.32. 
Sec. 18-28. - Appointment of members. 
    The planning commission shall consist of seven (7) members to be appointed by the city council in accordance with the provisions of Section 6.18(b) of the Charter of the city. 
(Ord. No. 113, eff. 2-7-63; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 15.052) 
Sec. 18-29. - Officers, meetings, records. 
    The planning commission shall elect its chairman from among the appointed members and create and fill such other of its offices as it may determine. The term of chairman shall be one (1) year, with eligibility for reelection. The planning commission shall hold at least one (1) regular meeting in each month. It shall adopt rules for the transaction of business and shall keep a record of its resolutions, transactions, findings, and determinations, which record shall be a public record. 
(Ord. No. 113, eff. 2-7-63; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 15.053) 
State law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 125.34. 
Sec. 18-30. - Functions and duties. 
(a)	Advise city council and recommend improvements. It shall be the function and duty of the planning commission to advise the city council in regard to the proper development of the city and to recommend annually a program of public structures and improvements for the ensuing five (5) years, which program shall show those public structures and improvements in the general order of their priority. 
(b)	Make and adopt master plan. It shall also be the function and duty of the planning commission to make and adopt a master plan for the physical development of the city. Such plan, with the accompanying maps, plats, charts, and descriptive matter shall show the planning commission's recommendations for the accomplishing of a coordinated, adjusted, and harmonious development of the city and its environs, including, among other things, the general location, character, and extent of streets, viaducts, bridges, boulevards, parkways, playgrounds and open spaces, the general location of public buildings, and other public property, and the general location and extent of public utilities and terminals, whether publicly or privately owned or operated, the removal, relocation, widening, vacating, abandonment, change of use or extension of any streets, grounds, open spaces, buildings, property, utilities, and the general location, character, layout and extent of community centers and neighborhood units, the general character, extent and layout of the replanning and redevelopment of blighted districts and slum areas, as well as a zoning plan for the control of the height, area, bulk, location, and use of buildings and premises. As the work of making the whole master plan progresses, the planning commission may from time to time adopt and publish a part thereof, any such part to cover one (1) or more major sections or divisions of the city or one (1) or more of the aforesaid or other functional matters to be included in the plan. The planning commission may from time to time amend, extend, or add to the plan. 
(Ord. No. 113, eff. 2-7-63; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 15.054) 
Secs. 18-31-18-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ZONING 

Sec. 18-51. - Notice of ordinance adoption. 
    A comprehensive zoning ordinance regulating the development and use of all land within the city has been approved by the city council. The zoning ordinance, Ordinance No. 281, is effective April 1, 2010. Copies of the zoning ordinance are available for purchase or inspection during normal business hours at the office of the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 204, eff. 5-26-94; Ord. No. 281, eff. 4-1-2010)

ARTICLE II. - RESERVE POLICE FORCE 

Sec. 19-26. - Authority of chief of police to provide. 
    In addition to the members of the regular police force, the chief of police, with the approval of the city manager, may provide for a reserve police force consisting of reserve police officers. 
(Ord. No. 164, § 1, eff. 10-6-81) 
Sec. 19-27. - Authority to perform actions of regular police officers generally. 
    Reserve police officers shall have the authority to perform the actions of regular police officers for this city while engaged in the enforcement of city ordinances; provided that such reserve police officers shall at that time be in uniform at and under the general direction of the police department. 
(Ord. No. 164, § 2, eff. 10-6-81) 
Sec. 19-28. - Authority to issue and serve appearance tickets. 
    Reserve officers are specifically authorized hereby to issue and serve appearance tickets with respect to all city ordinance violations, including traffic violations, whether civil or criminal in nature. 
(Ord. No. 164, § 3, eff. 10-6-81)

Chapter 21 - SOLID WASTE 
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; planning, Ch. 18; soil erosion and sedimentation control, Ch. 20; utilities, Ch. 26. (Back)
State Law reference- Authority to regulate disposal of garbage and rubbish, MCL 123.241 et seq., 123.361 et seq. (Back)
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 21-1-21-9. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LITTERING
