Sec. 21-10. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division shall have the meanings as described to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Highway means a public or private road, street, or other place generally accessible to motor vehicles, including the right-of-way or easement area and any area designated for parking of vehicles. 
    Litter means all rubbish, refuse, waste materials, garbage, offal, paper, glass, cans, bottles, trash, debris, or other foreign substances. 
    Vehicle means every motor vehicle registered under the Michigan Vehicle Code, Act 300 P.A. 1949, being Sections 257.1 through 257.923 of the Michigan Compiled Laws. 
    Vessel means a vessel registered under the Marine Safety Act, Act 303 P.A. 1967, being Section 281.1001 through 282.1199 of the Michigan Compiled Laws. 
(Ord. No. 219, § 2, eff. 9-7-95) 
Sec. 21-11. - Littering prohibited. 
    A person shall not knowingly, without the consent of a public authority having supervision of public property or the owner of private property, dump, deposit, place, throw, or leave, or cause or permit the dumping, depositing, placing, throwing, or leaving of litter on public or private property or water other than property designated or set aside for such purposes. 
(Ord. No. 219, § 2, eff. 9-7-95) 
Sec. 21-12. - Unlawful use of solid waste disposal container of another. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit or place any litter or other solid waste, as defined in this chapter, in a properly authorized solid waste disposal container owned or operated by another without the lawful authority of the owner, operator, or occupant responsible for the container or by an agent or servant of the owner or occupant responsible for the container or when prohibited by written notice conspicuously posted on or about the premises or the container. 
(Ord. No. 219, § 2, eff. 9-7-95) 
Sec. 21-13. - Debris from highway. 
    A person or any other non-public agency or entity who removes a vehicle that is wrecked or damaged in an accident on a highway shall remove all glass and other injurious substances dropped on the highway, as a result of the accident. 
(Ord. No. 219, § 2, eff. 9-7-95) 
Sec. 21-14. - Litter on vehicles. 
    A person shall not knowingly cause litter or any object to fall or to be thrown into the path of or hit a vehicle traveling upon a highway. 
(Ord. No. 219, § 2, eff. 9-7-95) 
Sec. 21-15. - Violation as civil infraction; authorized official; community service; presumptions. 
(a)	A person who violates any provisions of this article is responsible for a municipal civil infraction in accordance with section 1-9 of this Code; and subject to payment of a civil fine, plus costs and other sanctions, for each infraction or repeat offense, as provided by section 1-9(c) of this Code. 
(b)	The city manager, fire chief, and officers of the police department are designated as authorized city officials to issue municipal civil infraction citations (directing alleged violator to appear in court), or municipal civil infraction notices (directing the alleged violator to appear at the City of Grandville Municipal Ordinance Violation Bureau) as provided in this Code. 
(c)	Additionally, the court may impose, under supervision of the court, community service in the form of litter gathering labor, including but not limited to litter connected with the particular violation. 
(d)	The following presumptions shall exist:
(1)	The driver of a vehicle or vessel is presumed to be responsible for litter that is thrown, dropped, dumped, deposited, placed or left from the vehicle or vessel on public or private property or water. 
(2)	In a proceeding for a violation under this division involving litter from a motor vehicle or a vessel, proof that the particular vehicle or vessel described in the citation or notice was used in the violation, together with proof that the alleged violator named in the citation or notice was the registered owner or lessee of the vehicle or vessel at the time of the violation, constitutes in evidence a presumption that the registered owner or lessee of the vehicle or vessel was the driver of the vehicle or vessel at the time of the violation. 
(Ord. No. 219, § 2, eff. 9-7-95) 
Sec. 21-16. - Prohibition of dumping. 
(a)	No person shall dump, deposit, throw or place or allow to be placed, any garbage or rubbish on any premises or property, private or public or direct that garbage or rubbish be dumped, deposited, thrown, placed or allowed to be placed, within the city, without the permission of the owner or occupier of that premises or property, and unless that garbage or rubbish is placed in and kept in approved garbage or rubbish containers. 
(b)	Violation of this section shall be a misdemeanor pursuant to section 1-26 of this Code. 
(c)	Rubbish and/or garbage shall be as defined in section 21-26 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 263, § 1, eff. 2-5-2004) 
Secs. 21-17-21-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL OF SOLID WASTE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 21-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Act 641 means Act No. 641 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1978 (MCL 299.401 et seq.), as amended. 
    Act 641 plan means the county solid waste management plan approved by the city, the county board of commissioners, and by the director of the department of natural resources, pursuant to the requirements and provisions of Act 641, and any amendments thereto adopted in accordance with the act. 
    Approved incinerator and approved garbage grinder mean incinerators and garbage grinders, respectively, that conform to all city ordinance requirements, are used exclusively to dispose of solid waste generated by the occupant of the site of generation on which they are located, and are consistent with the Act 641 plan. 
    Ashes means the residue from the burning of wood, coal, refuse, waste water sludge, and other combustible materials. 
    Board of public works means the county board of public works established pursuant to the provisions of Act No. 185 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1957 (MCL 123.731 et seq.), as amended. 
    Combustible waste means solid waste that is combustible in the MBI as shall be determined solely by the board of public works. Combustible waste shall include: (a) Garbage; (b) combustible rubbish, such as paper; cardboard; cartons; wood; boxes; rags; cloth; bedding; leather; grass; leaves and brush; yard trimmings; tree limbs; timber; logs, and stumps six (6) inches in diameter or less; carpeting; and combustible construction and demolition debris; and (c) any other solid waste that is combustible in the MBI as shall be determined solely by the board of public works. Combustible waste shall exclude: (a) noncombustible solid waste, such as ashes; noncombustible rubbish; incinerator ash; incinerator residue; municipal and industrial sludges; animal waste; pathological and biological waste; asbestos and asbestos waste products; biological waste; asbestos and asbestos waste products; explosives; radioactive materials; appliances; concrete rubble; noncombustible construction and demolition debris; rock; gravel and earth materials; automobiles; trailers; equipment wire and cable; (b) all waste other than solid waste (such as hazardous waste, site-separated materials, and source separated materials), and (c) any other type of waste that is noncombustible in the MBI as shall be determined solely by the board of public works. 
    Commercial operation date means the date when the MBI has been completed and tested and is, in the sole opinion of the county, ready for full commercial operation. 
    County means the County of Kent, Michigan, acting by and through its board of commissioners or its department of public works. 
    Disposal site means any of the following: 
(1)	A solid waste transfer facility;
(2)	A single incinerator having an average daily design capacity exceeding fifty (50) tons of solid waste per day or two (2) or more incinerators located at one (1) site under the control of one (1) person and having an aggregate average daily design capacity exceeding one hundred fifty (150) tons of solid waste per day; 
(3)	A sanitary landfill;
(4)	A solid waste processing plant; or
(5)	Any other solid waste handling or disposal facility utilized in the disposal of solid waste. 
    Garbage means rejected food wastes, including waste accumulation of animal, fruit, or vegetable matter used or intended for food or that attends the preparation, use, cooking, dealing in, or storage of meat, fish, fowl, fruit, or vegetable. 
    Hazardous materials means any materials which pose a substantial present or potential hazard to human life, health and safety, or the environment, including but not limited to hazardous substances as defined in Act 307 of Michigan Public Acts 1982 (being MCL 299.603), as amended, and any other substances that have been classified by the local, state or federal government or any of their departments or agencies to be hazardous or toxic. 
    Hazardous waste means hazardous waste as defined in Act No. 64 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1979 (MCL 299.501 et seq.), as amended, and as identified in administrative rules promulgated pursuant to the act by the director of the state department of natural resources. 
    HazMat unit means the vehicle and personnel provided by the City of Wyoming pursuant to an agreement with the city, equipped with apparatus designed to provide emergency service in situations involving the suspected or actual release, accident or other similar occurrence involving hazardous materials. 
    MBI means the mass-burn steam energy generating incinerator to be constructed by or on behalf of or available by contract or lease with the county within the City of Grand Rapids in accordance with the Act 641 plan. 
    Premises means any enclosed area used for residential, commercial, or industrial purposes, separately or in combination, to which a separate street address, postal address or box, tax roll description, or other similar identification has been assigned to or is in use by a person having control of the area. 
    Release means any unpermitted spilling, leaking, pumping, pouring, emitting, emptying, discharging, injecting, leaching, dumping or disposing into the environment. 
    Responsible party means any individual, firm, corporation, association, partnership, commercial entity, consortium, joint venture, government entity or any other legal entity that is responsible for a release of a hazardous material, either actual or threatened, or is an owner, as defined in Act 307 of Michigan Public Act 1982 (being MCL 299.063), as amended, tenant, occupant or party in control of property onto which or from which hazardous materials have been released. 
    Rubbish means nonputrescible solid waste, exuding ashes, consisting of combustible and noncombustible waste, including paper, cardboard, metal containers, yard clippings, wood, glass, bedding, crockery, demolished building materials, or litter of any kind that may be a detriment to the public health and safety. 
    Site of generation means any premises in or on which solid waste is generated by any person. 
    Site-separated materials means recyclable materials, including but not limited to bottles, cans, newspapers, corrugated containers, metals, grass, leaves, brush, and yard trimmings, that are separated from solid waste after collection from a site of generation by either a waste hauler or by the operators of the disposal site to which it is delivered. 
    Solid waste means garbage, rubbish, ashes, incinerator ash, incinerator residue, street cleanings, municipal and industrial sludges, solid commercial and solid industrial waste, and animal waste; provided, however, that this definition shall not include hazardous waste, site-separated materials, source-separated materials, human body waste, liquid or other waste regulated by statute, ferrous or nonferrous scrap directed to a scrap metal processor or to a reuser of ferrous or nonferrous products, and slag or slag products directed to a slag processor or to a reuser of slag or slag products. 
    Source-separated materials means recyclable materials, including but not limited to bottles, cans, newspapers, corrugated containers, metals, grass, leaves, brush, and yard trimmings, that are separated from solid waste prior to the collection of solid waste from a site of generation. 
    Tipping fee means the fee established by the board of public works to be charged upon delivery of combustible waste to the MBI. 
    Waste hauler means any person engaged, in whole or in part, in the business of collecting, transporting, delivering, or disposing of solid waste within the city. 
(Ord. No. 174, § 1, eff. 12-5-85; Ord. No. 186, § 1, eff. 8-22-91; Ord. No. 210, § 1, 1-8-95; Ord. No. 223, § 1, eff. 3-11-96) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 21-27. - Compliance with laws, rules, and regulations. 
    Waste haulers shall comply with the Act 641 Plan and all applicable federal and state laws, statutes, rules, and regulations (including, but not limited to, Act 641 and administrative rules promulgated pursuant to Act 641) in the collection, transportation, delivery, and disposal of combustible waste. Waste haulers shall also comply with all rules and regulations of the board of public works for the administration and operation of the MBI (including, without limitation, rules and regulations prohibiting delivery of loads consisting primarily of unacceptable waste as solely determined by the board of public works acting through its designated representatives) and other disposal sites of the Kent County Refuse Disposal System. 
(Ord. No. 174, § 12, eff. 12-5-85; Ord. No. 186, § 1, eff. 8-22-91) 
Sec. 21-28. - Depositing solid waste in containers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit or place any solid waste in any street, alley, or other public place within the city, nor shall any person deposit or place any solid waste upon any private property unless such garbage is in a suitable watertight can, vessel, or container equipped with a closely fitting cover, which cover shall not be removed except when necessary. Such container shall be of convenient size to be handled by the waste hauler and shall be kept on the ground level, so as to be readily accessible for collection. No person unless duly authorized by the city council, shall molest, remove, or transport through the streets or alleys, any solid waste that has been deposited as provided in this section. 
(Ord. No. 174, § 6, eff. 12-5-85) 
Sec. 21-29. - Authorization of person to collect solid waste. 
(a)	For the purpose of collecting and disposing of solid waste systematically and in a sanitary manner, the city council shall from time to time designate and authorize a person to collect and dispose of solid waste. Such collection shall be under the supervision of the city street administrator and in accordance with any agreement the city council may have made with the party so authorized. 
(b)	No waste hauler shall collect solid waste or source-separated materials in any residentially-zoned district of the city between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 6:30 a.m. 
(Ord. No. 174, § 7, eff. 12-5-85; Ord. No. 251, §§ 1, 2, 7-2-2002) 
Sec. 21-30. - License required, fee. 
    No person shall engage in the business of collecting, transporting, delivering, or disposing of solid waste in the city without first obtaining a license in accordance with chapter 12. The license shall be subject to all of the provisions of chapter 12. An annual fee determined by resolution of the city council shall be paid for each license. It shall be an express condition of each license that the waste hauler shall comply with all provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 174, § 8, eff. 12-5-85) 
Sec. 21-31. - Certification of equipment. 
    No license shall be issued to any waste hauler unless such waste hauler shall present to the city license officer a certificate issued by the city manager certifying that the equipment to be used by the waste hauler will not endanger the health and safety of the inhabitants of the city. Failure of the licensee to maintain his equipment in satisfactory condition or operation of the equipment in a manner detrimental to the health and safety of the inhabitants of the city shall be grounds for revocation of the license. 
(Ord. No. 174, § 9, eff. 12-5-85) 
Sec. 21-32. - Disposal of solid waste and combustible waste. 
(a)	Solid waste shall be disposed of only by means of an approved incinerator or approved garbage grinder, or by collection by licensed waste haulers, except that any individual may dispose of solid waste from his own household: 
(1)	Upon the individual's own land so long as the disposal does not create a nuisance or hazard to health, in accordance with Section 18 of Act 641 (MCL 299.418); or 
(2)	By personally transporting the same to an approved sanitary landfill but only in accordance with rules and regulations pertaining thereto and the Act 641 plan. No individual transporting any solid waste in accordance with this section shall fail to securely cover and secure the load so that no part of the load shall be lost while being transported. 
(b)	Commencing on the commercial operation date, all combustible waste collected or transported by waste haulers from a site of generation within the city shall be disposed of only in accordance with section 21-33. Prior to the commercial operation date, all combustible waste collected or transported by waste haulers from a site of generation within the city shall be disposed of only at disposal areas approved by the city council which may include solid waste processing plants, sanitary landfills, solid waste transfer stations, and other solid waste facilities, such as are consistent with the Act 641 plan. 
(c)	All solid waste other than combustible waste collected or transported by waste haulers from a site of generation within the city shall be disposed of only at disposal areas approved by the city council which may include solid waste processing plants, sanitary landfills, solid waste transfer stations or other solid waste facilities, such as are consistent with the Act 641 plan. 
(Ord. No. 174, § 10, eff. 12-5-85) 
Sec. 21-33. - Delivery of combustible waste. 
(a)	Commencing on the commercial operation date and at all times thereafter, waste haulers shall (a) deliver to the MBI all combustible waste collected or transported from a site of generation within the city and (b) pay the tipping fee for delivery of such waste at the MBI (unless otherwise provided by contract between the city and the waste hauler). Commencing on the commercial operation date and at all times thereafter, no waste hauler shall deliver combustible waste collected or transported from a site of generation within the city to any disposal site other than the MBI. 
(b)	Waste haulers shall deliver to the MBI all combustible waste regardless of whether the combustible waste is transported in the same load or vehicle as solid waste which is not combustible waste. This requirement shall be absolute and unconditional unless the board of public works, acting through its designated representatives, has made a prior written determination that a specific load of waste consists primarily of waste which would not be accepted for delivery at the MBI. Such a written determination of the board of public works shall not be applicable to waste collected from any site of generation, any load or vehicle, any waste hauler or any facts or circumstances, other than those expressly identified in the written determination. This subsection shall become effective on January 1, 1992. 
(c)	Waste haulers shall not deliver combustible waste to a site for site separation of recyclable materials unless the board of public works, acting through its designated representatives, after request of the waste hauler, has made a prior written determination that such delivery does not violate this section. Such a written determination shall not be applicable to waste collected from any site of generation, load or vehicle, any waste hauler, or any facts or circumstances other than those expressly identified in the written determination. A written determination pursuant to this section shall not relieve the waste hauler from the obligation to deliver to the MBI all combustible waste remaining in a load after site separation of recyclable materials. This subsection shall become effective on January 1, 1992. 
(d)	Waste haulers shall not deliver hazardous waste to the MBI.
(e)	Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, waste haulers shall not be prohibited from transporting combustible waste collected from a site of generation within the city for disposal at any disposal site located outside of this state. 
(Ord. No. 174, § 11, eff. 12-5-85; Ord. No. 186, § 1, eff. 8-22-91; Ord. No. 228, § 1, eff. 1-1-98) 
Sec. 21-34. - Remedy for violations as civil infractions; other relief, suspension or revocation of license; authorized official. 
(a)	A person who violates a provision of this article is responsible for a municipal civil infraction in accordance with this article and section 1-9 of this Code; and subject to payment of a civil fine, plus costs and other sanctions, for each infraction or repeat offense, as provided in this article and section 1-9(c) of this Code. The civil fine for a violation of sections 21-32 or 21-33 shall be as follows: 
First offenseNot less than $2,000.00 (plus costs)First repeat offenseNot less than $5,000.00 (plus costs)Second or any subsequent repeat offenseNot less than $10,000.00 (plus costs) 
The civil fines for all other violations of this article shall be as follows: 
First offenseNot less than $100.00 (plus costs)First repeat offenseNot less than $500.00 (plus costs)Second or any subsequent repeat offenseNot less than $1,000.00 (plus costs) 
For purposes of this article, a "repeat offense" means a second (or subsequent) municipal civil infraction violation of the same requirement or provision (i) committed by a person within any five-year period and (ii) for which the person admits responsibility or is determined to be responsible. Each day that a violation occurs shall be deemed a separate offense and shall be subject to sanctions as a separate offense. 
(b)	In addition, upon a violation of any provision of this article the city may seek other legal and/or equitable relief in a court of the competent jurisdiction. A violation of any provision of this article shall also be cause for suspension or revocation of the license of a waste hauler in accordance with chapter 12 
(c)	The fire chief is hereby designated as the authorized city official to issue municipal civil infraction citations (directing alleged violators to appear in court) or municipal civil infraction violation notices (directing the alleged violator to appear at the municipal ordinance violation bureau) as provided in this Code. 
(Ord. No. 174, § 13, eff. 12-5-85; Ord. No. 213, § 13, eff. 5-26-95; Ord. No. 228, § 2, eff. 1-1-98) 
Sec. 21-35. - Identification of solid waste containers. 
(a)	A solid waste container having a capacity of at least one-half (1/2) cubic yard shall be plainly marked with the name and current street address or the name and current telephone number of the waste hauler which collects solid waste from or transports solid waste within the solid waste container. The name and current street address or the name and current telephone number of the waste hauler shall be plainly marked on at least three (3) sides of the solid waste container in letters and figures not less than three (3) inches in height. 
(b)	The waste hauler collecting solid waste from or transporting the solid waste container having a capacity of at least one-half (1/2) cubic yard shall be responsible for complying with this section. It shall be a violation of this section for any waste hauler to collect solid waste from or to transport such a solid waste container unless the solid waste container has been marked in compliance with this section. 
(c)	For purposes of this section, "solid waste container" means a container or receptacle designed or used for depositing, storing, or accumulating solid waste for collection or transportation by a waste hauler. Without limitation, this definition shall include dumpsters, packer boxes, and roll-offs or other receptacles designed or used to store solid waste or to transport solid waste from a site of generation. 
(d)	This section shall become effective on January 1, 1992.
(Ord. No. 187, § 1, eff. 8-22-92) 
Secs. 21-36-21-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - VEHICLES 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic and motor vehicles generally, Ch. 25. (Back)
Sec. 21-51. - Compliance with division required. 
    No person shall use any vehicle for the purpose of collecting, transporting, delivering or disposing of solid waste within the city except in accordance with the requirements of and as permitted by this division. 
(Ord. No. 174, § 2, eff. 12-5-85) 
Sec. 21-52. - Identification. 
    Any vehicle used for collecting, transporting, delivering or disposing of solid waste within the city shall have the name, address and telephone number of the owner or, if operated by one other than the owner, the operator plainly marked upon both sides of the vehicle in letters and figures not less than three (3) inches in height. 
(Ord. No. 174, § 3, eff. 12-5-85) 
Sec. 21-53. - Specifications. 
    Any vehicle used to collect, transport, deliver, or dispose of solid waste within the city shall meet the requirements of subsection (1) or (2) as follows: 
(1)	Compaction units. All compaction type vehicles shall be constructed in accordance with the following requirements: 
a.	The load-carrying portion of the vehicle shall be equipped with a unit for compacting, and shall be totally and permanently enclosed and of welded steel construction. 
b.	Such vehicles shall be of tight-fitting construction and designed to form a totally enclosed body or unit. 
c.	Such vehicles shall be so equipped that all loading and unloading openings on the body have tight-fitting doors or covers with latches or clamps and rubber or other suitable gaskets to prevent spilling, leaking and the emission of dust. 
(2)	Other vehicles. All vehicles other than compaction type vehicles shall be constructed in accordance with the following requirements: 
a.	The portion of the vehicle used to carry solid waste shall be of steel construction and shall have walls not less than two (2) feet in height. 
b.	The portion of the vehicle used to carry solid waste shall be fully enclosed and covered on the top in such manner as to prevent the contents from escaping therefrom. The covering over the top of the area may be constructed of slats or grates provided that there is no gap or space in excess of three (3) inches in width at any point in or around the cover. 
c.	The requirements set forth in subsection (2) of this section shall apply to the portion of any vehicle designed to hold or contain solid waste, whether such portion is an independent, transportable unit designed to be replaced rather than emptied at the premises or an integral part of the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 174, § 4, eff. 12-5-85) 
Sec. 21-54. - Operation, use, cleaning. 
(a)	While transporting solid waste all vehicles shall have all openings, doors and covers closed and secured by an adequate latch or restraining mechanism to keep them closed while transporting solid waste. 
(b)	The solid waste carrying portion of any vehicle shall not be filled beyond its capacity.
(c)	Where spillage does occur from any solid waste transporting vehicle, the material shall be picked up immediately and the area thoroughly cleaned. 
(d)	Should solid waste be purposely dumped from a vehicle due to heat or fire, the fire shall be immediately extinguished by the most effective means and the area thoroughly cleaned before the vehicle leaves the area where such dumping occurred. 
(e)	Solid waste transporting vehicles shall be cleaned at such intervals as required to maintain them in a sanitary condition and free from disagreeable odors to prevent a nuisance or the attraction of vermin. 
(f)	Solid waste transporting vehicles shall not be parked in any district zoned for residential uses by the zoning ordinance longer than necessary to collect solid waste and shall not be parked, stored, or established at any location so as to a cause a nuisance or hazard to health nor in violation of any provision of the zoning ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 174, § 5, eff. 12-5-85) 
Secs. 21-55-21-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - HAZARDOUS MATERIALS CLEANUP 

Sec. 21-61. - Duty to remove. 
    It shall be the duty of any responsible party to remove immediately hazardous materials released and undertake and complete a total cleanup of the area of the release in such a manner as to ensure that the hazardous materials are fully removed and the area is fully restored to its condition prior to the release of such hazardous materials, or to conditions or standards established by Michigan Department of Natural Resources pursuant to Act 307 of the Michigan Public Acts of 1982, as amended, or other applicable law or environmental law or regulation. 
(Ord. No. 210, § 2, eff. 1-8-95) 
Sec. 21-62. - Failure to remove. 
(a)	Any responsible party who fails to comply completely with section 21-61 shall be liable to the city, its agents, contractors and employees for any costs incurred in the removal and cleanup of any and all hazardous materials and the restoration of the affected property. 
(b)	In the event that any responsible party fails to remove immediately such hazardous material, the city shall have the right to enter on to the property involved with the release and remove and conduct a cleanup of all such hazardous materials, either by city employees or by contractors and agents of the city. 
(c)	Where the HazMat unit is used for any aspect of the removal, cleanup, control or monitoring of any release or other incident involving hazardous materials, the responsible party shall be liable to the city for costs incurred in using the HazMat unit. 
(Ord. No. 210, § 2, eff. 1-8-95) 
Sec. 21-63. - Liability for cost recovery. 
(a)	When the city fire department, department of public works or other city personnel respond to a call for assistance which involves hazardous materials, the responsible parties shall be obligated, jointly and severally to reimburse the city, its agents, contractors and employees for all costs of the city incurred in connection with the response to the incident and any mitigation of any hazardous materials. In addition, all costs incurred by the city under section 21-62 shall be the joint and several responsibility of the responsible parties. For purposes of this section, the costs incurred by the city for any response, mitigation, removal, cleanup, and/or restoration activities shall include, but not be limited to: 
(1)	Per hour charges for fire department and public works department vehicles as established by resolution of the city commission; 
(2)	The costs of personnel, supplies, and equipment of city personnel utilized in connection with the incident; 
(3)	The costs charged to the city for the services of the HazMat unit including, without limitation, personnel, supplies, and equipment, and any costs charged to the city for services of a third party; and 
(4)	Billing and collection costs including attorneys' fees.
(b)	In the event that said costs are not paid, the city may take whatever collection steps may be deemed appropriate, including the placement of all such charges on the tax roll for said property and to levy and collect such costs in the same manner as provided for the levy and collection of real property taxes against such property. 
(c)	The city may pursue any other remedy, or may institute any appropriate action or proceedings in a court of competent jurisdiction to collect costs for which liability is imposed under this division. 
(d)	The recovery of charges composed under this division does not limit or modify liability of parties under local ordinance, state or federal law, rule or regulation. 
(Ord. No. 210, § 2, eff. 1-8-95; Ord. No. 223, § 2, eff. 3-11-96) 
Secs. 21-64-21-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ACCUMULATION AND BURNING OF GARBAGE AND TRASH 

Sec. 21-71. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Garbage means waste resulting from the processing, handling, preparation, sale or consumption of food. 
    Incinerator means any equipment or device designed and used for the purpose of destroying or disposing of garbage or trash by fire. 
    Open burning means a fire from which the products of combustion are emitted directly into the air without passing through a stack or chimney. 
    Trash means all waste material other than garbage, including, but not limited to, yard trimmings such as grass, leaves, twigs, branches, brush, logs and stumps. 
(Comp. Ords. 1977, § 27.171; Ord. No. 183, § 1, eff. 8-23-90) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 21-72. - Accumulation. 
    No person shall allow trash or garbage to accumulate unreasonably upon any premises which he owns or occupies, and it shall be the responsibility of each owner or occupant to provide for the periodic removal of trash and garbage to an area where it may be lawfully placed and which is licensed to receive it. 
(Comp. Ords. 1977, § 27.173) 
Sec. 21-73. - Placement of containers. 
    No can, barrel or other device used or intended to be used to contain, store or receive trash or garbage shall be kept in the front of any premises within the city except for such brief periods of time, which shall not exceed twenty-four (24) hours, as may be necessary to allow for the pickup and removal of the trash or garbage contained therein; provided, however, that it shall be lawful to keep such containers within any garage or other building regardless of the location of such garage or building upon the premises. 
(Comp. Ords. 1977, § 27.174) 
Sec. 21-74. - Open burning prohibited. 
(a)	Open burning is prohibited within the city, and no person shall burn any trash or garbage except within an incinerator as provided by section 21-75 
(b)	This article prohibits open burning for the purpose of preparing food or recreational fire unless there is compliance with the following: 
(1)	The fire is located within a container, utensil, or device designed and intended for outdoor cooking or a recreational fire. Any such container, utensil, or device shall not have a horizontal dimension or diameter greater than forty-eight (48) inches. 
(2)	The fire is located a minimum distance of fifteen (15) feet from any structure and ten (10) feet from any lot line. 
(3)	An adult, eighteen (18) years or older, is present on the premises during the entire duration of the fire. 
(4)	Only fire wood or charcoal may be burned. At no time shall waste, brush, leaves, or any other materials be burned. 
(5)	If fire or police personnel find that the fire or smoke creates a nuisance, hazard, or risk to public safety, they may order that the fire be immediately extinguished. 
(6)	No fires may be held on declared Ozone Action Days.
(7)	No open burning shall be permitted between the hours of 12:00 a.m. midnight and 8:00 a.m. 
(8)	A propane gas grill or charcoal grill burning charcoal only and used solely for cooking is not regulated by this section. 
(Comp. Ords. 1977, §§ 27.172, 27.177; Ord. No. 183, § 2, eff. 8-23-90; Ord. No. 285, § 1, eff. 11-18-2010) 
Sec. 21-75. - Incinerators. 
    No incinerator shall be used to destroy or dispose of trash or garbage by fire except in accordance with the following requirements: 
(1)	The combustion chamber of the incinerator shall be completely enclosed within a building and vented through a chimney or stack; 
(2)	The incinerator shall be designed, constructed, and used so as:
a.	To prevent the emission of noxious odors;
b.	To prevent the emission of smoke, fly ash, heat or other air contaminants in unreasonable quantities or in a manner or to an extent that may be detrimental to the health, safety or welfare of the community; and 
c.	To otherwise meet all applicable local, state or federal laws or regulations.
(Comp. Ords. 1977, § 27.175; Ord. No. 183, § 3, eff. 8-23-90) 
Sec. 21-76. - Freestanding outdoor furnaces prohibited. 
    It is unlawful to install or operate a freestanding outdoor furnace, or to cause or permit the installation or operation of a freestanding outdoor furnace, within the City of Grandville. A freestanding outdoor furnace is defined as a furnace, stove or boiler (a) that is not located within a building intended for habitation by humans, (b) that is designed, intended or used to provide heat and/or hot water to any residence or structure and (c) that burns wood, other solid fuel such as, but not limited to coal, paper, or agricultural products, or any other combustible material. 
(Ord. No. 285, § 2, eff. 11-18-2010) 
Sec. 21-77. - Disposal pursuant to state statutes not prevented by article. 
    This article shall not be construed to prevent the disposal of trash or garbage pursuant to any statutes enacted by the state by those licensed by the state. 
(Comp. Ords. 1977, § 27.179) 
Sec. 21-78. - Trash and garbage violations as civil infractions; authorized official. 
(a)	A person who violates any provision of this article is responsible for a municipal civil infraction in accordance with section 1-9 of this Code; and subject to payment of a civil fine, plus costs and other sanctions, for each infraction or repeat offense, as provided by section 1-9(c) of this Code. 
(b)	The fire chief is hereby designated as the authorized city official to issue municipal civil infraction citations (directing alleged violators to appear in court) or municipal civil infraction violation notices (directing the alleged violator to appear at the municipal ordinance violation bureau) as provided in this Code. 
(Ord. No. 213, § 14, eff. 5-26-95) 
Secs. 21-79-21-95. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SCAVENGERS 

Sec. 21-96. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Container glass means glass of any color typically used in the sale and storage of beverages and foodstuffs. Window glass and other glass with metallic or other coatings are specifically excluded from this definition. 
    Corrugated paper means heavy paperboard consisting of three (3) separate layers of paper with the middle layer molded into parallel ridges and grooves. 
    Heavy plastic containers means biomold grade polyethylene containers such as those commonly used for milk containers. 
    Newspaper means paper commonly referred to as newsprint, a common machine-finished paper made chiefly from pulpwood, upon which news, opinions, advertisements, and other matters of public interest are printed. 
    Recyclable materials means newspaper, corrugated paper, container glass, tin-coated cans and heavy plastic containers, but excludes solid wastes. 
    Solid waste means rejected food wastes, yard wastes and rubbish, excluding recyclable materials normally placed at the curb by the residents of the city for regular weekly collection. 
    Tin-coated cans means any cans typically used in the sale and storage of foodstuffs and made primarily of ferrous metal coated with a thin layer of tin. 
(Ord. No. 166, § 2, eff. 4-9-82) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 21-97. - Findings; service to collect recyclable materials from residential refuse established. 
    The city supports the concept of organized curbside collection of recyclable materials and desires to study the potential for a successful curbside recyclables collection program. Further, the city finds that the collection of recyclable materials from residential refuse will not only serve the general public but may result in a financial advantage to the residents and taxpayers of the community. Therefore, the city, in cooperation with the Kent/Ottawa Resource Recovery Project and others, has established a service to collect source-separated recyclable materials from residential refuse placed at or in the vicinity of the curbline. 
(Ord. No. 166, § 1, eff. 4-9-82) 
Sec. 21-98. - Ownership of recyclable materials placed for collection. 
    From the time at which recyclable materials, contained in suitable containers so as to be easily identified as recyclable materials, are placed in the vicinity of the curb for collection by the city or its authorized agent, such recyclable materials shall be and become the property of the city or its authorized agent. It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for any person, firm, or corporation unauthorized by the city other than the owner, lessee, or occupant of that dwelling to collect or pick up any such recyclable materials. Any and each such collection in violation hereof from one (1) or more premises shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. No. 166, § 3, eff. 4-9-82) 
Chapter 22 - SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Special assessments, Ch. XII. (Back)
Cross reference- Any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor saved from repeal, § 1-6(7); community development, Ch. 7; planning, Ch. 18; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 23; subdivisions and utility extensions, Ch. 24; utilities, Ch. 26. (Back)
State Law reference- Powers re special assessments, MCL 117.4a, 117.4b, 117.4d, 117.5, MSA 5.2074, 5.2075, 5.2077, 5.2084. (Back)
Sec. 22-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Cost, when referring to the cost of any improvement, means the cost of surveys, plans, right-of-way, spreading of rolls, notices, advertising, financing, and construction, and all other costs incidental to the making of such improvement, the special assessments therefor and the financing thereof. 
    Improvement means any public improvement, any part of the cost of which is to be assessed against one (1) or more lots or parcels of land to be especially benefited thereby, in proportion to the benefits to be derived therefrom. 
(Ord. No. 75, eff. 4-16-59; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 17.061) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-2. - Authority to defray cost of improvement by special assessment. 
    The city council shall have the power to determine by resolution that the whole or any part of the cost or expense of any improvement shall be defrayed by special assessments upon the property especially benefited, in proportion to the benefits derived or to be derived, in the manner provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 75, eff. 4-16-59; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 17.062) 
Sec. 22-3. - Petition for improvement. 
    The city council, in order to ascertain whether or not a reasonable number of property owners to be assessed desire any particular improvement to be made, may request and receive a petition therefor or may receive such a petition voluntarily presented; but, in either event, such petition shall be advisory only and shall not be jurisdictional. 
(Ord. No. 75, eff. 4.16-59; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 17.063) 
Sec. 22-4. - Report and recommendation of city manager. 
    Before determining to make any improvement, any part of the cost of which is to be defrayed by special assessment, the city council shall require the city manager to ascertain the assessed valuation of all property affected by the proposed improvement, the number of parcels which show tax delinquencies, the number of parcels owned by public authorities, the number of parcels which are vacant and to prepare, or cause to be prepared, plans and specifications therefor and an estimate of the cost thereof, and to file the same with the city clerk, together with his recommendation as to what proportion of the cost should be paid by special assessment and what part, if any, should be a general obligation of the city, the number of installments in which assessments may be paid, and the lands which should be included in the special assessment district. 
(Ord. No. 75, eff. 4-16-59; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 17.064) 
Sec. 22-5. - Public hearing. 
    After the filing of the city manager's report and recommendation required by section 22-4, a public hearing shall be held before the city council, which hearing shall be held not less than ten (10) days after notice of the time and place thereof has been published and sent by the city clerk by first class mail to all property owners in the proposed district as shown by the current assessment roll of the city. At the time and place specified in such notice for the public hearing, the city council shall meet and hear any person to be affected by the proposed public improvement. The hearing may be adjourned from time to time by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 75, eff. 4-16-59; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 17.065) 
State law reference- Special assessment notices and hearings, MCL 211.741 et seq., MSA 5.3534(1) et seq. 
Sec. 22-6. - Determination to make improvement. 
    After the public hearing required by section 22-5, the city council may by resolution determine to make the improvement and to defray the whole or any part of the cost of the improvement by special assessment upon the property especially benefited in proportion to the benefits derived or to be derived. By resolution, the city council shall approve the plans and specifications for the improvement; determine the estimated cost thereof; determine what proportion of such cost shall be paid by special assessment upon the property especially benefited and what part, if any, shall be a general obligation of the city; determine the number of installments in which assessments may be paid; determine the rate of interest to be charged on installments; designate the district or land and premises upon which special assessment shall be levied; and direct the city assessor to prepare a special assessment roll in accordance with the city council's determination. 
(Ord. No. 75, eff. 4-16-59; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 17.066; Ord. No. 75-C, eff. 8-7-84) 
Sec. 22-7. - Preparation of roll. 
(a)	The city assessor shall prepare a special assessment roll including all lots and parcels of land within the special assessment district designated by the city council and shall assess to each such lot or parcel of land such relative portion of the whole sum to be levied against all the lands in the special assessment district as the benefit to such lot or parcel of land bears to the total benefits to all lands in such district. There shall also be entered upon such roll the amount which has been assessed to the city at large, if any. 
(b)	When the city assessor shall have completed such assessment roll, he shall attach thereto, or endorse thereon, his certificate to the effect that the roll has been made by him pursuant to a resolution of the city council, giving the date of adoption of the resolution, and that in making the assessments therein he has as near as may be according to his best judgment conformed in all respects to the directions contained in such resolution and to the city Charter and the provisions of this chapter. Thereupon he shall file the special assessment roll with the city clerk who shall present the same to the city council. 
(Ord. No. 75, eff. 4-16-59; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 17.067) 
Sec. 22-8. - Hearing on roll; objections, corrections or changes, confirmation. 
(a)	Upon receipt of the special assessment roll, the city council shall order it filed in the office of the city clerk for public examination and shall fix the time and place when it will meet and review such roll, which meeting shall be held not less than ten (10) days after notice thereof has been published and sent by the city clerk by first class mail to all property owners in the proposed district as shown by the current assessment roll of the city. Such notice shall specify the time and also the place of such meeting. 
(b)	Any person deeming himself aggrieved by the special assessment roll may file his objections thereto in writing with the city clerk prior to the close of the hearing, which written objections shall specify in what respect he deems himself aggrieved. 
(c)	The city council shall meet and review the special assessment roll at the time and place appointed or at an adjourned date therefor and shall consider any written objections thereto. The city council may correct the roll as to any assessment or description of any lot or parcel of land or other errors appearing therein. Any changes made in such roll shall be noted in the city council's minutes. After such hearing and review, the city council may confirm such special assessment roll with such corrections as it may have made, if any, or may refer it back to the city assessor for revision or may annul it and any proceedings in connection therewith. No original special assessment roll shall be finally confirmed except by the affirmative vote of five (5) of the members of the city council if prior to such confirmation written objections to the proposed improvement have been filed by the owners of property which will be required to bear more than fifty (50) percent of the amount of the special assessment. The city clerk shall endorse the date of confirmation upon each special assessment roll. 
(d)	The special assessment roll shall, upon confirmation, be final and conclusive.
(Ord. No. 75, eff. 4-16-59; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 17.068) 
State law reference- Special assessment notices and hearings, MCL 211.741 et seq., MSA 5.3534(1) et seq. 
Sec. 22-9. - Lien, notice, payment without penalty, installments, collections. 
(a)	All special assessments contained in any special assessment roll, including any part thereof deferred as to payment, shall from the date of confirmation of such roll constitute a lien upon the respective lots or parcels of land assessed and until paid shall be a charge against the respective owners of the several lots and parcels of land and a debt to the city from the persons to whom they are assessed. Such lien shall be of the same character and effect as the lien created by the city Charter for city taxes and shall include accrued interest and penalties. No judgment or decree, nor any act of the city council vacating a special assessment, shall destroy or impair the lien of the city upon the premises assessed for such amount of the assessment as may be equitably charged against the same or as by a regular mode of proceeding might be lawfully assessed thereon. All special assessments shall become due upon confirmation of the special assessment roll or in annual installments not to exceed fifteen (15) in number as the city council may determine at the time of confirmation and if in annual installments, the city council shall determine the first installment to be due upon confirmation or on the following July first and subsequent installments on July first of succeeding years. 
(b)	The assessment roll shall be transmitted by the city clerk to the city treasurer for collection immediately after its confirmation. The city treasurer shall mail statements of the several assessments to the respective owners, as indicated by the records of the city assessor, of the several lots and parcels of land assessed, stating the amount of the assessment and the manner in which it may be paid; provided, however, that failure to mail any such statement shall not invalidate the assessment or entitle the owner to an extension of time within which to pay the assessment. 
(c)	The whole or any part of any such special assessment may be paid without interest or penalty after the date of confirmation on the special assessment roll and before the following April first or such other date as shall be set by the city council when the roll is confirmed. Not later than fifteen (15) days after the end of the period, the city treasurer shall transmit such roll to the city assessor with all payments upon assessments noted thereon. The city assessor shall then divide any remaining balance of each assessment into such number of equal installments as shall have been fixed by the city council; provided, that if such division operates to make any installment less than ten dollars ($10.00), then the city assessor shall reduce the number of installments so that each installment shall be above and as near to ten dollars ($10.00) as possible. 
(d)	The first installment shall be spread upon the next city tax roll in a column headed "Special Assessments," together with interest upon all unpaid installments from the date set by the city council as provided in subsection (c) of this section to the first day of July of the year in which such tax roll is made; provided, that any fraction of a month shall be considered as a full month. Thereafter one (1) installment shall be spread upon each annual tax roll, together with one (1) year's interest upon all unpaid installments; provided, that when any annual installment shall have been prepaid as provided in subsection (f) of this section, then there shall be spread upon the tax roll for such year only the interest upon all unpaid installments. 
(e)	After each installment has been placed on the tax rolls, the same shall be collected by the city treasurer, or other person designated by law, with the same rights and remedies and the same penalties and interest as provided in the Charter for the collection of taxes. 
(f)	After the expiration of the period provided for in subsection (c) of this section, any installment which has not been spread upon the tax rolls may be discharged by paying the face amount thereof plus interest thereon to date of payment. Any person desiring to pay such installment in advance shall first secure the proper statement from the city assessor to permit the city treasurer to compute the amount to be paid. The city treasurer shall report to the city assessor all advance payments on installments so that the city assessor shall have such information before spreading installments on the next city tax roll. 
(Ord. No. 75, eff. 4-16-59; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 17.069; Ord. No. 75-B, eff. 1-4-71) 
Sec. 22-10. - Certification of cost. 
    Upon completion of the improvement and the payment of the cost thereof, the city manager shall certify to the city council the total cost of the improvement, together with the amount of the original roll for the improvement. 
(Ord. No. 75, eff. 4-16-59; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 17.070) 
Sec. 22-11. - Deficiency in assessments. 
    Should the assessments in any special assessment roll, including the amount assessed to the city at large, prove insufficient for any reason to pay the cost of the improvement for which they were made, then the city council shall make additional assessments against the city and the several lots and parcels of land, in the same ratio as the original assessments, to supply the deficiency; but the total amount assessed against any lot or parcel of land shall not exceed the value of the benefits received from the improvement, provided that the additional pro rata assessment shall not exceed twenty-five (25) percent of the assessment as originally confirmed unless a meeting of the city council is held to review such additional assessment. Notices for such meeting shall be mailed as provided in the case of review of the original special assessment roll. 
(Ord. No. 75, eff. 4-16-59; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 17.071) 
Sec. 22-12. - Excess of assessments. 
    The excess by which any special assessment proves larger than the actual cost of the improvement and expenses incidental thereto may be placed in the general fund of the city if such excess is five (5) percent, or less of the assessment, but should the assessment prove larger than necessary by more than five (5) percent the entire excess shall be refunded on a pro rata basis to the owners of the property assessed. Such refund shall be made by credit against future unpaid installments in the inverse order in which they are payable to the extent such installments then exist and the balance of such refund shall be in cash. No refunds may be made which contravene the provisions of any outstanding evidence of indebtedness secured in whole or part by such special assessment. 
(Ord. No. 75, eff. 4-16-59; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 17.072) 
Sec. 22-13. - Deferred payments. 
(a)	If in the opinion of the city assessor and the city council any person holding property subject to special assessment is unable to contribute toward the cost thereof by reason of poverty, payment of such special assessment or any part thereof may be resolution of the city council be deferred until the death of such person or until such person transfers any part or all of his interest in such property. At such time any deferred payments of the special assessment shall become due and payable together with any and all interest accrued thereon to such time. While payment is so deferred, interest on the amount of the special assessment shall accrue and be added to the amount of the deferred special assessment. 
(b)	If property subject to special assessment is only partially used for residential purposes or is entirely undeveloped or unplatted, the city council may by resolution defer payment of the special assessment levied against part or all of such property. Deferment of the payment of special assessments in such case may be permitted until such time as the premises are developed or platted or, in the case of water or sewer services, until such services are connected to any part of the premises for which payment was deferred. At such time, the entire amount of the special assessment against the area so developed, platted or connected with sewer or water services shall become due and payable. If there is no such development, platting or connection, deferment of the payment of such special assessment shall terminate five (5) years after the special improvement was completed or at the time title to the premises subject to deferred special assessment changes, whichever occur first. Upon the happening of either such event, the first installment of the special assessment shall become due and payable and the remaining installments shall be paid in regular annual intervals thereafter together with interest on the amount of the special assessment from the date payment of the first installment became due. The city council may after a public hearing extend the period for deferment of the payment of any such special assessment and interest thereon for such period as it finds reasonable in the light of all factors prevailing at that time. 
(c)	If after consideration of all relevant circumstances, the city council determines that it would be equitable and not detrimental to the overall best interests of the city, the city council may by resolution defer the payment of any special assessments levied against property in a special assessment district for such period as the city council shall specify, up to five (5) years. When the period of deferment ends, the first installment of the special assessment shall become due and payable and the remaining installments shall be paid in regular annual intervals thereafter together with interest on the amount of the special assessment from the date payment of the first installment became due. The city council may after a public hearing extend the period for deferment of the payment of any such special assessment and interest thereon for such period as it finds reasonable in the light of all factors prevailing at that time. 
(d)	Deferment of the payment of any special assessment shall not destroy or impair the lien of the city on the premises so assessed from the date of confirmation of the special assessment roll as above provided. The resolution deferring payment may be made as part of the resolution confirming the roll. If the city council shall by resolution determine, after notice to the owner of the property for which payment was deferred and after public hearing, that there has been a material change in the circumstances on which the deferment was based or that the best interests of the city so require, the deferment may be terminated and all or part of the deferred payments and accrued interest, if any, shall then become due and payable. 
(Ord. No. 75, eff. 4-16-59; Ord. No. 75-A, eff. 8-25-66; Ord. No. 75-B, eff. 1-4-71; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 17.072-A) 
State law reference- Deferment of special assessments for older persons, MCL 211.761 et seq., MSA 5.3536(1) et seq. 
Sec. 22-14. - Illegal assessment; reassessment procedure. 
    Whenever any special assessment shall, in the opinion of the city council, be invalid by reason of irregularity of informality in the proceedings, or if any court of competent jurisdiction shall adjudge such assessment to be illegal, the city council shall, whether the improvement has been made or not, or whether any part of the assessment has been paid or not, have power to cause a new assessment to be made for the same purpose for which the former assessment was made. All proceedings on such reassessment and for the collection thereof shall be conducted in the same manner as provided for the original assessment. Whenever the assessment or any part thereof levied upon any premises has been so set aside, if the same has been paid and not refunded, the payment so made and not refunded, the payment so made shall be applied upon the reassessment and the reassessment shall to that extent be deemed satisfied. 
(Ord. No. 75, eff. 4-16-59; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 17.073) 
Sec. 22-15. - Remedies for delinquent payments. 
    In addition to any other remedies and without impairing the lien therefor, any delinquent special assessment, together with interest and penalties, may be collected in an action in assumpsit in the name of the city against the person assessed in any court having jurisdiction of the amount. If in any such action it shall appear that by reason of any irregularities or informalities the assessment has not been properly made against the defendant or upon the premises sought to be charged, the court may, nevertheless, on satisfactory proof that expense has been incurred by the city which is a proper charge against the defendant or the premises in question, render judgment for the amount properly chargeable against such defendant or upon such premises. 
(Ord. No. 75, eff. 4-16-59; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 17.074) 
Sec. 22-16. - Apportionment of assessment when property divided after confirmation of assessment and before complete collection. 
    Should any parcel of land be divided after a special assessment thereon has been confirmed and before the complete collection thereof, the city assessor shall apportion the uncollected amounts between the several divisions thereof. The assessor shall thereupon give notice by mail to the owner of each of the several divisions of such property, insofar as the owners are known to him, and such apportionment by the assessor shall be final unless any of the owners shall file written objections thereto within fifteen (15) days thereafter, which written objections shall be filed with the city clerk and shall stand as an appeal of the apportionment to the city council. In the event of any such appeal from the apportionment of the assessor, the city council shall review the apportionment and either confirm the assessor's apportionment or make such other apportionment as shall to such council appear to be equitable in the circumstances. 
(Ord. No. 221, § 1, eff. 12-1-95) 
Chapter 23 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES 
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the city saved from repeal, § 1-6(3); any ordinance establishing or prescribing grades in the city saved from repeal, § 1-6(6); possession of alcoholic liquor open container in public places prohibited, § 3-3; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; community development, Ch. 7; parks and recreation, Ch. 17; planning, Ch. 18; special assessments, Ch. 22; subdivisions and utility extensions, Ch. 24; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 25; utilities, Ch. 26; vegetation, Ch. 27. (Back)
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 23-1. - Vacation of street, alley, public ground. 
(a)	When the city council shall deem it advisable to vacate, discontinue, or abolish any street, alley, or public ground, or any part thereof, it shall by resolution so declare and in the same resolution shall appoint a time not less than two (2) weeks thereafter when it will meet and hear objections thereto. Notice of such meeting shall be published once not less than ten (10) days before the time appointed for such meeting in conformance with the city Charter, and notice shall be sent by first class mail to all persons having an interest in the land abutting on any such street, alley, or public ground. Failure to mail such notice shall not invalidate action under this section by the city council. 
(b)	Objections to such proposed action of the city council may be filed with the city clerk, in writing, and if any such shall be filed, the street, alley, or public ground, or any part thereof, shall not be vacated or discontinued except by a concurring vote of two-thirds of the councilmen elect. 
(Ord. No. 78, eff. 6-18-59; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 17.022) 
Sec. 23-2. - Driving over sidewalk, curb, parkway. 
    No person shall drive any vehicle over or upon any sidewalk, curb, or parkway within the city without first having protected such sidewalk, curb, or parkway from damage. 
(Ord. No. 92, eff. 6-13-60; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.577) 
Secs. 23-3-23-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SIDEWALKS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 23-26. - Permission from city council required to build sidewalk. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to build or construct any sidewalk upon any street or alley within the city without first receiving permission and authority from the city council, authorizing and permitting him to build and construct such sidewalk. Upon receipt of such authority from the city council, it shall be the duty of such person building or constructing the sidewalk, to build and construct the sidewalk in accordance with the direction of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 10, eff. 6-12-08; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 17.001) 
Secs. 23-27-23-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - REPAIR AND MAINTENANCE 

Sec. 23-46. - Duty of owners of abutting lands. 
    It shall be the duty of all owners of land in the city to maintain and keep in repair all sidewalks along public streets and highways in the city upon which such lands abut at the cost and expense of the respective owners of such lands. 
(Ord. No. 50, eff. 9-12-40; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 17.011) 
Sec. 23-47. - Notice to owner of abutting lands to repair. 
    If any sidewalk shall be found to be out of repair, the city council may cause a notice in writing to be served upon the owner of the land abutting the sidewalk requiring the owner to put the sidewalk in good repair within twenty (20) days from the date of the notice. Such notice may be served in person if the owner resides within the city or may be served by mail to the last known address of the owner who resides outside the city. 
(Ord. No. 50, eff. 9-12-40; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 17.012) 
Sec. 23-48. - Repair by city; lien upon abutting land. 
    If the owner of the abutting land shall fail to put the sidewalk in good repair within the time limited by the notice to repair, the city council may order the street administrator to make the repairs, and the cost thereof including the necessary supervision and clerical service incidental thereto shall be the obligation of the owner to the city and shall be a lien upon the abutting land and shall be due and payable forthwith. If the lien shall remain unpaid, the city clerk shall certify the amount thereof to the city assessor who shall cause the same to be entered upon the tax assessment roll with interest as set by the city council pursuant to state law, from the date when the lien became due and payable. Such sum shall be collected by the city treasurer in the same manner as the general taxes of the city. The city council in its discretion may cause the cost of any such repairs to be defrayed by special assessment in the same manner as other special assessments are made and levied within the city. 
(Ord. No. 50, eff. 9-12-40; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 17.013) 
Sec. 23-49. - Emergency repairs. 
    If the city council shall determine that any sidewalk is in such condition as to seriously endanger life or limb, it may cause necessary repairs to be made forthwith either with or without notice to the owner of the abutting lands, and the cost thereof shall be paid and collected as provided in this division. 
(Ord. No. 50, eff. 9-12-40; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 17.014) 
Secs. 23-50-23-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CONSTRUCTION ACTIVITIES WITHIN PUBLIC RIGHT-OF-WAY 

Sec. 23-66. - Promulgation of regulations by city council. 
    The city council shall promulgate by resolution such regulations as are necessary or appropriate for the purposes of this article. 
(Ord. No. 173, § 11, eff. 6-18-85) 
Sec. 23-67. - Street, sidewalk, driveway, culvert, curb construction-Highway construction permit. 
(a)	Required. No person shall engage in building, replacing, or repairing any street, sidewalk, driveway, driveway approach, driveway culvert, curb or curbcut, within the public right-of-way of the city; nor shall any person install, repair or replace any connection to or conduit attaching to a water main, storm sewer or sanitary sewer, within the public right-of-way of the city; nor shall any person install, repair or replace any lawn sprinkling system within the public right-of-way without first obtaining a highway construction permit from the director of inspections. 
(b)	Compliance with article. No highway construction permit shall be issued unless there has been compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(c)	Application. Applications for highway construction permits shall be submitted on forms provided by the director of inspections. 
(d)	Fee. Prior to the issuance of the highway construction permit a fee, as specified by resolution of the city council, shall be paid to the city clerk. 
(e)	Term. A highway construction permit shall be valid for thirty (30) days after the date of issuance. 
(f)	Indemnification of city. The permittee shall indemnify and hold harmless the city and its employees and agents from any and all damages caused by any of the work performed pursuant to the permit. 
(g)	Type and extent of work specified. The permit shall specify the type and extent of the work to be performed pursuant to the permit. 
(Ord. No. 173, § 1, eff. 6-18-85) 
Sec. 23-68. - Same-Highway construction license. 
(a)	Required. Any contractor or other person who is compensated in any manner for performing any of the work specified in section 23-67 must obtain a highway construction license from the city clerk before performing such work. 
(b)	Application. Application for an annual highway construction license shall be submitted on forms provided by the city clerk. 
(c)	Term, expiration date. The highway construction license shall be issued hereunder for a term of twelve (12) months, unless earlier revoked, commencing on July 1, 1989. The terms of any valid city permit which would expire prior to July 1, 1989, are hereby extended until such date. 
(d)	Fee. The fee for an annual highway construction license shall be as specified by resolution of the city council. 
(e)	Prerequisites to issuance. No highway construction license shall be issued unless the applicant shall comply with the bonding and insurance provisions of this article, all other applicable provisions of this article and all applicable provisions of any regulations adopted by the city council pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. No. 173, § 2(a), eff. 6-18-85) 
Sec. 23-69. - Same-Bond. 
(a)	Required. Any contractor or other person who is compensated in any manner for performing any of the work specified in section 23-67 must file a performance bond with the city clerk in an amount established by resolution of the city council. 
(b)	Conditions. The bond shall be conditioned upon performance of the conditions of the highway construction permit as specified in this article by resolution of the city council. 
(c)	Form. The form for the bond shall be as specified by resolution of the city council. 
(d)	Annual bond or individual project bond. The bond may be an annual bond in an amount as prescribed by resolution of the city council for the term of the permit to cover all such work to be performed during the term of the permit or may be an individual bond for the work to be performed under a single highway construction permit. 
(Ord. No. 173, § 2(b), eff. 6-18-85) 
Sec. 23-70. - Same-Insurance. 
    Any contractor or other person who is compensated in any manner for performing any of the work specified in section 23-67 must file a certificate of insurance with the city clerk evidencing insurance coverage in an amount as prescribed by resolution of the city council protecting the city and its employees and agents against any and all claims for damage arising from the operations covered by the highway construction permit. The certificate shall provide that the insurance may not be canceled without ten (10) days' written notice to the city. 
(Ord. No. 173, § 2(c), eff. 6-18-85) 
Sec. 23-71. - Same-Description and plans of proposed work. 
(a)	No highway construction permit for any work specified in section 23-67 shall be issued unless the application is accompanied by a description of the proposed work. In addition, any application relating to driveways to be constructed in a commercial or industrial zone or to be used in conjunction with any use other than a single-family or two-family residence must be accompanied by one (1) set of plans of the proposed work to be reviewed by the director of inspections prior to issuance of the permit. 
(b)	Plans submitted pursuant to this section shall be drawn to scale and shall show the following: 
(1)	The location of the proposed work in relation to property lines, corners, existing drives and curbcuts, drainage and utility structures and trees within one hundred (100) feet of the proposed work; 
(2)	Surface features such as sidewalks, existing curb and gutter and direction of drainage flow in the area within one hundred (100) feet of the proposed work. 
(c)	Descriptions and plans shall be submitted for review two (2) working days prior to the time work is to begin. 
(Ord. No. 173, § 3, eff. 6-18-85) 
Sec. 23-72. - Same-Compliance with city specifications. 
    All work specified in section 23-67 shall be performed according to standard construction specifications, details, and conditions as set forth by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 173, § 5, eff. 6-18-85) 
Sec. 23-73. - Construction, repair, installation of utility lines-Utility line permit. 
(a)	Required term. No person shall construct, repair, install or replace telephone lines, electrical power lines, gas lines or cable television lines within the public right-of-way in the city, whether aboveground or underground, without first obtaining a utility line permit from the director of inspections which permit shall specify the type and extent of the work to be performed under the permit and shall be valid for sixty (60) days after the date of issuance. 
(b)	Application. Application for utility line permits shall be submitted on forms approved by the director of inspections. 
(c)	Fee. Fees as specified in a resolution of the city council shall be paid to the city clerk. The fees shall not be collected prior to the issuance of the utility line permit but utility line permit holders shall be invoiced for the applicable fees on a monthly basis. 
(d)	Annual permit. An annual utility line permit permitting the holder of the permit to perform limited activities without the necessity of obtaining a regular utility line permit for each individual activity is hereby authorized subject to the following provisions: 
(1)	The fee for the permit shall be by resolution of the city council.
(2)	Activities permissible under the annual utility line permit shall be limited to the hookup of individual properties to any telephone lines, electrical power lines, gas lines, or cable television lines already existing within the public right-of-way and to the erection or replacement of telephone or electric power poles within the public right-of-way. 
(3)	Holders of the permit shall comply with all other provisions of this article, including notice requirements. 
(4)	The annual utility line permit shall be issued hereunder for a term of twelve (12) months, unless earlier revoked, commencing on July 1, 1989. The terms of any valid city permit which would expire prior to July 1, 1989, are hereby extended until such date. 
(Ord. No. 173, § 7(a), (c), (f), eff. 6-18-85) 
Sec. 23-74. - Same-Bond. 
(a)	Required. Prior to the issuance of a utility line permit, any person who seeks to perform any of the work specified in section 23-73 shall file a performance bond with the city clerk unless exempted by this section. 
(b)	Conditions. The bond shall be conditioned upon performance of the conditions of the utility line permit as specified in this article and by resolution of the city council. 
(c)	Form. The form for the bond shall be as specified in a resolution adopted by the city council. 
(d)	Annual bond or individual project bond. The bond may be an annual bond in the amount as prescribed by resolution of the city council for the term of the permit to cover all such work performed during the term of the permit or may be an individual bond for the work to be performed under a single utility line permit. 
(e)	Exemptions. Utility companies regulated by the state public service commission are exempt from the bonding requirements of this section if the work specified in this section is performed by their employees. However, if said utility companies contract for the performance of such work, the contractor must comply with the bonding requirements of this section. 
(Ord. No. 173, § 7(d), eff. 6-18-85) 
Sec. 23-75. - Same-Insurance. 
(a)	Required.
