State Law reference- Michigan Vehicle Code, MCL 257.1 et seq.; regulation by local authorities, MCL 257.605, 257.606, 257.610. (Back)
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 25-1. - Warrantless arrests. 
    A peace officer, without a warrant, may arrest a person in any of the following situations: 
(1)	The officer is has reasonable cause to believe the person was, at the time of an accident in this city, the operator of a vehicle involved in the accident and was operating the vehicle in violation of section 25-28(5.15(1), (3), or (6)) or section 25-28(5.15m) of this Code, or section 625(1), (3), or (6) or section 625m of the Michigan Vehicle Code, Act No. 300 of the Public Acts of 1949, being sections 257.625 and 257.625m of the Michigan Compiled Laws. 
(2)	The person is found in the driver's seat of a vehicle parked or stopped on a highway or street within the city if any part of the vehicle intrudes into the roadway and the peace officer has reasonable cause to believe the person was operating the vehicle in violation of section 25-28(5.15(1), (3), or (6) or section 25-28(5.15m) of this Code, or section 625(1), (3), or (6) or section 625m of Act No. 300 of the Public Acts of 1949. 
(3)	The peace officer has reasonable cause to believe the person was, at the time of an accident, the operator of a snowmobile involved in the accident and was operating the snowmobile in violation of section 82127(1) or (3) or part 821 (snowmobiles) of the Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act, Act No. 451 of the Public Acts of 1994, being section 324.82127 of the Michigan Compiled Laws. 
(4)	The peace officer has reasonable cause to believe the person was, at the time of an accident, the operator of an ORV involved in the accident and was operating the ORV in violation of section 81134(1) or (2) or 81135 of part 811 (off-road recreation vehicles) of Act No. 451 of the Public Acts of 1994, being section 324.81134 and 324.81135 of the Michigan Compiled Laws. 
(5)	The peace officer has reasonable cause to believe the person was, at the time of an accident, the operator of a vessel involved in the accident and was operating the vessel in violation of section 80176(1) or (3) or part 801 (marine safety) of Act No. 451 of the Public Acts of 1994, being section 324.80176 of the Michigan Compiled Laws. 
(Ord. No. 227, § 2, 4-3-97) 
Secs. 25-2-25-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MICHIGAN VEHICLE CODE AND UNIFORM TRAFFIC CODE 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 243, § 1, eff. Sept. 4, 2000, repealed the former Art. II, §§ 25-26-25-28 and enacted a new Art. II, § 25-26 as set out herein. The former Art. II pertained to similar subject matter. For complete derivation please see the Code Comparative Table at the back of this volume. 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt Uniform Traffic Code, MCL 257.951. (Back)
Sec. 25-26. - Adoption by reference of Michigan Vehicle Code. 
(a)	The Michigan Vehicle Code (Act No. 300 of the Public Acts of 1949, as amended; MCL 257.1 et seq.), as amended from time to time, is hereby adopted by reference. 
(b)	References in the Michigan Vehicle Code to "local authorities" shall mean the City of Grandville. 
(c)	The city clerk shall publish this ordinance in the manner required by law and shall publish, at the same time, a notice stating the purpose of the Michigan Vehicle Code and the fact that a complete copy of the Code is available in the office of the city clerk available for inspection by and distribution to the public at all times. 
(d)	The penalties provided by the Michigan Vehicle Code are adopted by reference provided, however, that the city may not enforce any provision of the Michigan Vehicle Code for which the maximum period of imprisonment is greater than ninety-three (93) days. 
(e)	The Michigan Vehicle Code adopted by reference is amended by inserting immediately following Section MCLA 257.674(1)(aa) the following three (3) subsections which shall read as follows: 
(bb)	Upon the public streets between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m., from December 1 through the following March 31. 
(cc)	Between a sidewalk and street curb.
(dd)	On private property without the consent of the owner of such private property.
(Ord. No. 237, § 1, 8-27-99; Ord. No. 238, §§ 2-10, 10-1-99; Ord. No. 243, § 1, 9-4-2000; Ord. No. 253, § 1, 12-17-2002; Ord. No. 264, § 1, 3-18-2004) 
Sec. 25-27. - Adoption by reference of Uniform Traffic Code. 
(a)	The Uniform Traffic Code for Cities, Townships, and Villages ("Uniform Traffic Code") promulgated by the Department of State Police in Rule No. 2002-009 (effective October 30, 2002) in accordance with Public Act No. 62 of 1956, as amended, is hereby adopted by reference. 
(b)	References in the Uniform Traffic Code to "governmental unit" shall mean the city.
(c)	The city clerk shall publish this article in the manner required by law and shall publish, at the same time, a notice stating the purpose of the Uniform Traffic Code and the fact that a complete copy of the Code is available for inspection by the public at the office of the city clerk. 
(d)	Violations of the provisions of the Uniform Traffic Code designated as civil infractions shall constitute civil infractions under the City Code. Violations of the Uniform Traffic Code designated as misdemeanors shall constitute misdemeanors under the City Code. 
(e)	All current traffic control orders are hereby ratified and confirmed and remain in full effect without further action of the city. 
(f)	R28.1323 is hereby added to the Uniform Traffic Code to read as follows:
R28.1323. Engine brakes prohibited in certain areas. 
(1)	For purposes of this section, "engine brakes" are defined as an exhaust or exhaust manifold powered auxiliary braking system found on trucks. The terms "truck" and "truck tractor" used in this section shall have the same meaning as provided in the Michigan Vehicle Code, as amended from time to time, being MCL 257.1 et seq. 
(2)	The city council hereby finds that engine brakes are an auxiliary system and that drivers of trucks have other means of braking. In certain areas of the city, the use and application of engine brakes can be noisy and disruptive of the peace and tranquility of nearby residential areas. 
(3)	The traffic engineer is hereby authorized to designate streets, or parts of streets, where it is unlawful for the driver of a truck or truck tractor to use engine brakes (except in an emergency situation). The traffic engineer shall erect appropriate traffic-control devices to give notice of the prohibited use of engine brakes. 
(4)	A person who violates a prohibition on the use of engine brakes on designated streets or parts of streets under this section is responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(Ord. No. 253, § 2, 12-17-2002; Ord. No. 270, § 1, 4-7-2005) 
Secs. 25-28-25-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING 
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate parking, stopping and standing, MCL 257.606(1)(a). (Back)
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 25-51-25-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - INOPERABLE, DISMANTLED CARS 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Nuisance generally, Ch. 4. (Back)
Sec. 25-66. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Dismantled or partially dismantled motor vehicle means a motor vehicle from which some part that is ordinarily a component of such motor vehicle has been removed or is missing. 
    Inoperable motor vehicle means a motor vehicle that by reason of dismantling, disrepair or other cause is incapable of being propelled under its own power. 
    Motor vehicle means any wheeled vehicle which is self-propelled or intended to be self-propelled. 
(Ord. No. 119, eff. 5-10-64; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.533) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 25-67. - Construction. 
    This division shall not be construed as repealing any ordinance now in effect or hereafter made effective relating to rubbish, litter, garbage, refuse, trash or junk, but shall be construed as supplementary to any such ordinances as well as any statutes of the state relating thereto. 
(Ord. No. 119, eff. 5-10-64; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.534) 
Sec. 25-68. - Storage. 
    It is hereby declared to be unlawful for any person to store on, place on or permit to be stored or placed on or allowed to remain on any platted or unplatted parcel of land a dismantled, partially dismantled or inoperable motor vehicle or any parts of a motor vehicle if the platted or unplatted parcel of land is located in the city, except as the same may be permitted under the provisions of the zoning ordinance of the city unless the partially dismantled motor vehicle or parts of a motor vehicle shall be kept in a wholly enclosed garage or other wholly enclosed structure. 
(Ord. No. 119, eff. 5-10-64; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.531) 
Sec. 25-69. - Violation declared public nuisance. 
    The presence of a dismantled, partially dismantled or inoperable vehicle or parts of a motor vehicle on any platted or unplatted parcel of land in violation of the terms of this division is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 119, eff. 5-10-64; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.535) 
Secs. 25-70-25-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - BICYCLES 
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate bicycles, MCL 257.606(1)(i). (Back)
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 25-91-25-105. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - REGISTRATION 

Sec. 25-106. - Required; exceptions. 
    No person shall ride or propel a bicycle or adult tricycle upon any roadway, sidewalk, alley, or public path set aside for the use of bicycles unless such bicycle or adult tricycle has been registered and a tag is attached thereto as provided in this division; provided however, that no registration shall be required for a bicycle having wheels less than twenty (20) inches in diameter; and provided further, that the provisions of this section shall not apply to any bicycle owner or rider from another city or community who has complied with its bicycle licensing or registration ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 150, eff. 4-11-75; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.243) 
Sec. 25-107. - Application, fee. 
    Application for a bicycle registration shall be made to the chief of police upon a form provided for that purpose, which registration shall be renewed by May 1 each year thereafter. An application fee as prescribed by resolution of the city council shall accompany each application. 
(Ord. No. 150, eff. 4-11-75; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.244) 
Sec. 25-108. - Issuance. 
    The chief of police or his designated representatives shall on proper application and payment of the registration fee issue a bicycle registration to such applicant as he knows or has reasonable grounds to believe is the owner or is entitled to the possession of a bicycle. No such registration shall be issued if such bicycle is found or determined to be in an unsafe condition. The chief of police shall register such bicycle as follows: Number and date thereof, name, address and phone number of owner, the manufacturer, and serial number or I.D. number on the frame of the bicycle. No bicycle registration shall be issued unless the bicycle is properly stamped with the manufacturer's serial number or the owner's driver's license number or social security number. The chief of police shall also keep a record of all bicycle registration fees collected by him and turn over same for deposit by the city treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 150, eff. 4-11-75; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.245) 
Sec. 25-109. - Tag. 
(a)	The chief of police upon registering a bicycle shall issue a suitable registration tag assigned to the bicycle. 
(b)	Such registration tag shall be firmly attached to the vertical frame member of the bicycle or prominently attached to the rear fender of such bicycle for which it is issued in such a position as to be plainly visible. 
(c)	No person shall remove such tag from a bicycle or mutilate or deface it.
(d)	In case of loss or mutilation the owner by showing proof of such loss or mutilation shall apply for issuance of a replacement at no cost. 
(Ord. No. 150, eff. 4-11-75; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.246) 
Sec. 25-110. - Transfer. 
    Upon the sale or transfer of a bicycle, the tag issued for such bicycle shall remain attached thereto, and the transferer shall endorse upon the reverse side of the bicycle registration certificate issued for such bicycle the name and address of the transferee and the date. The transferee shall, within ten (10) days after such sale or transfer, notify the chief of police of the sale or transfer and, unless he is a person engaged in the business of buying and selling bicycles, shall obtain a new bicycle registration certificate. 
(Ord. No. 150, eff. 4-11-75; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.247) 
Sec. 25-111. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person of the age of sixteen (16) years or older who shall violate any of the provisions of this division shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine of up to one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. No. 150, eff. 4-11-75; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.248) 
Secs. 25-112-25-135. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - MOTORCYCLES AND ALL TERRAIN VEHICLES 

Sec. 25-136. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    All terrain vehicle means every self-propelled motor vehicle whose primary intended use is to be operated, as a recreational vehicle on land off from the public streets. The term includes, for example, those vehicles commonly called "all terrain vehicles," "go-carts" and "dune buggies" but excludes farm tractors and domestic garden vehicles. 
    Motorcycle means every motor-driven vehicle having a saddle or seat for the use of the operator and designed to travel with no more than three (3) wheels in contact with the ground, but excluding farm tractors and domestic garden vehicles. The term includes those vehicles commonly called "minibikes," "trail bikes," "motor-driven cycles," "motorbikes" and "motor scooters." 
    Vehicle means both motorcycles and all terrain vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 137, eff. 8-8-71; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.511) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 25-137. - Legal owner responsible for use of vehicle and property damage. 
    The legal owner of every motorcycle and every all terrain vehicle shall be responsible for all use made of his vehicle within the city. The legal owner shall be responsible for any damage caused by the operation of such vehicle on private property. No such owner shall knowingly authorize or permit such vehicle to be operated by any person in violation of any part of this article. 
(Ord. No. 137, eff. 8-8-71; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.517) 
Sec. 25-138. - Permission of property owner required for operation. 
    No motorcycle or all terrain vehicle shall be operated on private property within the city or on property owned by the city or the public schools, unless designated for such use, except as the specific and express verbal permission of the owner of such private or governmental property has been first obtained for such operation. 
(Ord. No. 137, eff. 8-8-71; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.513) 
Sec. 25-139. - Operator's license, vehicle license required for operation in public places. 
    No motorcycle or all terrain vehicle shall be operated on public streets or places within the city by any person who does not then have in his possession a valid operator's or chauffeur's license issued by the state, nor shall such vehicle be operated on such public streets or places unless properly equipped and licensed as required by the state. 
(Ord. No. 137, eff. 8-8-71; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.512) 
Sec. 25-140. - Operation by unlicensed person. 
    No motorcycle or all terrain vehicle shall be operated on any private property by an unlicensed person without his parent's permission unless operated exclusively on private property owned by the parent or guardian of such operator. 
(Ord. No. 137, eff. 8-8-71; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.513) 
Sec. 25-141. - Operation on private property during certain hours prohibited. 
    No motorcycle or all terrain vehicle shall be operated on private property with or without the permission of the owner of such property between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(Ord. No. 137, eff. 8-8-71; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.515) 
Sec. 25-142. - Operation on sidewalks prohibited. 
    No motorcycle or all terrain vehicle shall be operated upon sidewalks at any time. 
(Ord. No. 137, eff. 8-8-71; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.515) 
Sec. 25-143. - Helmet required to operate or ride motorcycle. 
    No person shall operate or ride on a motorcycle in the city without wearing a protective helmet of a type approved by the state for such purpose. 
(Ord. No. 137, eff. 8-8-71; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.514) 
Sec. 25-144. - Noise levels. 
    The acceptable noise emission level of motorcycles and all terrain vehicles shall be governed by the standards established in chapter 13. 
(Ord. No. 137, eff. 8-8-71; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.516) 
Sec. 25-145. - Impoundment of vehicle operated in violation of article. 
    Any motorcycle or all terrain vehicle operated in violation of this article by any person not licensed by the state to operate such vehicle shall be impounded by the police department. Such vehicle will be released to the legal owner thereof upon request of such legal owner and upon payment of an impoundment and storage fee as prescribed by resolution of the city council. If such owner is a minor, his parent or guardian shall accompany him in requesting the release of the impounded vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 137, eff. 8-8-71; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.518) 
Sec. 25-146. - Motorcycles impounded three times. 
    If within any twelve-month period, a motorcycle has been impounded more than two (2) times under this article, such motorcycle shall not be released to the legal owner after being impounded for the third time until after sixty (60) days have elapsed from the date of the third such impoundment. 
    The provisions of this article shall not supersede or repeal any provisions of the "Uniform Traffic Code," included in this chapter as article II and previously adopted by the city which may be applicable to the operation of motorcycles and shall be in addition to such regulation. 
(Ord. No. 137, eff. 8-8-71; Comp. Ords. 1977, §§ 20.519, 20.521) 
Secs. 25-147-25-165. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SNOWPLOWING 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 25-166. - Compliance with article required. 
    No person shall operate or cause to be operated any highway-licensed motor vehicle or other equipment for the purpose of moving, removing or plowing snow or ice in the city except in the manner provided this article. 
(Ord. No. 124, eff. 11-23-67; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.091) 
Sec. 25-167. - Lights required. 
    In addition to any equipment required by the laws of the state, each highway-licensed motor vehicle used to plow snow shall be equipped with yellow overhead lights mounted in a position as to be visible to any approaching or following traffic or pedestrians. Such lights shall be turned on and be operating at all times during any time such vehicle is used for snowplowing. 
(Ord. No. 124, eff. 11-23-67; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.095) 
Sec. 25-168. - Leaving snow, ice on public property or other private property prohibited. 
    No snow or ice shall be removed from private property and deposited or left upon any public road or any public sidewalk nor shall snow or ice be plowed into or left upon the property, sidewalk, driveway or parkway of another person. 
(Ord. No. 124, eff. 11-23-67; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.096) 
Secs. 25-169-25-180. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Licensing generally, Ch. 12. (Back)
Sec. 25-181. - Required; exceptions. 
    No person shall operate or cause to be operated any highway-licensed motor vehicle or other equipment for the purpose of moving, removing or plowing snow or ice in the city without first having obtained a license for each highway-licensed motor vehicle so used; provided, however, that no license shall be required with respect to plowing or removing snow or ice from premises owned by or leased to the person operating such vehicle or if such work is done without compensation or remuneration. 
(Ord. No. 124, eff. 11-23-67; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.091) 
Sec. 25-182. - Application, fee. 
    Any person desiring a license required by this division shall file an application with the city clerk on a form approved by the city manger, which application shall contain the applicant's full name, address, telephone number and the number, make, model and license number of any vehicle which he proposes to operate for the purpose of moving or plowing snow or ice. An annual license fee shall be paid in the amount prescribed by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 124, eff. 11-23-67; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.092) 
Sec. 25-183. - Certificates of insurance required. 
    Each applicant for a license shall file along with the application certificates of insurance for public liability and property damage insuring both the applicant and the city in the minimum amounts as prescribed by resolution of the city council for damage caused by the operation of such highway licensed motor vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 124, eff. 11-23-67; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.093) 
Sec. 25-184. - License tag or decal. 
    For each vehicle for which a license fee has been paid a license tag or decal shall be issued by the city clerk. Such license tag or decal shall have a number which shall correspond to the number assigned to such vehicle by the city clerk. Such license tag or decal shall be affixed by the applicant to the rear window of the vehicle in a position so as to be readily seen. 
(Ord. No. 124, eff. 11-23-67; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 20.094) 
Secs. 25-185-25-188. - Reserved.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL

ARTICLE II. - WATER 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-26. - Charges made against premises; unpaid charges constitute lien; discontinuance of service for non-payment. 
(a)	All charges for water service pipe installation, repairs, damages caused by carelessness or neglect, or penalties, shall be made against the premises supplied, and the owner of the premises shall be held responsible therefore. Such charges, if not paid, shall constitute a lien on the property served and shall be added to the next municipal tax against the property. 
(b)	The city manager is hereby authorized to discontinue water service to the premises against which the above lien has accrued whenever any person shall fail to pay the charges referred to in this section or may institute suit for the collection of the same in any court of competent jurisdiction, but no attempts to collect such charges by any process shall in any way invalidate or waive the lien upon the premises. 
(c)	The city manager is hereby authorized and directed to make such rules and regulations as may be necessary for the management and control of the waterworks and water system which shall not be inconsistent with law. Such rules and regulations, when made, shall be approved by the city council by resolution and shall then have the effect and authority and shall be and become a part of this article and any violation of any such rules and regulations so made and approved shall be deemed a violation of this article. The current rules and regulations which have been approved by the city council are set forth in the remainder of article II of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 80, eff. 10-8-59; Comp. Ords. 1977, §§ 26.203, 26.204) 
Sec. 26-27. - Liability of city. 
    The city shall not be liable for any damages caused by the failure of a customer to receive water for any reason, including the shutting off of such supply by the city, nor shall the city be liable for any damage caused by any change in the pressure of water delivered to any customer. 
(Res. No. 1327, § IX, eff. 10-1-86) 
Sec. 26-28. - Acceptance of water deemed acceptance of rules. 
    Every person who shall be supplied or whose property shall be supplied with water by the department of public works of the city shall be deemed to have accepted and approved the rules of the city governing the regulating and supplying of water and the same shall constitute a part of the contract between such person and the city. Whenever the word "consumer" shall be used in the rules and regulations, it shall mean the owner of the premises. The continuance of the consumer to take water after any amendments or changes of these rules shall be deemed an acceptance of such amendment or change. 
(Res. No. 1327, § I, eff. 10-1-86) 
Sec. 26-29. - Authority of city manager to make additional regulations. 
    The city manager, subject to approval by the city council, may make and issue such additional rules and regulations concerning the city water system as may from time to time be necessary. 
(Comp. Ords. 1977, § 26.201; Res. No. 1327, § XII, eff. 10-1-86) 
Sec. 26-30. - Authority of city manager to regulate use of water. 
    The city manager may regulate, limit, or prohibit the use of water by any customer should certain circumstances seem to warrant such action. 
(Res. No. 1327, § IX, eff. 10-1-86) 
Sec. 26-31. - Service connections. 
(a)	All connections to the city water supply system shall be made by authorized city employees unless otherwise permitted in writing by the city manager. 
(b)	All service pipe on either public or private property shall be laid on solid ground not less than six (6) feet below the established grade immediately above the pipe. When water service is laid in the same trench with a sewer, it shall be at least eighteen (18) inches distant from the sewer horizontally. 
(c)	All service pipe from the property line to the meter shall be of copper and of a size and type approved by the city manager. The minimum size of any service shall be one (1) inch inside diameter. All service pipe from main to curb stop shall be copper including service pipe tail. 
(d)	The corporation, service pipe, curb stop, and stop box will be provided in place and maintained by the city after payment of the permit fee as established by resolution of the city council. 
(e)	The service pipe from the curb stop to the meter may be installed by the customer upon issuance of a permit by the city and payment of a fee as prescribed by resolution of the city council for each inspection required. Such service must be left open until inspected by the city. 
(f)	For services that do not have meter horn setters, the consumer shall provide two (2) gate valves, of approved type, on either side of the meter. 
(g)	No service of general supply shall be tapped from pipes intended for fire protection only. 
(Res. No. 1327, § IV, eff. 10-1-86) 
Sec. 26-32. - Condemnation of services. 
    If service from the street to the meter is found to be deteriorated, leaking, or if a cross-connection exists in the service between the water supply of the city and any other water supply, the city manager may condemn or discontinue such service and require that the same be repaired or replaced as directed by the city. The replacements or repairs shall be done at the expense of the consumer. 
(Res. No. 1327, § X, eff. 10-1-86) 
Sec. 26-33. - Turning on water service. 
    No person other than an authorized employee of the department of public works shall turn on or off any water service without the written permission of the city. 
(Res. No. 1327, § VII, eff. 10-1-86) 
Sec. 26-34. - Unauthorized tampering with equipment; reimbursement to city for damage. 
    No person, except an employee of the city in the performance of his duties, shall uncover or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or equipment which is a part of the city water distribution system. Any person responsible for any injury to any main, pipe, hydrant, or other water facility, shall reimburse the city therefor and for the loss of water caused thereby and shall be responsible for any damage caused by escaping water. 
(Res. No. 1327, § XI, eff. 10-1-86) 
Sec. 26-35. - Application for water. 
    Any person desiring to obtain water from the city shall make application upon proper forms to be furnished by the city and pay the prescribed fees. Applications made by any person other than the owner of the premises shall be deemed to be the agent of the owner and to have made such application with the consent of the owner. Any special agreements or conditions relative to water shall be in writing and signed by the city manager and the consumer. 
(Res. No. 1327, § II, eff. 10-1-86) 
Sec. 26-36. - Meters. 
(a)	Purchase, installation, cost. All meters will be purchased from the city and installed by city personnel. Cost of the meter will include meter, horn and valve from five-eighths inch through one (1) inch as prescribed by resolution of the city council. 
(b)	Size. Meters for ordinary domestic service shall be of five-eighths inch by three-fourths inch. Where application for a larger service is made, determination as to size shall be made by the city manager. Larger sizes may be required for commercial or multiple dwelling use. Larger meters will be ordered and the city's current cost will be assessed. Meters of one and one-half (11/2) inches or larger will not include valves. Installation of meters of larger size shall be subject to special agreement with the approval of the city council. 
(c)	Location. Meters shall be set in an accessible location and in a manner approved by the city manager. Where due to unusual circumstances it is necessary to place the meter in a pit, such pit shall be built at the expense of the owner as directed by the city manager. 
(d)	Access. The city shall have the right to shut off the water supply to any customer where access is not available to the meter. Qualified employees of the city shall at all reasonable hours have the right to enter the premises where such meters are installed, for the purpose of reading, testing, removing or inspecting same and no person shall hinder, obstruct, or interfere with any such employee in the discharge of his duties. 
(e)	Damage. Any damage to a meter resulting from carelessness or neglect of an owner, agent, or tenant to properly secure and protect the meter, as well as damage by frost, hot water, or steam, shall be paid for by the customer upon presentation of the bill therefor. The same shall be collected in the same manner as any service charge. 
(f)	Failure to register. If any meter shall fail to register properly, the city shall estimate the consumption and bill accordingly. 
(g)	Inaccurate meters. A customer may require that a meter be tested upon depositing with the city treasurer a fee as prescribed by resolution of the city council. If the meter is found to register more than two (2) percent fast, the deposit shall be returned. 
(h)	Bill adjustments. When the city, on its own initiative, tests a water meter and finds same to register five (5) percent or more slow, the city may estimate such consumption loss and bill accordingly. 
(Res. No. 1327, §§ III, VI, eff. 10-1-86) 
Sec. 26-37. - Rates for tapping. 
    The city will make water service available at the lot line, or up to and including the service box, as established elsewhere in this article, at the rates as prescribed by resolution of the city council. 
(Res. No. 1327, § III, eff. 10-1-86) 
Sec. 26-38. - Hookup fees. 
(a)	Generally. In addition to the rates and charges mentioned elsewhere in this article, there shall be paid, before connection to the city's water system is permitted, a regular connection charge as prescribed by resolution of the city council for each connection made. 
(b)	Parcels larger than minimum residential lot. In the case of connections where the parcel of land to be served is larger than the minimum residential building lot as required in an A-80 Residential District under the provisions of the zoning ordinance, a connection charge of three (3) times the normal connection charge shall be paid for each acre served or pro rata for a fraction thereof. 
(c)	Churches. In the case of churches, the connection charge shall be based on the regular seating capacity which the principal sanctuary was designed to accommodate at the rate of one (1) regular connection charge for each one hundred (100) seats and proportionately for any fraction thereof, with additional charges at the same rate for any subsequent expansion of such seating capacity. 
(d)	Schools. In the case of school buildings, public and private, the connection charge shall be the following proportion of the regular connection charge: 
(1)	A building with a pool and facilities for serving hot lunches, seventy-five hundredths (.75) of the normal charge per classroom; 
(2)	A building without pool or facilities for serving hot lunches, four-tenths (.4) of the normal charge per classroom. 
(e)	Apartments, motels, mobile home parks. Apartments, motels, and mobile home trailer parks will be computed on the following rate schedule: 
(1)	First two (2) units at one hundred (100) percent of the single residential fee;
(2)	Next four (4) units at eighty (80) percent of the single residential fee;
(3)	All over six (6) units at sixty (60) percent of the single residential fee.
For apartments and motels, each building shall be computed separately. 
(Res. No. 1327, § III, eff. 10-1-86) 
Sec. 26-39. - Rates for water service. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article, water furnished to each consumer shall be measured by a meter installed and controlled by the city. Charges for water service to each consumer within the city shall be as prescribed by resolution of the city council. 
(Res. No. 1327, § III, eff. 10-1-86) 
Sec. 26-40. - Fire protection rates. 
    Automatic sprinkler services or hose connections for fire protection purposes only shall be at the rates as prescribed by resolution of the city council. Billing for fire protection shall be made quarterly for future benefits. High and low pressure services, when installed, shall constitute separate services and a charge shall be made for each. 
(Res. No. 1327, § III, eff. 10-1-86) 
Sec. 26-41. - Unmetered water. 
    Water may be delivered to unmetered consumers with the written approval of the city manager and upon payment of a fee as prescribed by resolution of the city council, and as shall be agreed to in writing. 
(Res. No. 1327, § III, eff. 10-1-86) 
Sec. 26-42. - Water used during construction. 
    Water used will be metered during construction and billed to the responsible party. A construction reading will be taken prior to occupancy and billed at the prevailing rate. 
(Res. No. 1327, § III, eff. 10-1-86) 
Sec. 26-43. - Use of hydrants. 
    No person except an employee of the city in the performance of his duties shall open or use any fire hydrant except in the case of emergency, without first securing written permission from the city, and paying such charges as may be made. 
(Res. No. 1327, § VIII, eff. 10-1-86) 
Sec. 26-44. - Billing. 
    All bills for water consumed or services rendered shall be sent by mail unless other arrangements are made with the city treasurer. Failure to receive a bill shall not affect in any way the terms or conditions of the billing. 
(Res. No. 1327, § III, eff. 10-1-86) 
Sec. 26-45. - Delinquencies. 
    The due date for billings shall be the twentieth day of the month after the billing thereof. If the twentieth day is a Saturday, Sunday or holiday, the due date shall be the next regular business day succeeding such Saturday, Sunday or holiday. An additional charge of ten (10) percent shall be added to the billing for the preceding quarter upon becoming delinquent. Delinquency date shall be at 12:00 noon the next regular business day following the due date. 
(Res. No. 1327, § III, eff. 10-1-86) 
Sec. 26-46. - Discontinuance of service. 
    If within thirty (30) days after the due date, the total billing for water or service has not been paid or satisfactory arrangements made with the city treasurer for such payment, then the city may discontinue service. No service which has been so discontinued shall be restored until such delinquency is fully paid or satisfactory arrangements made with the city treasurer. For each such discontinuance, a service fee as prescribed by resolution of the city council shall be added to the delinquent bill and collected before service is restored. 
(Res. No. 1327, § V, eff. 10-1-86) 
Secs. 26-47-26-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CROSS-CONNECTION CONTROL 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 258, § I, effective July 11, 2003, repealed the former Div. 2, §§ 26-61-26-70, and enacted a new Div. 2 as set out herein. The former Div. 2 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 148, effective Jan. 2, 1975; Comp. Ords. 1977, § 26.701-26.710. 
Sec. 26-61. - Definitions. 
    Backflow means water of questionable quality, wastes, or other contaminants entering a public water supply system due to a reversal of flow. 
    Cross connection means a connection or arrangement of piping or appurtenances through which backflow could occur. 
    Department means the City of Grandville. 
    Public water supply system means a water system operated by a municipality which furnishes water to the public for household or drinking purposes. 
    Safe air gap means the minimum distance a water inlet or opening is located above the maximum high water level or overflow rim in a fixture, device, or container to which public water is furnished which shall be at least two (2) times the inside diameter of the water inlet pipe, but shall not be less than one (1) inch and not more than twelve (12) inches. 
    Secondary water supply means any water supply that is not a public water supply and including but not limited to a water supply from ground or surface sources not meeting the requirements of Act 399 of Public Acts of 1976 (Michigan Safe Drinking Water Act), as amended, being sections 325.1001 to 325.1023 of the Michigan Compiled Laws, or water from a public water supply system which in any way has been treated, processed or exposed to any possible contaminant or stored in an other-than-approved storage facility or a private water storage tank supplied from a public water supply system unless it is designed and approved for potable water usage. Any and all private water storage tanks supplied from a public water supply system are included and must meet guidelines for approved potable water usage. 
    Submerged inlet means a water pipe or extension thereto from a public water supply system terminating in a tank, vessel, fixture or appliance which may contain water of questionable quality, wastewater, or other contaminant and which is unprotected against backflow. 
    Water utility means a governmental unit, municipal or private corporation, association, partnership, or individual engaged in furnishing water to the public for household or drinking purposes. 
(Ord. No. 258, § I, eff. 7-11-2003) 
Sec. 26-62. - Compliance with existing law. 
    A connection with a public water supply system shall comply with existing laws, ordinances, codes and rules, including: 
(1)	Act 260 of the Public Acts of 1929, as amended, being sections 338.901 to 338.917 of the Michigan Compiled Laws (State of Michigan Code). 
(2)	The Grandville Code of Ordinances including this division and all other sections of the Code of Ordinances pertaining to plumbing, water supply and sewage disposal. 
(3)	Act 399 of the Public Acts of 1976, as amended, and the Administrative Rules, Michigan Safe Drinking Water Act, which are hereby adopted by reference. 
(4)	The Cross Connection Rules Manual of the Michigan Department of Environmental Quality, Drinking Water and Radiological Protection Division, being sections 8325.11401 to 8325.11407 of the state administrative code, which are hereby adopted by reference. 
(5)	The latest edition of the Michigan Plumbing Code and the latest edition of the Michigan Residential Code, which are hereby adopted by reference. 
(6)	The City of Grandville Cross Connection Control Program, dated August 2001, as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 258, § I, eff. 7-11-2003) 
Sec. 26-63. - Cross connection prohibited. 
    A cross connection to a public water supply system is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 258, § I, eff. 7-11-2003) 
Sec. 26-64. - Inspection program and access to premises. 
    The department shall develop a program for the elimination and prevention of cross connections. As part of this program, the department or its designated agent shall cause inspections and re-inspections to be made for cross connections to the public water supply system. The frequency of inspections and re-inspections shall be based on potential health hazards, as determined by the department or its designated agent, to the public water supply system through possible cross connections. A duly authorized representative of the city shall be granted access to the consumer's premises at all reasonable hours to determine the presence of an existing cross connection. On request, the owner or occupant shall furnish the city any pertinent information regarding the piping system of the premises. The refusal to supply such information or refusal to grant access, when requested, shall be prima facie evidence of the presence of a cross connection and deemed a violation of this division. 
(Ord. No. 258, § I, eff. 7-11-2003) 
Sec. 26-65. - Discontinuance of service. 
    The city is authorized to disconnect water service to the consumer, after reasonable notice, for violation of any of the rules and regulations of the department or the provisions of this division applicable to cross connections and to take such other precautionary measures deemed necessary to eliminate any danger of contamination of the public water supply system from cross connections or otherwise. Water service shall not be restored until the cross connection has been eliminated in accordance with the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 258, § I, eff. 7-11-2003) 
Sec. 26-66. - Protective devices. 
    A consumer shall obtain written approval from the city of any proposed backflow prevention corrective action or protective device before use or installation. All testable backflow prevention devices shall be tested upon installation and at specified periodic intervals thereafter. The department may require the filing of a backflow device test report, on a periodic basis or frequency established by the department, for any backflow prevention devices used by a consumer. All testing and maintenance of consumer's backflow prevention devices shall be at the consumer's own expense and be performed by a person approved by the city. The individual testing the device shall certify that the results or his or her testing are accurate. Such certification may be required to be part of the backflow prevention device test reports which may also be required to be filed with the city. The city shall review backflow device test reports filed with the city. 
(Ord. No. 258, § I, eff. 7-11-2003) 
Sec. 26-67. - Cross connection program fees. 
    The city may by resolution establish fees to be charged to consumers that are reasonably related to the services provided to the consumer by the city in the operation of the program for the elimination and prevention of cross connections. Any such fees may be added to, and for the purposes of discontinuance of service, shall be considered part of a consumer's water bill. 
(Ord. No. 258, § I, eff. 7-11-2003) 
Sec. 26-68. - Cross connection program violations. 
    Any person or consumer found to be in noncompliance or in violation of any of the provisions of this division or any written order of the city after the compliance date given shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. Each day upon which a violation of the provisions of this division shall occur shall be deemed a separate and additional violation for the purpose of this division. 
(Ord. No. 258, § I, eff. 7-11-2003) 
Sec. 26-69. - Protection of potable water and warning requirements. 
    Any water outlet which could be used for potable or domestic purposes and which is not supplied by a public water supply system must be labeled in a conspicuous manner as "water unsafe for drinking." 
(Ord. No. 258, § I, eff. 7-11-2003) 
Sec. 26-70. - Piping identification. 
    When a secondary water source is used in addition to a public water supply system, exposed public water supply piping shall be identified by a blue color or tags and all other exposed piping shall be distinguished from the public water supply piping by a different contrasting color or tags and so maintained that the public water supply piping and secondary water supply piping can be traced readily in their entirety. If such piping is so installed that it is impossible to trace it in its entirety, it will be necessary to protect the public water supply system at the service connection in a manner acceptable to the Michigan Department of Environmental Quality and the City of Grandville. 
(Ord. No. 258, § I, eff. 7-11-2003) 
Secs. 26-71-26-85. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SEWERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 26-86-26-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SEWER USE REGULATIONS 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 280, § 1, Feb. 19, 2010, repealed the former Art. III, Div. 2, §§ 26-101-26-109. Section 2 of said ordinance enacted a new Div. 2 as set out herein. The former Div. 2 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 191, § 2, effective December 31, 1992. 
Sec. 26-101. - Purpose and scope. 
(a)	Purpose, policy and objectives. This division is intended to accomplish the following primary purposes, policies and objectives: 
(1)	To establish standards, rules, and regulations with respect to the use of public and private sewers and drains, private sewage disposal, and use of the POTW. 
(2)	To prevent the discharge of pollutants into the POTW which do not meet applicable pretreatment standards and requirements; which would interfere with the operation of the POTW; which would pass through the POTW; which would inhibit or disrupt the POTW's processing, use or disposal of sludge; or which would result in a violation of the city's NPDES permit or of other applicable laws and regulations. 
(3)	To regulate the discharge of wastewater to the POTW by issuing orders of determination and through other means of enforcing the requirements of this division. 
(4)	To authorize and require all inspection, monitoring, reporting and enforcement activities as necessary to insure compliance with applicable pretreatment standards and requirements and other applicable laws and regulations. 
(5)	To provide for a system of charges for connection to and use of the POTW which equitably distributes the costs of the POTW system. 
(b)	Scope. This division shall apply to any person owning, using, constructing or maintaining any private system or facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage or wastewater within the city. This division shall also apply to persons within the city and to persons outside the city who, by contract or agreement with the city, discharge into the POTW. Any other municipality that discharges into the POTW shall, as a condition to discharge, adopt an ordinance that is at least as restrictive as this division and is approved by the city. 
(Ord. No. 280, § 2, eff. 2-19-2010) 
Sec. 26-102. - Definitions. 
    Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms and abbreviations used in this division shall be as follows: 
    Accidental discharge means any discharge that could result in potential problems at the POTW treatment plant and includes, without limitation, the following: (1) an upset in operation which places the industrial user in a temporary state of noncompliance; (2) a chemical spill to floor drains or which will otherwise enter the wastewater treatment system; or (3) a discharge including slug loading that could cause treatment system problems. 
    BOD (Biochemical oxygen demand) means the quantity of oxidation of organic matter in five (5) days at twenty (20) degrees Centigrade, expressed in milligrams per liter. 
    Building drain means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge inside the walls of a building and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five (5) feet outside of the inner face of the building wall. 
    Building sewer means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal. 
    Bypass means the intentional diversion of waste streams from any portion of an industrial user's pretreatment facility. 
    CFR means the Code of Federal Regulations, as amended. 
    COD (Chemical oxygen demand) means the total quantity of oxygen required for oxidation of a waste to carbon dioxide and water, expressed in milligrams per liter. It does not differentiate between stable and unstable organic matter and thus does not necessarily correlate with BOD. COD is also known as OC (oxygen consumed) and DOC (dichromate oxygen consumed). 
    Categorical pretreatment standards means a national pretreatment standard promulgated by the U.S. EPA in accordance with Sections 307(b) and (c) of the FWPCA which specifies quantities or concentrations of pollutants or pollutant properties which may be discharged to a POTW by industrial users in specific industrial subcategories. 
    Chlorine demand means the difference between the amount of chlorine added to water or wastewater and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specified contact period, expressed in milligrams per liter. The demand for any given water varies with the amount of chlorine applied, time of contact and temperature. 
    City means the City of Grandville or an authorized representative. 
    City manager means the city manager of the City of Grandville or an authorized representative. 
    Combined sewer means a sewer receiving both surface run-off and sewage. 
    Combined waste stream means the waste stream at industrial facilities where regulated process effluent is mixed with other wastewaters, either regulated or unregulated, prior to pretreatment. 
    Compatible pollutant means biochemical oxygen demand, suspended solids, pH and fecal coliform bacteria, and any additional pollutants identified in the POTW's NPDES permit, if the POTW treatment plant is designed to treat the pollutants and is generally able to remove eighty (80) percent or more of the pollutants. 
    Composite sample means a collection of individual samples taken over regular intervals, collected on a flow-proportional or time-proportional basis, over a specific time period and which provides a representative sample of the average stream during the sampling period. Cooling water means the water discharged from any use such as air conditioning, cooling or refrigeration, to which the only pollutant added is heat. 
    Control authority enforcement response plan or "CAER plan" means the plan prepared by the city as required by 40 CFR 403.8(f)(5) which describes how the POTW will investigate and respond to instances of noncompliance and the types of escalated enforcement actions the POTW will take in response to violations of applicable standards and requirements. 
    Daily average means the sum of the concentrations (or mass loadings, expressed in terms of pounds per day) of a constituent for the measurement period divided by the number of days in the measurement period. The concentrations (or loadings) which are added are single numbers for single days for all days for which analyses are obtained, but such concentrations (or loadings) may be based upon a sample or samples taken over either all or part of that day and upon single or multiple analyses for that day as determined by the city. Sampling for daily average shall be twenty-four-hour flow proportioned composite samples, except that a minimum of four (4) grab samples shall be taken in lieu of a twenty-four-hour flow proportioned composite sample for a single day for pH, cyanide, total phenols, oil and grease, sulfide, and volatile organic compounds. If it is not feasible to obtain a flow proportioned composite sample, a time proportioned composite sample or a minimum of four (4) grab samples may be used in lieu of the flow proportioned composite sample if the user demonstrates to the city that representative samples will be obtained. 
    Daily maximum means the concentration (or mass loading, expressed in terms of pounds per day) which shall not be exceeded on any single calendar day. Sampling for daily maximum shall be a twenty-four-hour flow proportioned composite sample except that a minimum of four (4) grab samples shall be taken in lieu of a twenty-four-hour flow proportioned composite sample for pH, cyanide, total phenols, oil and grease, sulfide, and volatile organic compounds. If it is not feasible to obtain a flow proportioned composite sample, a time proportioned composite sample or a minimum of four (4) grab samples may be used in lieu of the flow proportioned composite sample if the user demonstrates to the city that a representative sample will be obtained. 
    Debt service charges are the charges levied to users of the wastewater system which are used to pay principal, interest and administrative costs of retiring the debt incurred for construction of the sewage works. 
    Discharge means the introduction of wastewater or pollutants into the POTW, whether intentional or unintentional, and whether direct or indirect. 
    Domestic user means a user that discharges only segregated domestic wastes or wastes from sanitary conveniences into the POTW. 
    EPA or U.S. EPA means the United States Environmental Protection Agency. 
    FWPCA means the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (also known as the Clean Water Act) as amended, 33 U.S.C. 1251, et seq. 
    Garbage means solid wastes from the preparation, cooking, and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage, and sale of produce. 
    Grab sample is a sample which is taken from a waste stream on a one-time basis over a period of time of not more than fifteen (15) minutes without regard to the flow in the waste stream. 
    Grease trap means a device designed to separate and retain fats, oils, and grease from liquid waste and permit the liquid waste to discharge into the sewer system. 
    Hazardous waste means any substance discharged or proposed to be discharged into the POTW, which, if otherwise disposed of, would be a hazardous waste under 40 CFR part 261 or under the rules promulgated under Part 111 of the Michigan Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act (NREPA). 
    Incompatible pollutant means any pollutant that is not a compatible pollutant. 
    Industrial wastes means the wastewater discharges from industrial, manufacturing, trade or business processes, or wastewater discharge from any structure or premises with those characteristics, as distinct from segregated domestic wastes or wastes from sanitary conveniences. 
    Interference means a discharge which, alone or in conjunction with a discharge or discharges from other sources, both: (1) inhibits or disrupts the POTW, its treatment processes or operations, or its sludge processes, use or disposal; and (2) therefore is a cause of a violation of any requirement of the POTW's NPDES permit (including an increase in the magnitude or duration of a violation) or of the prevention of sewage sludge use or disposal in compliance with the following statutory provisions and regulations or permits issued thereunder (or more stringent state or local regulations): Section 405 of the FWPCA; the Solid Waste Disposal Act (SWDA) (including Title II, more commonly referred to as RCRA, and including state regulations contained in any state sludge management plan prepared pursuant to Subtitle D of the SWDA); the Clean Air Act; the Toxic Substances Control Act; and the Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act. 
    mg/l means milligrams per liter. 
    Natural outlet means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface water or ground water. 
    New source means any building, structure, facility or installation from which there is or may be a discharge of pollutants, the construction of which commenced after the publication of proposed pretreatment standards under Section 307(c) of the FWPCA which will be applicable to such source if such standards are thereafter promulgated in accordance with that section, provided that: 
(1)	The building, structure, facility or installation is constructed at a site at which no other source is located; or 
(2)	The building, structure, facility or installation totally replaces the process or production equipment that causes the discharge of pollutants at an existing source; or 
(3)	The production or wastewater-generating processes of the building, structure, facility or installation are substantially independent of an existing source at the same site. In determining whether these are substantially independent, factors such as the extent to which the new facility is integrated with the existing plant, and the extent to which the new facility is engaged in the same general type of activity as the existing source should be considered. 
    Construction on a site at which an existing source is located results in a modification rather than a new source if the construction does not create a new building, structure, facility or installation meeting the criteria of paragraphs (2) or (3) of this section but otherwise alters, replaces, or adds to existing process or production equipment. Commencement of construction of a new source shall be determined in a manner consistent with 40 CFR 403.3(k)(3) and MAC 323.2311(4). 
    Nondomestic user means any user other than a domestic user. 
    NPDES permit means a permit issued pursuant to the National Pollution Discharge Elimination System of the FWPCA for the discharge of wastewater into the waters of the state. 
    Operation and maintenance (O&M) means all work, materials, equipment, utilities (and associated costs, direct and indirect, including replacement costs), necessary to ensure adequate wastewater treatment on a continuing basis, conform with all related federal, state, and local requirements, and assure optimal long-term facility management. Operation and maintenance costs do not include expenditures required to retire debts resulting from capital costs of construction. 
    Order of determination means a written order issued by the city as provided by this division to control the discharge of wastewater to the POTW (including the establishment of allowable discharge characteristics or requirements and the relative strength of discharge for individual users), and to ensure compliance with applicable pretreatment standards and requirements. 
    Pass-through means a discharge which exits the POTW into waters of the state in quantities or concentrations which, alone or in conjunction with a discharge or discharges from other sources, is a cause of a violation of any requirement of the POTW's NPDES permit (including an increase in the magnitude or duration of a violation). 
    Person means any individual, firm, company, association, society, corporation, unit of local government, government agency, or group. 
    pH means the logarithm of the reciprocal of the concentration of hydrogen ions in grams per liter of solution. 
    Pollutant means any material which is discharged to the POTW or is proposed for discharge to the POTW, including, without limitation, any of the various chemicals, substances, and refuse materials such as solid waste, sewage, garbage, sewage sludge, chemical wastes, biological materials, radioactive materials, and industrial, municipal, domestic and agricultural wastes which impair the purity of the water or soil, or which impair the operations of or adversely affect worker health and safety at the POTW. The term "pollutant" also includes properties of materials, including, but not limited to, pH and heat. 
    POTW (publicly owned treatment works) means the treatment works, as defined by applicable provisions of the CFR and the FWPCA, that is owned by the city, including any devices, processes and systems used in the storage, treatment, recycling or reclamation of wastewater, sewage or sludge, as well as sewers, pipes and other conveyances used to collect or convey wastewater or sewage to the treatment works. The term "POTW" shall also include any sewers that convey wastewaters to the city's POTW from persons outside the city who are, by contract or agreement with the city, users of the city's POTW. The term "POTW" may also be used in this division to refer to the city or its authorized representatives. 
    POTW treatment plant means that portion of the POTW which is designed to provide treatment (including recycling or reclamation) of sewage and industrial waste. 
    Premises means a lot or parcel of land, or a building or structure, having any connection, direct or indirect, to the POTW, or from which there is a discharge to the POTW. 
    Pretreatment means the reduction of the amount of pollutants, the elimination of pollutants, or the alteration of the nature of pollutant properties in wastewater prior to or instead of discharging or otherwise introducing the pollutants into the POTW. The reduction or alteration can be obtained by physical, chemical, or biological processes, process changes, or by other means, except as prohibited by 40 CFR 403.6(d) and (e). 
    Pretreatment facility means devices or structures for use in providing pretreatment for industrial waste prior to entry into public sewers. 
    Pretreatment requirement means any substantive or procedural requirement related to pretreatment, other than a national pretreatment standard, imposed on an industrial user. 
    Pretreatment standard means any regulation containing pollutant discharge limits promulgated in accordance with Section 307(b) and (c) of the FWPCA and Part 31 of NREPA, and which applies to industrial users, including prohibited discharges and local limits established under 40 CFR 403.5, MAC 323.2303, or categorical standards. 
    Private sewage works means any sewage works or part thereof not connected to a public sewer and includes, without limitation, any septic tank, cesspool, seepage pit, privy, privy vault or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage or wastewater. 
    Public sewer means a sewer which is owned and controlled by a public authority. Public sewer means the main sewer line exclusive of sewer leads. Sewer leads shall be considered to be part of the "building sewer." 
    RCRA means the federal Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, 42 U.S.C. 6901 et seq. as amended. 
    Replacement means the replacement in whole or in part of any equipment in the POTW to ensure continuous treatment of wastewater in accordance with the POTW's NPDES permit and other applicable laws and regulations. Replacement costs include necessary expenditures made during the service life of the POTW to replace equipment and plant appurtenances required to maintain the intended performance of the POTW. 
    Sanitary sewer means a sewer which carries sewage and to which stormwater, surface water, and groundwater are not intentionally admitted. 
    Severe property damage means substantial physical damage to property, damage to the treatment facilities which causes them to become inoperable, or substantial and permanent loss of natural resources which can reasonably be expected to occur in the absence of a bypass. Severe property damage does not mean economic loss caused by delays in production. 
    Sewage means a combination of the water carried wastes, whether treated or untreated, from residences, business buildings, institutions, and industrial establishments, together with such groundwater, surface water, and stormwater as may be present. 
    Sewage treatment plant means the POTW treatment plant. 
    Sewage works means the POTW. 
    Sewer means a pipe or conduit for carrying sewage. 
    Sewer service charge means the sum of any applicable user charges, surcharges and debt service charges. 
    Significant industrial user means (1) any industrial user subject to categorical pretreatment standards; or (2) any other industrial user to which one of the following applies: (a) discharges to the POTW an average of twenty-five thousand (25,000) gallons per day or more of process wastewater (excluding sanitary, noncontact cooling and boiler blow-down wastewater), (b) contributes a process waste stream which makes up five (5) percent or more of the average dry weather hydraulic or organic capacity of the POTW treatment plant, or (c) is designated by the city as a significant industrial user on the basis that the industrial user has a reasonable potential to adversely affect the operation of the POTW or to violate any pretreatment standard or requirement. The city may determine that a user which meets the criteria of this section is not a significant industrial user if the city finds that the user has no reasonable potential to adversely affect the operation of the POTW or to violate any pretreatment standard or requirement. 
    Significant noncompliance means a violation (or group of violations) of applicable pretreatment standards or requirements or any other action (or failure to act) by an industrial user which meets the criteria set forth in section 26-108(h), or which will otherwise adversely affect the operation or implementation of the city's pretreatment program as determined by the superintendent. 
    Slug loading means (1) any discharge of water, sewage or industrial waste which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds more than five (5) times the average twenty-four-hour concentration or quantity of flow during normal operation, for any period longer than fifteen (15) minutes; or (2) any pollutant released in a discharge at a flow rate and/or pollutant concentration which will cause interference with the POTW; or (3) any discharge of a nonroutine, episodic nature, including, but not limited to, an accidental spill or a noncustomary batch discharge. 
    Storm drain (or "storm sewer") means a sewer which is intended to carry only stormwater, surface runoff, and drainage water which is not wastewater. Stormwater means any flow occurring during or following any form of natural precipitation and resulting therefrom. 
    Superintendent means the superintendent of the city's wastewater treatment plant or a duly authorized representative. 
    Surcharge means an extra charge to reimburse the city for any costs, direct or indirect, incurred by the city, or imposed upon the city, in handling or treating a discharge which exceeds the applicable discharge limitations. 
    Suspended solids (SS) means solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in, water, sewage, or other liquids, and which are removable by laboratory filtering. 
    Toxic pollutant means any pollutant or combination of pollutants which is or can potentially be harmful to public health or environment, including those listed as toxic in regulations promulgated by the administrator of the U.S. EPA under the provisions of Section 307(a) of the FWPCA. 
    25% rule means the combined depth of oil and grease and other solids (floating and settled) in any chamber of a trap shall not be equal to or greater than twenty-five (25) percent of the total operating depth of the trap. The operating depth of a trap is determined by measuring the internal depth from the water outlet invert elevation to the inside bottom of the trap. 
    Upset means an exceptional incident in which there is unintentional and temporary noncompliance with categorical pretreatment standards because of factors beyond the reasonable control of the industrial user. An upset does not include noncompliance to the extent caused by operational error, improperly designed pretreatment facilities, inadequate pretreatment facilities, lack of preventive maintenance, or careless or improper operation. 
    User means any person who discharges, or who causes or permits a discharge, into the POTW, or any municipality whose collection system discharges into the POTW. 
    User charge means the charge levied on all users of the POTW for the cost of operation and maintenance of the treatment works, including the cost of replacement. 
    User class means the kind of user connected to the POTW, as determined by the superintendent, including, without limitation, the following: 
(1)	Commercial user means an establishment involved in a commercial enterprise, business or service which discharges primarily segregated domestic wastes or wastes from sanitary conveniences, and which is not a residential user or an industrial user. 
(2)	Governmental user means any federal, state or local government user. 
(3)	Industrial user means any user who discharges industrial (nondomestic) waste. 
(4)	Institutional user means any establishment involved in a social, charitable, religious, or educational function which discharges primarily segregated domestic wastes or wastes from sanitary conveniences. 
(5)	Residential user means a user of the POTW whose premises or buildings are used primarily as a domicile for one (1) or more persons, including dwelling units such as detached, semi-detached and row houses; mobile homes, apartments, and permanent multi-family dwellings; but not including transit lodging which is considered a commercial use. 
    Wastewater means water or sewage discharged to the POTW by a user. 
    Watercourse means a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
    Waters of the state means all streams, lakes, ponds, marshes, watercourses, waterways, wells, springs, reservoirs, aquifers, irrigation systems, drainage systems and all other bodies or accumulation of water, surface or underground, natural or artificial, public or private, which are contained within, flow through, or border upon the state or any portion thereof. 
(Ord. No. 280, § 2, eff. 2-19-2010) 
Sec. 26-103. - Private disposal and treatment of wastewater; use of public sewer required if available. 
(a)	Purpose. This section provides the requirements applicable to the private disposal of sewage and wastewater within the city, including the installation and operation of private sewage disposal and treatment facilities, and the connection of building sewers to the public sewers. 
(b)	Depositing wastes upon public or private property prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit, or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner upon public or private property within the city any garbage, sewage pollutant, industrial waste or other objectionable waste. 
(c)	Discharge of sewage and wastewater prohibited without required approvals or permits. Except as otherwise expressly permitted by this division or by other applicable laws or regulations, and subject to obtaining any required approvals from any interested governmental agencies (including, without limitation, the city, the county drain commissioner, the state water resources commission, and the U.S. EPA), it shall be unlawful to discharge, or permit or cause to be discharged, either directly or indirectly: 
(1)	Polluted sewage or wastewater to any natural outlet within the city, to any waters of the state, or to any public sewer. 
(2)	Unpolluted water of any kind, including without limitation, stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, drainage water (surface or subsurface), industrial noncontact cooling water, air-conditioning water, or industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer. Such unpolluted water may be discharged only to a sewer that is specifically designated as a combined sewer or storm sewer or to a natural outlet, and only if all applicable approvals and permits have been first been obtained from all interested governmental agencies. 
(d)	Regulation of private sewage disposal systems. Except as provided by this division, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain within the city any private sewage works or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage or wastewater. 
(e)	Private system required if public sewer not available. If a public sanitary or combined sewer is not available as provided by section 26-103(e), the building sewer shall be connected to a private sewage disposal system as provided by this section: 
(1)	The private system shall be constructed at the owner's expense in accordance with all applicable city, county and state laws, regulations and standards, and shall be approved by the city manager. 
(2)	All sewage disposal facilities, such as flush toilets, urinals, lavatories, sinks, bathtubs, showers, or any similar fixtures used to receive or conduct water-carried wastes, shall be connected to the private sewage works in the manner required by all applicable city, county and state laws, regulations and standards, and shall be approved by the city manager. 
(3)	A permit signed by the city manager shall be required for all installations, construction of or alteration to private sewage works. Application for a permit shall be in writing and shall be signed by the applicant. The application shall include the name and address of the applicant, the description of the property on which the construction, alteration, or extension is proposed and a complete plan of the proposed disposal system with any additional information or data as required by the city manager. An application fee in an amount established by resolution of the city council shall accompany each application. If the proposed construction meets the requirements of this division, a permit shall be issued to the applicant. 
(4)	The city manager shall inspect each sewer, septic tank, disposal field, or other underground appurtenance, before the appurtenance is covered. It shall be the duty of the permit holder to request the inspection. The inspection shall be made by the city manager within forty-eight (48) hours of receipt of the request by the city manager, excluding Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays. 
(5)	The city manager may condemn any existing private sewage works if the effluent from the sewage works is exposed to the surface of the ground or is permitted to drain on or to the surface of the ground or into any waters of the state; or if the seepage of effluent from the sewage works may endanger a public or private water supply; or if a public or private nuisance is created by a system improperly constructed or maintained. 
(6)	The provision of this section shall not apply if the physical size or shape of the premises make their application impossible, as determined by the city manager. If the provision of this section are determined to be inapplicable, the owners of the premises may construct or cause to be constructed private sewage works upon the premises under the direction of and as approved by the city manager. In granting variances from or modifications of the standards or requirements of this section, the city manager may impose any condition as determined necessary by the city manager to substantially secure the purposes and objectives of the standards or requirements varied or modified. 
(7)	No private sewage works shall be permitted to discharge to any public sewer or natural outlet. 
(8)	The owner shall operate and maintain the private sewage works in full compliance with all applicable laws and regulations and in a sanitary manner at all times, and at no expense to the city. 
(9)	When a public sewer becomes available to any property served by private sewage works as provided by section 26-103(e), the building sewer shall be directly connected to the public sewer as required by this division, and any septic tanks, cesspools and similar private sewage works shall be abandoned, emptied of wastes, and filled with suitable material. 
(f)	Connection to public sewer required if available. Connection to a public sewer shall be required as provided by this section: 
(1)	The owner of any house, building, or property used for human occupancy, employment, recreation, or other purpose situated within the city and abutting on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is located a public sanitary sewer, is hereby required, at the owner's expense, to install suitable toilet facilities therein and to connect the facilities directly with the public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this division, provided that the public sewer is within one hundred (100) feet of the property line. The connection with the public sewer shall be made within ninety (90) days after date of official notice from the city that connection with the public sewer is required. 
(2)	The owner of any lands hereafter platted in the city, abutting on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is then located a public sanitary sewer, or lying within five hundred (500) feet of an existing public sanitary sewer, shall, at the owner's expense, cause a public sewer to be installed in each of the plats. The public sewer installed by the owner shall be constructed, shall be of a capacity, and shall be connected to the platted lands, as required by and under the supervision and direction of the city manager. 
(g)	Interceptors. Grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be provided if, in the opinion of the city manager, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes, sand and other harmful ingredients. However, interceptors shall not be required for private residential living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the city manager, and shall be located so as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. Interceptors shall be constructed of impervious materials capable of withstanding abrupt and extreme changes in temperature. They shall be of substantial construction, watertight, and equipped with easily removable covers which when bolted in place shall be gas-tight and water-tight. All interceptors shall be maintained by the owner, at the owner's expense, in continuous, efficient operation at all times. 
(h)	Meters. All sewer customers shall either have approved meters on all water sources that ultimately discharge into the sewage works or shall meter the liquid wastes at the point of discharge into the sewage works. 
(i)	Provision of sewer service; capacity. The city shall have the authority to contract to provide sewer services at rates established by this division to any person and to guarantee capacity in its sewer system whenever the city council determines it to be in the best interests of the city to do so.
