(j)	Additional requirements. No statement contained in this section shall be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by the city or by other applicable authorities. 
(k)	Grease traps. 
(1)	All establishments where food is manufactured, sold or prepared, except for small areas designated as employee break areas or the equivalent, discharging wastewater containing fats, oils, and grease (FOG) to the City of Grandville sewage works and/or the POTW shall install, operate, and maintain a sufficiently-sized oil and grease, water and solids separator (hereinafter called grease trap) necessary to achieve and maintain compliance with the limits set forth in article III, division 2 of the Code. 
(2)	Unless otherwise authorized by the department of public works (DPW) director, all grease traps shall be of the outdoor, inline variety. With special authorization by the director, grease traps of the indoor, under-counter, stand-alone variety may be allowed. In this case, maintenance of indoor grease traps shall be performed at frequencies necessary to protect the capacity of the sewer system against accumulation of grease and oils, as required by the "25% Rule" as defined herein. Under no condition shall an indoor grease trap be cleaned at intervals less than once every fourteen (14) days unless approved in writing by the DPW director. 
(3)	Grease traps shall be provided when they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease in amounts that may potentially violate the Grandville Code of Ordinances or any flammable wastes, sand or other substances that are deemed harmful to the collection system and/or the wastewater treatment plant. Such traps shall not be required for dwelling units. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the DPW director and shall be located so as to be readily accessible for cleaning and inspection. 
(4)	Grease traps shall be constructed of impervious materials capable of withstanding abrupt and extreme changes in temperature. They shall be of substantial construction, watertight and equipped with easily removable covers which, when bolted in place, shall be gastight and watertight. 
(5)	Where installed, all grease traps shall be cleaned and maintained by the owner and shall be operated continuously in an efficient manner whenever the facility is in operation. The city shall have the right to inspect all traps and the maintenance and disposal records related to the operation of grease traps. 
(6)	The user shall be responsible for the proper removal and legal disposal of the grease trap waste. All waste removed from each grease trap must be disposed of at a facility permitted to receive such waste. No grease trap pumpage may be discharged to the city sewer system. Maintenance shall include the complete removal of all contents, including floatable materials, wastewater, sludges and solids and jet flushing to remove measurable build-up on tank walls. Top skimming of outdoor grease traps, decanting or back flushing of the grease trap or its wastes for the purpose of reducing the volume to be hauled is prohibited. 
(7)	There shall be ample room and reasonable access to grease traps to allow accurate sampling and preparation of samples for transport and analysis. 
(8)	Grease traps shall be installed in compliance with the current plumbing codes adopted by the city. The DPW director shall make final determination and approval of a grease trap's size. If additional pretreatment and/or maintenance is required to meet the provisions in this section, the DPW director, may require that the establishment in existence prior to the effective date of this section upgrade to the requirements provided. 
(9)	Maintenance of an outdoor grease trap shall be performed at frequencies necessary to protect the capacity of the sewer system against accumulation of grease and oils, as required by the "25% Rule" and at intervals no less than once every ninety (90) days unless approved in writing by the DPW director. 
(10)	Use of any bacteriological, chemical or enzymatic addition for the purpose of maintaining a grease trap is prohibited unless written approval is obtained from the DPW director. 
(11)	The user shall be responsible for maintaining records and/or manifests as to the dates of service, quantity and waste hauler name at the user's location for a period of three (3) years, which records shall be subject to review by the city without prior notification. 
(12)	Should any user fail to properly clean and maintain a grease trap as required herein, the city, at its option, may contract for appropriate cleaning and maintenance by a licensed contractor, the cost of which shall be collectable by the city from the user at a charge of actual cost plus one hundred (100) percent. 
(Ord. No. 280, § 2, eff. 2-19-2010) 
Sec. 26-104. - Building sewers and connections. 
(a)	Permit required. It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to uncover, use, alter, disturb, or make any connections with or opening into any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the city manager as provided by this division. 
(b)	Classes of permits; application. There shall be two (2) classes of building sewer connection permits, the first class for service to establishments producing industrial wastes, and the second class for all other user classes. For either class of permit, the owner or the owner's agent shall apply on a permit application form furnished by the city. The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications, or other information determined necessary by the city manager to adequately evaluate the application. The permit application shall be accompanied by an application fee in an amount established by resolution of the city council. 
(c)	Denial of permit. The city manager may deny a building sewer connection permit if the application for the permit indicates that the proposed discharge will be harmful to or hinder the operation of the POTW or storm sewer, will violate the provisions of this division, or will endanger the public health or safety or the environment. 
(d)	Costs, expenses and liability. All costs, expenses and liability incident to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify and save harmless the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. 
(e)	Separate sewer required; exception. A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building. However, where one (1) building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no separate building sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, courtyard or driveway, the building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one (1) building sewer. The city assumes no responsibility for damage caused by or resulting from any single building sewer which serves more than one (1) building. Compliance with pretreatment standards and requirements prescribed by this division shall be determined within each tributary to the common sewer prior to commingling with other wastewater. 
(f)	Existing building sewers. An existing building sewer may be used in connection with a new building only after examination and a determination by the city manager that the existing building sewer complies with all applicable requirements of this division. 
(g)	Requirements for building sewer installation and connection. Except as otherwise expressly provided by this section, the size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building sewer, and the methods to be used in excavating, placing the pipe, jointing, testing and back-filling the trench, shall conform to the requirements of applicable building and plumbing codes, or other applicable rules and regulations of the city. In the absence of code provisions or in amplification thereof, the materials and procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the American Society for Testing Materials (A.S.T.M.) and the Water Pollution Control Federation (W.P.C.F.) shall apply. 
(1)	If the building sewer is located within ten (10) feet of a water service pipe, is exposed to damage by tree roots, or is installed in filled or otherwise unstable ground, the use of vitrified clay pipe or cement asbestos pipe for that part of the sewer so situated is prohibited. The building sewer shall not be located closer than three (3) feet on a horizontal plane to any other utility service. 
(2)	The size of the building sewer shall not be less than four (4) inches when cast iron is used and six (6) inches when clay pipe is used. The slope shall not be less than one-eighth inch per lineal foot. 
(3)	Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. No building sewer shall be laid parallel to and within three (3) feet of any bearing wall which might thereby be weakened. The depth shall be sufficient to afford protection from frost. The building sewer shall be laid at uniform grade and in straight alignment insofar as possible. Changes in direction shall be made only with properly curved pipe or long-radius fittings with a cleanout at each curved pipe. 
(4)	In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the building sewer, sewage carried by such drain shall be lifted by approved means and discharged to the building sewer. 
(5)	All excavation required for the installation of a building sewer shall be open trench work unless otherwise approved by the city manager. No backfill shall be performed until the work has been inspected and approved by the city manager. Under no circumstances shall cinders be used as backfill. 
(6)	The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall be made at the "Y" branch, if the "Y" branch is available at a suitable location. If the public sewer is twelve (12) inches in diameter or less, and no "Y" branch is available at a suitable location, the owner shall, at the owner's expense, install a "Y" branch in the public sewer at the location specified by the city manager. If the public sewer is greater than twelve (12) inches in diameter, and no "Y" branch is available at a suitable location, a neat hole may be cut into the public sewer to receive the building sewer, with entry in the downstream direction at an angle of about forty-five (45) degrees. A forty-five (45) degree ell may be used to make the connection, with the spigot end cut so as not to extend past the inner surface of the public sewer. The inside crown line of the building sewer at the point of connection shall be at the same or higher elevation than the inside crown line of the public sewer. A smooth, neat joint shall be made, and the connection shall be made secure and watertight by encasement in concrete. Special fittings may be used for the connection only if approved by the city manager. 
(7)	All excavation for building sewer installations shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city. 
(h)	Inspection required. The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the city department of public works when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection shall be made under the supervision of the city department of public works within forty-eight (48) hours (excluding Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays) of receipt of notice by the department of public works. 
(i)	Connection of surface runoff or groundwater prohibited. No person shall make connection of roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains, areaway drains, or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer. 
(Ord. No. 280, § 2, eff. 2-19-2010) 
Sec. 26-105. - Discharge to the POTW; prohibitions, limitations and requirements. 
(a)	General discharge prohibitions. No user shall discharge or cause to be discharged into the POTW any pollutant which causes pass through or interference. This general prohibition, and the specific discharge prohibitions in section 26-105(b), shall apply to every user whether or not the user is subject to other pretreatment standards or requirements. 
(b)	Specific discharge prohibitions. Except as expressly provided below, or as otherwise expressly authorized or made more restrictive by another provision of this division, by an order of determination, or by special agreement between the city and a user, a user shall not discharge or cause to be discharged into the POTW any of the following: 
(1)	Solid or viscous pollutants in amounts which will cause obstruction to the flow in the POTW, or otherwise result in interference. In no case shall any grease or oil or other substance that will solidify or become viscous in the sewer exceed seventy (70) mg/l (daily average); provided that any grease, oil, or other substance that will solidify or become viscous in the sewer that exceeds fifty (50) mg/l (daily average) will be surcharged at a rate established by resolution of the city council. 
(2)	Any pollutant, including oxygen demanding pollutants, released in a discharge at a flow rate and/or pollutant concentration which will cause interference in the POTW. 
(3)	Heat in amounts which will inhibit biological activity in the POTW resulting in interference, but in no case heat in such quantities that the temperature at the POTW treatment plant exceeds one hundred four (104) degrees Fahrenheit (40 degrees Centigrade). No discharge to the POTW shall have a temperature less than thirty-two (32) degrees Fahrenheit or greater than one hundred fifty (150) degrees Fahrenheit. 
(4)	Petroleum oil, nonbiodegradable cutting oil, or products of mineral oil origin in amounts that will cause interference or pass through. 
(5)	Pollutants which result in the presence of toxic gases, vapors or fumes within the POTW in a quantity that may cause acute or chronic worker health and safety problems. 
(6)	Pollutants which create a fire or explosion hazard in the POTW, including, without limitation, waste streams with a closed cup flashpoint of less than one hundred forty (140) degrees Fahrenheit (sixty (60) degrees Centigrade) using the test methods specified in 40 CFR 261.21. 
(7)	Pollutants which will cause corrosive structural damage to the POTW or which are otherwise capable of causing a hazard to POTW personnel, but in no case discharges with pH lower than 6.0 or above 10.0. 
(8)	Any noxious or malodorous liquids, solids or gases which, either singly or by combination or interaction with other wastes, are sufficient to create a public nuisance, to endanger the public health or the environment, or to prevent entry into the sewers for maintenance and repair. 
(9)	Any wastewater with objectionable color not removed in the treatment process, such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and vegetable tanning solution, which could interfere with treatment plant processes or prevent analytical determinations. 
(10)	Any five-day, twenty (20) degree Centigrade BOD in excess of three thousand (3,000) mg/l; provided that any five-day, twenty (20) degree Centigrade BOD in excess of two hundred fifty (250) mg/l (daily average) will be surcharged at a rate established by resolution of the city council. 
(11)	Suspended solids (SS) in excess often thousand (10,000) mg/l; provided that any SS in excess of two hundred (200) mg/l (daily average) will be surcharged at a rate established by resolution of the city council. 
(12)	COD in excess of seven thousand five hundred (7,500) mg/l; provided that any COD in excess of six hundred (600) mg/l (daily average) will be surcharged at a rate established by resolution of the city council. 
(13)	Chlorine demand in excess of fifty (50) mg/l (daily average).
(14)	Phosphorus in excess of thirty (30) mg/l (daily average); provided that any phosphorus in excess of eight and one-half (8.5) mg/l (daily average) will be surcharged at a rate established by resolution of the city council. 
(15)	Ammonia nitrogen in excess of seventy-five (75) mg/l (daily average); provided that any ammonia nitrogen in excess of thirty (30) mg/l (daily average) will be surcharged at a rate established by resolution of the city council. 
(16)	Pollutants in concentrations which exceed the concentrations (daily average) listed below or any other metallic compounds in sufficient quantity to impair the operations of the POTW treatment processes: 
Cadmium (Cd)1.2 mg/lZinc (Zn)4.2 mg/lTotal Chromium (Cr)2.0 mg/lCopper (Cu)1.5 mg/lCyanide (Cn)1.0 mg/lNickel (Ni)1.5 mg/lLead (Pb)0.6 mg/lSilver (Ag)0.6 mg/lMercury (Hg)Nondetectible per U.S. EPA Method 245Total Metals10.0 mg/lPhenols (or derivative)0.2 mg/lTotal Toxic Organics (TTO)2.13 mg/l 
(17)	Radioactive wastes or isotopes of a half-life or concentration which may exceed limits established by the city in compliance with applicable state and federal regulations. 
(18)	Garbage not properly shredded. To be considered "properly shredded" for purposes of this division, garbage must be shredded to the degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particles greater than one-half inch in dimension. 
(19)	Any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, or other unpolluted drainage, or any unpolluted noncontact cooling water, unpolluted air-conditioning water or unpolluted industrial process water, except as otherwise may be expressly permitted by applicable law, regulation or permit and having first obtained necessary approvals from any interested governmental agencies. 
(20)	Any substance which tends to settle out in the sewer and cause stoppage or obstruction to the flow in the POTW. 
(21)	Any substance which may be harmful to POTW pipes, jointing material or manholes.
(22)	Any pollutant that results in excess foaming during the treatment process. (Excess foaming is any foam which, in the opinion of the superintendent, inhibits, disrupts or creates a nuisance in the treatment process.) 
(23)	Any discharge of a character or in a quantity that requires unusual attention or expense to handle at the POTW or to maintain the POTW. 
(24)	Any substance which may cause the effluent from the POTW or any other product of the sewage works, such as residues, sludges or scums, to be unsuitable for reclamation and reuse or cause interference with the reclamation process, or which otherwise inhibits or disrupts the POTW sludge processes, use or disposal. 
(25)	Any liquid, solid or gas, including, without limitation, any toxic pollutant or hazardous substance, which by reason of its nature or quantity is or may be sufficient, either singly or by combination or interaction with other substances, to be injurious in any way to the POTW, the POTW treatment facilities, processes or operations; to endanger human health or the environment; to create a public nuisance; to result in noncompliance with the POTW's NPDES permit or the water quality standards of the receiving water; or to result in noncompliance with any other applicable pretreatment standard or requirement. 
(26)	Any trucked wastes or hauled pollutants, except at discharge points designated by the city manager and subject to the prior approval of the city manager. The city manager shall determine whether to permit the discharge of trucked wastes or hauled pollutants based on the particular nature or quantity of the proposed discharge in accordance with the discharge prohibitions, limitations and requirements provided by this division. The city manager may impose any conditions on the discharge determined necessary to ensure compliance with this division, including, without limitation, requiring a certification or manifest to verify the source of the wastes, or sampling and analysis of individual truckloads prior to discharge. 
(27)	Any pollutant or discharge prohibited by, or in excess of the limitation contained in, any applicable order of determination. 
(c)	Pretreatment standards and requirements. The following provisions shall apply in determining compliance with applicable pretreatment standards and requirements: 
(1)	The categorical pretreatment standards when finalized for specific industries shall become a part of the requirements of this division in accordance with federal and state laws and regulations. A user shall comply with all categorical pretreatment standards and any other pretreatment requirements established under the FWPCA that are applicable to that user. If specific parameter levels established by this division are more restrictive than an equivalent federal or state requirement, the more restrictive parameter level established by this division shall apply. 
(2)	If federal categorical standards are expressed in terms of mass of pollutants per unit of production, the city may elect to convert these limits to equivalent limitation expressed as either a mass of pollutant discharged per day or an effluent concentration. Equivalent discharge limits calculated in accordance with federal regulations (40 CFR 403.6) shall be deemed pretreatment standards and enforceable as pretreatment standards. Any industrial user subject to equivalent mass or concentration limits calculated from a production based standard that does not notify the superintendent of significant changes in production levels as required by 40 CFR 403.6(c)(9) or MAC 323.2311(5)(g) shall be required to meet the applicable mass or concentration limits that were based on the original estimate of the long term production rate. 
(3)	A user may apply to the superintendent for an adjustment in a categorical pretreatment standard to reflect the presence of pollutants in the user's intake water in accordance with 40 CFR 403.15 (net/gross calculations). In the event that adjustment is made, the adjusted categorical pretreatment standard shall apply, provided the adjustment will not result in interference or pass through. 
(4)	If process effluent is mixed prior to treatment with wastewaters other than those generated by the regulated process, fixed alternative discharge limits may be derived by the POTW, or by the industrial user with the written approval of the POTW, for application to the mixed effluent as provided by 40 CFR 403.6(e) (combined waste stream formula) and MAC 323.2311(7). 
(5)	Existing sources shall comply with applicable pretreatment standards and requirements in accordance with the deadline for compliance provided by 40 CFR 403.6(b) and as provided by the city. New sources shall install and have in operating condition, and shall "start-up" all pollution control equipment required to meet applicable pretreatment standards and requirements before beginning to discharge. Within the shortest feasible time (not to exceed ninety (90) days), new sources must meet all applicable pretreatment standards and requirements. 
(6)	Alternative categorical limits may be derived and applied to an industrial user otherwise subject to categorical standards pursuant to MAC 323.2313, at the city manager's discretion. 
(d)	Reserved right of revision. Future conditions imposed on the city by other government agencies may require subsequent amendment of this division by the city. If federal pretreatment standards require limits on parameters not covered in this division or limits more stringent than those specified in this division, the federal limits shall control and shall be complied with within the time period provided by 40 CFR 403.6(b). The city reserves the right to establish more restrictive prohibitions, limitation or requirements for discharges to the POTW as necessary to prevent interference, pass through, to protect the POTW, to comply with applicable federal or state laws or regulations, to comply with the POTW's NPDES permit, or otherwise as determined necessary by the city. 
(e)	Special agreements. Nothing in this division shall be construed as preventing a special agreement between the city and any user (which may be in the form of an order of determination). The special arrangements may include, but are not limited to, pollutant concentration discharge limitations different than those provided in this section. The city shall not be obligated to enter into a special agreement, but may do so in its discretion. A special agreement shall not create any vested rights or property rights in the user. The special agreement may be terminated or modified at will by the city. As a condition to the issuance of or entry into a special agreement, the city shall require the user to sign an acknowledgement and acceptance of the provisions of this section. A special agreement or arrangement may contain provision for the user to pay a surcharge to the city. A violation of the terms of a special agreement shall be a violation of this division. No special agreement shall be entered into which, in the opinion of the city manager, has the potential to cause or result in a discharge which violates applicable pretreatment standards or the discharge prohibitions established by this division, to cause or result in pass through or interference, or to endanger public health or the environment. 
(f)	Dilution prohibited as substitute for treatment. Unless expressly authorized to do so by an applicable pretreatment standard or requirement, no user shall ever increase the use of process water, or in any other way attempt to dilute a discharge as a partial or complete substitute for adequate treatment to achieve compliance with any pretreatment standard or requirement. 
(g)	Pretreatment required prior to point of discharge. The discharge prohibition, limitation and requirements provided by this division or by any order or special agreement shall apply at the point where wastewater and pollutants are discharged or caused to be discharged into the POTW and any required pretreatment shall be effected prior to that point of discharge. 
(h)	Authority for control of discharges to POTW. If any user discharges or proposes to discharge wastewaters or pollutants to the POTW which are prohibited or limited by this division, the city manager may issue an order, enter into a special agreement, impose surcharges, assess fines and penalties, or take any other action as authorized by this division or by other applicable law or regulation to assure and require compliance with this division. 
(Ord. No. 280, § 2, eff. 2-19-2010) 
Sec. 26-106. - Industrial waste control program. 
(a)	Notice of intent to discharge; information required. Prior to connecting to the POTW and commencing any discharge to the POTW, all nondomestic users must notify the city of the nature and characteristics of their processes and proposed discharge. Existing industrial users already connected to the POTW or discharging to the POTW shall submit the notice and required information upon request of the city manager. The notice of intent to discharge shall be made on forms prepared by the city, or in the form prescribed by the city, for that purpose. The city manager shall determine whether the user will be considered a significant industrial user for purposes of this division based on the information received from the user (in addition to any other information that may be available regarding the user's processes or discharge). The information required by this section shall be provided by the user in units and terms appropriate for adequate evaluation by the city manager, and shall include at least the following as applicable to the user: 
(1)	User name, address, and location (if different than address).
(2)	Whether the user is a corporation, partnership, proprietorship, or other type of entity, and the name of the person(s) responsible for discharges by the user. 
(3)	Standard industrial classification (SIC) code of both the industry (or use) as a whole and any processes for which categorical pretreatment standards have been promulgated. 
(4)	Wastewater constituents and characteristics, including, without limitation, the nature and quantity of any pollutants which are limited or regulated by any federal, state, or local standards or requirements. Sampling and analysis shall be performed in accordance with the procedures established by the U.S. EPA and contained in 40 CFR part 136. 
(5)	Time and duration of discharges.
(6)	Daily maximum, daily average, and monthly average wastewater flow rates, including daily, monthly, and seasonal variation, if any. 
(7)	Description of activities, facilities, and plant process on the premises, including a list of all raw materials and chemicals used at the facility which are or could be (by accident or otherwise) discharged to the POTW. 
(8)	Site plans, floor plans, mechanical and plumbing plans, and details to show all sewers, sewer connections, floor drain, inspection manholes, sampling chambers, and appurtenances by size, location and elevation. 
(9)	Each product produced by type, amount, process, and rate of production, as relevant to pretreatment standards and requirements. 
(10)	Type and amount of raw materials processed (average and maximum per day), including copies of material safety data sheets. 
(11)	Number and type of employees, and hours of operation, and proposed or actual hours of operation of the pretreatment system. 
(12)	A listing of and copies of all environmental permits held by the user applicable to the premises. 
(13)	A statement whether additional operation and maintenance (O&M) and/or additional pretreatment is required for the user to meet all applicable federal, state and local standards and requirements. If additional O&M or additional pretreatment will be required to meet the applicable standards and requirements, then the user shall indicate the shortest time schedule necessary to accomplish installation or adoption of the additional O&M and/or pretreatment. The completion date in this compliance schedule shall not be longer than the compliance date established for the applicable pretreatment standard. The following conditions shall apply to this schedule: 
a.	The schedule shall contain progress increments in the form of dates for the commencement and completion of major events leading to the construction and operation of additional pretreatment required for the user to meet the applicable pretreatment standards (including, without limitation, hiring an engineer, completing preliminary plans, completing final plans, executing contracts for major components, commencing construction, completing construction, beginning operation, conducting routine operation, and all other acts necessary to achieve compliance with this division). No progress increment referred to above shall exceed two (2) months. 
b.	No later than fourteen (14) days following each date in the schedule and the final date for compliance, the user shall submit a progress report to the city manager including, at a minimum, whether or not the user complied with the increment of progress, the reason for any delay, and if appropriate, the steps being taken by the user to return to the schedule established. In no event shall more than three (3) months elapse between the progress reports to the city manager. 
(14)	Any other information determined necessary by the city manager to adequately evaluate the impacts of the discharge on the POTW and on POTW operations and treatment processes. To the extent that actual data is not available for a new source, the user shall supply estimated or expected information. All information requested by the city manager shall be submitted by the user to the city manager as soon as possible, but in no case later than thirty (30) days after receipt of the request for information. 
(15)	All notices and information submitted by a user as required by this section shall be signed and certified as provided by section 26-106(c)(9). 
(b)	Sampling, analysis and monitoring. Unless expressly provided otherwise for a particular industrial user by an order or special agreement, all users shall sample, monitor and analyze their discharges to the POTW according to the following minimum requirements: 
(1)	Sampling and analytical techniques and procedures. All sampling, measurements, tests, and analyses of the characteristics of discharges to the POTW shall be performed in accordance with procedures approved by the U.S. EPA contained in 40 CFR Part 136. If the city manager determines that these sampling and analytical techniques are not available or do not apply to the discharge or pollutants in question, sampling and analysis shall be performed using validated sampling and analytical methods and procedures approved by the city manager. 
(2)	Sampling frequency. Users shall sample their discharges to the POTW at a frequency necessary to assess and assure compliance with the requirements of this division, any order issued pursuant to this division, all applicable pretreatment standards and requirements, other applicable state and federal laws and regulation, or as otherwise determined necessary by the city manager consistent with the purposes and intent of this division. At a minimum, all users shall sample their effluent two (2) times per year and report the results to the city manager. Each discharge point to the POTW shall be sampled and reported individually. 
(3)	Sample types. Where representative samples are required to be taken, a user shall take a minimum of four (4) grab samples for pH, cyanide, total phenols, oil and grease, sulfide, and volatile organics. For all other pollutants, twenty-four-hour composite samples must be obtained through flow-proportional composite sampling techniques. The city manager may waive flow-proportional composite sampling for any user that demonstrates to the satisfaction of the city manager that flow-proportional sampling is infeasible. If flow-proportional sampling is waived, samples may instead be obtained through time-proportional composite sampling techniques, or through a minimum of four (4) grab samples, if the user demonstrates that this will provide a representative sample of the effluent being discharged. 
(4)	Approval of sampling methods, equipment and location required. Users shall submit a written description of the specific sampling method, sampling equipment, and sampling location to the city for approval by the city manager. Users discharging as of the effective date of this division shall obtain approval within ninety (90) days of that date. For new sources, approval shall be obtained prior to commencement of the discharge. Except as otherwise authorized by this division and approved by the city manager, industrial users subject to categorical pretreatment standards shall conduct their sampling and monitoring at the end of each process waste stream (or immediately following the pretreatment associated with each process waste stream, if pretreatment is provided for the waste stream). 
(5)	Costs of sampling and analyses. All samples shall be taken and analyzed at the sole cost of the user. 
(6)	Self-monitoring. Except as otherwise provided by this division, self-monitoring shall be conducted by each user to insure compliance with all applicable requirements of this division and other applicable laws and regulation. A user performing its own sampling shall submit the samples for analysis to a laboratory approved by the city (which may include the user's own laboratory). If the user uses its own laboratory for the analysis, the user shall send a split sample to an independent laboratory at least once per year as a quality control check. If a user performs its own sampling and analysis, the city may also take and cause to be analyzed up to four (4) daily composite samples or up to four (4) grab samples per day, for up to four (4) days in any calendar month, at the sole cost of the user. A user performing its own sampling shall record the date when a sample is taken, start time, stop time, sample location, sampler programming information, and persons involved in the sampling. If sampling performed by a user indicates a violation, the user shall notify the city manager within twenty-four (24) hours of becoming aware of the violation. The user shall also repeat the sampling and analysis and submit the results of the repeat analysis to the city within thirty (30) days after becoming aware of the violation, except that the user shall not be required to resample if (a) the city performs sampling at the user at a frequency of at least once per month, or (b) the city performs sampling at the user between the time when the user performs its initial sampling and the time when the user receives the results of the sampling which indicates the violation. 
(7)	Sampling and analysis performed by city. The sampling and analysis required by this division may be performed by the city in lieu of the user, as determined necessary and appropriate by the city manager. The city shall provide the user with copies of analytical results prepared by the city. If the city performs the required sampling and analysis for a user, the user shall pay a sampling fee to the city to fully reimburse the city for the sampling, including administrative and overhead costs. The city may contract with an independent firm to perform the sampling and analysis and the user shall fully reimburse the city for amounts paid by the city to the firm. 
(8)	Split samples. If requested, the city shall be provided with splits of any sample taken by a user. A user shall be provided with splits of any sample taken by the city if the user requests a split sample within fourteen (14) days after the sample is taken. If possible, split samples shall be provided at the time the sample is taken. 
(9)	Maintenance, repair and calibration of equipment. A user who is performing self-monitoring, or the city if performing sampling and monitoring in lieu of a user, shall contract with an independent company to maintain, repair, and calibrate the sampling and flow measurement equipment and instruments used to monitor the user. The maintenance, repair, and calibration shall be performed as often as necessary to ensure that monitoring data is accurate and representative, but in no event less frequently than twice in a calendar year at reasonable intervals. The city, in any event, may inspect and test a user's flow meters at reasonable times. 
(10)	Required sampling structures and devices. The city may require any user to install at each discharge point a suitable control structure (such as a manhole or sampling vault) and necessary measuring and sampling devices to facilitate the observation, sampling, and measurement of the quantity, composition, and concentrations of discharges to the POTW, including sampling and measuring of the building sewer and/or internal drainage systems. The control structure and devices shall be constructed and installed at the user's expense in accordance with plans submitted to the city manager and with all applicable local construction standards and specification. The control structure and devices shall be maintained by the user so as to be safe and accessible to POTW personnel during all reasonable times and so as to provide accurate and representative monitoring data. The control structure shall be located on the user's premises, provided that if a location on the premises would be impractical or cause undue hardship to the user, the city manager may permit the structure to be located in the public street or sidewalk if it will not be obstructed by landscaping or parked vehicles. The complexity of the required control structure or devices may vary with sampling requirements determined necessary by the city manager to protect the POTW and to comply with applicable laws and regulation. The control structure and monitoring facilities shall be constructed by the user within ninety (90) days of written notification to the user by the city that the structure and facility are required. If a user fails to install or maintain a required structure or device, the city may do so at the expense of the user. Samples shall be taken at the control structure. In the absence of a suitable control structure as required by this section, samples shall be taken immediately downstream from pretreatment facilities if pretreatment facilities exist, or immediately downstream from the regulated process if no pretreatment facilities exist. 
(c)	Reporting and notice requirements. All industrial users shall comply with the reporting and notice requirements provided by this section, as follows: 
(1)	Reports by industrial users regarding categorical pretreatment standards and requirements. 
a.	Baseline reports (40 CFR 403.12(b); MAC 323.2310(2)). Within one hundred eighty (180) days after the effective date of a categorical pretreatment standard, or one hundred eighty (180) days after the final administrative decision made upon a category determination submission under 40 CFR 403.6(a)(4) whichever is later, an existing industrial user subject to the categorical pretreatment standards and which currently discharges or is scheduled to discharge to the POTW shall submit a report to the city manager as required by 40 CFR 403.12(b) and MAC 323.2310(2), signed by and certified as required by MAC 323.2310(2). At least ninety (90) days prior to commencement of discharge, new sources, and sources that become industrial users subsequent to the promulgation of an applicable categorical pretreatment standard shall submit the reports to the city manager as required by 40 CFR 403.12(b) and MAC 323.2310(2), signed by an authorized representative. 
b.	Reports on compliance with categorical pretreatment standard deadline (40 CFR 403.12(d); MAC 323.2310(3)). Within ninety (90) days following the date for final compliance with applicable categorical pretreatment standard or, in the case of a new source, following commencement of the discharge to the POTW, any industrial user subject to categorical pretreatment standards and requirements shall submit the reports to the city manager required by 40 CFR 403.12(d) and MAC 323.2310(3), signed by an authorized representative. 
c.	Periodic reports on continued compliance (40 CFR 403.12(e); MAC 323.2310(4)). Any industrial user subject to a categorical pretreatment standard, after the compliance date of the categorical pretreatment standard, or, in the case of a new source, after commencement of the discharge into the public sewer or POTW, shall submit the periodic reports to the city manager required by 40 CFR 403.12(e) and MAC 323.2310(4), signed by an authorized representative. These periodic reports shall be submitted at least once every six (6) months (during the months of June and December unless alternate months are specified by the city manager), unless required more frequently by the applicable pretreatment standard or by the city manager. The reports required by this section shall be based upon data obtained through appropriate sampling and analysis performed during the period covered by the report, which data is representative of conditions occurring during the reporting period. If a user subject to the reporting requirements of this section monitors any pollutant more frequently than required by the city, using the required monitoring, sampling and analytical procedures, the results of this monitoring shall be included in the report. 
(2)	Reports required for significant industrial users not subject to categorical pretreatment standards (40 CFR 403.12(h)). All significant industrial users not subject to categorical pretreatment standards shall submit to the POTW periodic reports required by 40 CFR 403.12(h) and MAC 323.2310(7), signed by an authorized representative and providing information regarding the quality and quantity of wastewater and pollutants discharged into the POTW. These reports shall be based on sampling and analysis performed in the period covered by the report, and performed in accordance with the sampling, analysis and monitoring requirements provided by section 26-106(b). The reports shall be submitted at least once every six (6) months for the preceding six (6) months (during the months of June and December unless alternate months are specified by the city manager), unless required more frequently by the city manager. The reports shall be submitted on forms provided by (or in a format prescribed by) the city, and shall include, without limitation, a description of the nature of the discharge; the volume of wastewater; the concentration of pollutants; the names of all person(s) responsible for operating and maintaining any pretreatment equipment, pretreatment processes, or responsible for wastewater management at the user's facilities, with a brief description of each person's duties; information regarding materials or substances which may cause interference or pass through; and any other information deemed necessary by the city manager to assess and assure compliance with applicable discharge requirements or to safeguard the operation of the POTW. 
(3)	Notice by user of potential problems (40 CFR 403.12(f); MAC 323.2310(5)). All industrial users, whether or not subject to categorical pretreatment standards, shall notify the POTW immediately of all discharges by the user that could cause problems to the POTW, including, without limitation, slug loadings, or that exceed a discharge prohibition or limitation provided by this division. 
(4)	Notice by user of violation of pretreatment standards (40 CFR 403.12(g)(2); MAC 323.2310(6)(b)). If sampling performed by an industrial user to demonstrate compliance with applicable pretreatment standards indicates a violation, the user shall notify the POTW within twenty-four (24) hours of becoming aware of the violation and perform any additional sampling required under MAC 323.2310(6)(b). 
(5)	Notice by user of changed discharge or change in user status (40 CFR 403.12(j); MAC 323.2310(9)). All industrial users shall promptly notify the city manager in advance of any substantial change in the volume or character of pollutants in their discharge, including the hazardous wastes for which the industrial user has submitted initial notification under section 26-106(c)(6), as required by 40 CFR 403.12(j) and MAC 323.2310(9). If the change in discharge may convert an industrial user into a significant industrial user, the user shall promptly notify the city manager. 
(6)	Notice by user regarding wastes which are otherwise hazardous (40 CFR 403.12(p). Any industrial user that discharges to the POTW a substance which, if disposed of other than by discharge to the POTW, would be a hazardous waste under 40 CFR part 261 or under the rules promulgated under Part 111 of NREPA shall notify the city manager, the U.S. EPA Region V Waste Management Division Director, and the Chief of the Waste and Hazardous Materials Division of the Department of Natural Resources and Environment of the discharge as required by 40 CFR 403.12(p) and MAC 323.2310(15). 
(7)	Notice by user of installation of new pretreatment facilities. Within five (5) days after completing installation of new pretreatment facilities, an industrial user shall notify the city manager in writing of the time and date when it intends to commence operation of the new facilities, and the identity of the person who will conduct any tests to be performed. The pretreatment facilities shall not be placed in regular operation until adequate tests have been conducted to establish that the discharges will comply with the requirements of this division. Upon prior written request by the city manager, the user shall allow a representative of the POTW to observe the tests at the time they are conducted. The cost of the tests shall be paid by the user. 
(8)	Other reports and notices required by this division or by other applicable laws and regulations. Users shall comply with all other reporting or notice requirements as provided by this division or as required by any other applicable law or regulation, including, without limitation, the reporting and/or notice requirements in connection with intent to discharge (section 26-106(a)), accidental discharge (section 26-106(g)), upset (section 26106(h)) and bypass (section 26-106(i)). 
(9)	Signatory and certification requirements. The reports required by sections 26-106(c)(1) and (2) shall be signed and certified as follows: 
a.	Required signatures. The reports shall be signed by one (1) of the following persons: 
1.	By a responsible corporate officer, if the industrial user submitting the reports is a corporation. A "responsible corporate officer" means: A president, secretary, treasurer, or vice president of the corporation in charge of a principal business function, or any other person who performs similar policy or decision-making functions for the corporation; or the principal manager of one (1) or more manufacturing, production, or operation facilities employing more than two hundred fifty (250) persons or having gross annual sales or expenditures of more than twenty-five million dollars ($25,000,000.00), in second quarter 1980 dollars, if authority to sign documents has been assigned or delegated to the manager in accordance with corporate procedures. 
2.	By a general partner or proprietor if the industrial user submitting the reports is a partnership or sole proprietorship respectively. 
3.	By the principal executive officer or director having responsibility for the overall operation of the discharging facility if the industrial user submitting the reports is a federal, state or local governmental entity. 
4.	By a duly authorized representative of an individual designated in sections 26-106(c)(9)a.1., 2. or 3., if the authorization is made in writing by the individual designated in sections 26-106(c)(9)a.1., 2. or 3.; the authorization specifies either an individual or a position having responsibility for the overall operation of the facility from which the discharge originates (such as the position of plant manager, pretreatment operator, pretreatment superintendent, or a position of equivalent responsibility, or having overall responsibility for the environmental matters for the company); and the written authorization is submitted to the city manager. 
5.	If an authorization under section 26-106(c)(9)a.4. is no longer accurate because a different individual or position has responsibility for the overall operation of the facility, or overall responsibility for environmental matters for the company, a new authorization satisfying the requirements of section 26-106(c)(9)a.4. must be submitted to the city manager prior to or together with any reports to be signed by an authorized representative. 
b.	Required certification. The reports shall include the following certification statement: "I certify under penalty of law that this document and all attachments were prepared under my direction or supervision in accordance with a system designed to assure that qualified personnel properly gather and evaluate the information submitted. Based on my inquiry of the person or persons who manage the system, or those persons directly responsible for gathering the information, the information submitted is, to the best of my knowledge and belief, true, accurate, and complete. I am aware that there are significant penalties for submitting false information, including the possibility of fine and imprisonment for knowing violations." 
(d)	Orders of determination required for significant industrial users. It is unlawful for any significant industrial user to discharge to the POTW without an order of determination as provided by this section. 
(1)	Determination and notification of significant industrial user status. The city manager shall determine whether an industrial user is a significant industrial user based on the criteria set forth in section 26-102 as applied to all available information regarding the user's processes and discharges, including, without limitation, the information provided by the user under section 26-106(a), and any additional information requested by the city manager as required to adequately evaluate the user's processes and discharges. Upon determining that a user meets the criteria, the city manager shall notify the user in writing of its status as a significant industrial user and of the requirement to obtain an order of determination for discharge to the POTW as provided by this section. 
(2)	Submission of additional required information. A user required to obtain an order of determination shall submit any additional information requested by the city manager as determined necessary by the city manager to adequately prepare the order and to ensure that the user's discharge will comply with applicable pretreatment standards and requirements. All information requested by the city manager shall be submitted by the user to the city manager as soon as possible, but in no case later than thirty (30) days after receipt of the request for information. All information submitted by the user shall be signed and certified as provided by section 26-106(c)(9). 
(3)	Issuance of order. Within thirty (30) days after the submission by the user of all requested information, the city manager shall issue to the user a written order of determination subject to the terms and conditions as provided by this section. An order of determination is considered to be a part of this division. A violation of the terms and conditions of an order of determination is a violation of this division and shall be subject to all enforcement provisions of this division. The issuance of an order of determination shall not relieve a user of its obligation to comply with other provisions of this division or to obtain other permits or approvals which may be required by other federal, state or local laws and regulations. 
(4)	Conditions. Orders of determination shall include any conditions determined by the city manager to be necessary to ensure that the purposes, policies and objectives of this division are accomplished. Further, in issuing an order of determination, it shall be the duty of the city manager to attempt to apportion to each user its fair share of discharge (in terms of the character and/or the quantity of the user's discharge), such that the combined discharges of all users will comply with all applicable pretreatment standards and requirements and will not endanger the POTW or the POTW operations and treatment processes. An order of determination shall include all conditions determined necessary by the city manager to accomplish these purposes, as applicable to the user under consideration, including, without limitation, the following: 
a.	Limits on the average and/or maximum rate of discharge, time of discharge, and/or requirements for flow regulation and equalization. 
b.	Limits on the average and/or maximum concentration, mass, or other measure of identified wastewater constituents or properties. 
c.	Requirements for installation of pretreatment technology or construction of appropriate containment devices, or similar requirements designed to reduce, eliminate, or prevent the introduction of pollutants into the POTW. 
d.	Development and implementation of spill control plans or other special conditions, including additional management practices necessary to adequately prevent accidental, unanticipated, or routine discharges. 
e.	The unit charge and schedule of user charges and fees for the management of the wastewater discharged to the POTW by the user. 
f.	Requirements for installation, maintenance and operation of inspection and sampling facilities and discharge flow monitors. 
g.	Specifications for monitoring programs which may include sampling locations, frequency of sampling, number, types, and standards for tests, and reporting schedules. 
h.	Compliance schedules.
i.	Requirements for submission of technical reports or discharge reports.
j.	Requirements for maintaining and retaining plant records relating to wastewater discharge as specified by the city manager and affording the city manager access to those records. 
k.	Requirements for notification of any new introductions of wastewater constituents or of any substantial change in the volume or character of the wastewater being introduced into the POTW. 
l.	Requirements for the notification of any change in the manufacturing and/or pretreatment process used. 
m.	Requirements for notification of excessive, accidental, or slug discharges.
n.	A statement regarding limitations on transferability of the right to discharge as provided by the order. 
o.	A statement of the duration of the order.
p.	A statement that compliance with the order does not relieve the user of responsibility for compliance with all applicable pretreatment standards and requirements, including those which become effective during the term of the order, and will all other applicable provisions of this division or other law or regulation. 
q.	A statement of applicable civil and criminal fines and penalties for violation of discharge limitations, pretreatment standards and requirements, and compliance schedules. 
r.	Any other conditions as determined necessary by the city manager to ensure compliance with this division and other applicable laws, rules and regulations. 
(5)	Duration. An order of determination shall be issued (or renewed or reissued) for a specified time period not to exceed five (5) years. An order may be issued (or renewed or reissued) for a period of time less than five (5) years, at the discretion of the city manager. 
(6)	Renewal/reissuance of orders. At least ninety (90) days prior to the expiration date of an order of determination, the city manager shall notify a user in writing whether the existing order will be renewed upon the same terms and conditions or whether the order must instead be reissued with new terms and conditions. If the city manager notifies a user that an order will be renewed upon the same terms and conditions, the renewal shall become effective on the date of expiration of the existing order without any further action required by the city or the user (unless otherwise specified by the city manager). If the city manager notifies a user that an order must be reissued with new terms and conditions, the city and the user shall proceed as provided by this section for the initial issuance of orders, including the submission by the user of any additional information required by the city manager in connection with reissuance of the order. The order as reissued shall become effective upon the expiration date of the existing order. 
(7)	Modification of orders. The city manager may modify an order of determination for reasons determined necessary to ensure that the purposes, policies and objectives of this division are accomplished, including, without limitation, any of the following reasons: 
a.	To incorporate any new or revised federal, state or local pretreatment standards or requirements, or other applicable requirement of law or regulation. 
b.	To compensate for increased flows in the entire sewer system or increased contribution of pollutants by other users of the POTW. 
c.	Material or substantial changes or additions to the user's operations, processes, or the character or quantity of discharge, which were not considered in issuing the existing order. 
d.	A change in any condition in connection with either the user or the POTW that requires a temporary or permanent reduction or elimination of the user's discharge to assure compliance with applicable laws, regulation and the POTW's NPDES permit. 
e.	Information indicating that the user's discharge under the existing order threaten to endanger the POTW, the POTW collection or treatment systems, POTW personnel, the public health and safety, or the environment. 
f.	Violation of any terms or conditions of the order.
g.	Revision of, or a grant of a variance from, applicable categorical standards pursuant to 40 CFR 403.13. 
h.	To correct typographical or other errors in the order.
i.	To reflect transfer of the ownership of the user's facility or premises and/or transfer of the user's operation to a new owner/operator. 
j.	Upon request of the user, provided the request does not create a violation of any applicable requirements, standards, laws, rules or regulations, and as determined appropriate by the city manager. 
A user shall be notified of any modification in its order of determination at least thirty (30) days prior to the effective date of the modification, unless the city manager determines that a shorter time is necessary to meet applicable laws and regulations or to protect human health and safety or the environment, or the POTW. 
(8)	Suspension and revocation of orders. An order of determination may be suspended or revoked by the city manager for reasons determined necessary to ensure that the purposes, policies and objectives of this division are accomplished, including, without limitation, any of the following reasons: 
a.	Falsifying self-monitoring reports.
b.	Tampering with monitoring equipment.
c.	Refusing to allow timely access to the user's premises and records.
d.	Failure to meet effluent limitations.
e.	Failure to pay fees, charges, fines or penalties.
f.	Failure to meet compliance schedules.
g.	Failure to comply with any term or condition of the order.
h.	Misrepresentation or failure to disclose fully all relevant facts or information in response to a request by the city manager or in any required report or notice. 
i.	The city manager determines that the discharge permitted under the order has a reasonable potential to endanger human health and safety or the environment or the POTW and the threat can be abated only by suspension or revocation of the order. 
Upon suspension or revocation of an order of determination, a user shall immediately terminate its discharge to the POTW and shall not recommence discharge without further authorization from the city as provided by this division. 
(9)	Limitations on transfer. Orders of determination are issued with regard to specific users for specific operations at specific locations and are not transferable to another user or to another location without the prior written approval of the city manager. The city manager may (but shall not be required to) approve the transfer of an order if all of the following conditions are met: 
a.	The transferor shall give at least forty-five (45) days advance notice to the city manager of the proposed transfer. The notice shall include a written certification signed by the proposed transferee which (i) states that the transferee has no present intent to change the facility's operations and processes; (ii) identifies the specific date on which the transfer is to occur; (iii) acknowledges that the transferee has read and fully understands all terms and conditions of the order; and (iv) acknowledges that the transferee accepts all of the terms and conditions of the order as issued and accepts full responsibility for complying with the existing order if the transfer is approved. 
b.	The transferor has not violated any term or condition of the order or of this division during the six-month period preceding the proposed date of the transfer. 
c.	As of the date of the proposed transfer, there are no unpaid fees, charges, fines or penalties of any kind due to the city from the transferor or the transferee related to use of the POTW. 
d.	Except as to the identity of the new discharger (the transferee), all of the information as originally or subsequently submitted for the order by the transferor, as well as the terms and conditions of the order itself, remain completely accurate with respect to, and fully applicable to, the discharge, facilities, and activities of the transferee. 
If the transfer of an order is approved, the city manager shall make the necessary minor modifications to the order to show the transferee as the new discharger under the order, and a copy of the order shall be provided to the transferee for signature and certification by the transferee as provided by section 26-106(c)(9). 
(10)	Fees. To reimburse the city for costs associated with issuing, administering and monitoring compliance with orders of determination, each industrial user subject to an order of determination shall pay an annual fee in an amount established by resolution of the city council. The initial fee shall be due upon issuance of an order of determination. For each year thereafter, annual fees shall be due on the first day of the month following the anniversary date of the order of determination. The fees required by this section shall be in addition to any other fee, charge or surcharge required by other provisions of this division. 
(11)	Appeals. Except as otherwise provided by this section, an appeal to the sewage board of appeals ("SBA") of any final decision made by the city manager (or other authorized representative of the city) in connection with issuing or implementing an order of determination shall be governed by section 26-109. An appealing party must specify in its notice of appeal the action being appealed and the grounds for the appeal. If an appealing party objects to a particular provision of an order of determination, the notice of appeal must specify the reasons for the objection, and the alternative provision, if any, proposed. The effect of an order of determination or any provision of an order or any final decision made by the city manager or an authorized representative shall not be stayed pending a decision by the SBA on an appeal. If, after considering the record on appeal, including any statements or evidence provided by city official or employees in response to the appeal, the SBA determines that an order of determination or any provision of an order should be reconsidered, the SBA shall remand the matter to the appropriate city official for further action as specified by the SBA. Specific provisions of an order of determination which are remanded by the SBA for reconsideration by a city official shall be stayed pending further final action taken by the city official as required by the decision of the SBA. A decision of the SBA not to remand any matter shall be considered final administrative action for purposes of judicial review. 
(12)	Orders not stayed. Except as otherwise expressly provided by section 26-106(d)(11), no action taken or request filed by any user shall operate to stay the effect of any order of determination or of any provision, term or condition of any order. 
(e)	Confidential information. The following provisions shall apply regarding the treatment by the city of information submitted to or obtained by the city in the administration of this division: 
(1)	All information submitted to the city relating to matters regulated in this chapter is presumed to be not confidential, unless the user specifically indicates otherwise as provided by this section and MAC 323.2314. The information or portions of information submitted to the city which the user considers to be confidential shall be clearly marked on each page or sheet of information submitted, and shall be accompanied by a written explanation of why the user considers the information to be confidential or why the release of the information would divulge information, processes or methods of production entitled to protection as trade secrets of the user. Information which may disclose trade secrets or secret processes and for which the user has requested confidentiality as provided by this section shall not be made available for inspection by members of the general public; however, that information shall be made available upon written request to governmental agencies for uses related to matters regulated by this division and shall be made available for use by governmental agencies, including, without limitation, the city, in judicial review or enforcement proceedings which involve the user which furnished the information. The city shall notify the user ten (10) days in advance if it intends to release confidential information to another governmental agency as authorized by this section. 
(2)	Information furnished to the city on the volume or characteristics of wastewater or pollutants discharged or proposed to be discharged into the POTW shall be available to the public or other governmental agency without restriction. 
(3)	If a user has mass-based limits as allowed by certain categorical pretreatment standards on a production basis, the production data necessary to determine compliance must also be provided by the user to the city, and shall be available to the public. If application of the combined waste stream formula is necessary to apply categorical pretreatment standards to a user, the flow measurements and other data used in the calculation must be provided by the user to the city, and shall be available to the public. 
(f)	Record keeping requirements. All industrial users shall retain and preserve records, including, without limitation, all books, documents, memoranda, reports, correspondence and similar materials, related to matters regulated by this division as provided by this section: 
(1)	Any industrial user subject to the sampling, analysis, monitoring or reporting requirements of this division, including reports under 40 CFR 403.12 and MAC 323.2310, shall maintain copies of the records pertaining to those reports. For all samples, the records shall include the date, exact place, method and time of sampling and the names of the person(s) taking the samples; the dates analyses were performed; who performed the analyses; the analytical techniques and methods used; and the results of the analysis. The records shall be retained by the user for at least three (3) years. This retention period shall be extended during the course of any unresolved litigation regarding the discharges of the user or the POTW, or if requested by the city manager, the Department of Natural Resources and Environment, or the U.S. EPA. 
(2)	All industrial users who have records regarding their generation, treatment, storage, or disposal of hazardous waste or solid waste shall maintain those records for at least three (3) years and shall make them available to the city for inspection and copying, subject to the provisions contained in section 26-106(e) regarding confidential information. The terms "hazardous waste" and "solid waste" shall have the same definition as provided in Part 111 of NREPA, Hazardous Waste Management, MCL 324.11101 et seq., as amended, and rules promulgated under that Act. 
(g)	Accidental discharges. This section sets forth the minimum requirements for industrial users to prepare for, respond to, and report accidental discharges to the POTW. Additional or more restrictive requirements may be required for particular users under an order of determination, a special agreement, a slug control plan or by other applicable laws and regulations. Compliance with the requirements of this section shall not relieve a user of any expense, loss, damage, or other liability which may be incurred as a result of damage to the POTW, or for any other damage to person or property, or for any other liability which may be imposed under this division or other applicable laws and regulations. 
(1)	Designation of person in charge of discharge operations. Each industrial user shall designate in writing to the city manager at least one (1) person to be in charge of and responsible for the user's discharges to the POTW, including responsibility for maintaining pretreatment facilities and operation, if any, and prevention of accidental discharges. The person so designated shall be an individual or a position with knowledge of all toxic wastes or hazardous substances routinely or potentially generated by the user, and of all process alterations which could, in any manner, increase or decrease normal daily flow or waste strength to the POTW. 
(2)	Description of chemicals stored, used or manufactured by user. Each industrial user shall catalog all chemicals stored, used, or manufactured by the user at the user's premises. The list of chemicals shall include specific chemical names (not just manufacturer's codes) and shall be submitted to the city manager. 
(3)	Description of user discharges. Each industrial user shall provide the city manager with a written description of the user's discharge practices, including an estimate of daily average flows, waste strengths, and flow types, separated according to appropriate categories including process, cooling, sanitary, etc. 
(4)	Description of user premises. Each industrial user shall provide the city manager with a sketch of the user's plant building(s), including the location of pretreatment equipment, process and chemical storage areas, floor drain located near process and storage areas, manhole or other control structures, and sewer locations at the user's point of discharge into the POTW. 
(5)	Submission of information required at least annually. The information required above in subsections (g)(1), (2), (3) and (4) of this section (regarding designation of person(s) in charge; the description of the chemicals stored, used or manufactured; the description of user discharges; and the description of user premises) shall be provided by the user to the city manager at least once per year along with the first periodic report submitted for the year as required by section 26-106(c)(1)c. (categorical users) or section 26-106(c)(2) (noncategorical users) of this division, as applicable. If subsequent to the required annual submission of this information, changes are made in the designation of the person(s) in charge, the chemicals stored, used or manufactured, the user's discharge, or the user's premises, the user shall within fifteen (15) days of making the change (or sooner as otherwise required by this division) provide the city manager with written notice of the changes made. 
(6)	Segregation of wastewaters requiring pretreatment. Industrial users shall segregate wastewaters requiring pretreatment (including, without limitation, spent concentrates, toxics, and high strength organic wastes) as necessary to prevent pollutants from interfering with or passing through the POTW. All sludges generated by pretreatment shall be used or disposed of only as permitted by applicable laws and regulations. 
(7)	Spill prevention plan. Each industrial user shall provide protection from accidental discharge of materials which may interfere with the POTW by developing a spill prevention plan. If the materials of concern are on the state critical materials list, the user shall develop and submit to the city manager for approval a Pollution Incident Prevention ("PIP") Plan in accordance with the requirements of Part 31 of NREPA, Water Resources Protection, MCL 324.3101 et seq., as amended, and rules promulgated thereunder. Detailed spill prevention and/or PIP plans certified by a state-licensed professional engineer, including the facilities and the operating procedures, shall be submitted to the city manager within sixty (60) days of the effective date of this division for an existing source, or thirty (30) days prior to the date of discharge for a new source. 
(8)	Spill containment requirements. Each industrial user must provide and maintain at the user's expense spill containment structures (including diking, curbing or other appropriate structures) adequate to protect all floor drains from accidental spills and discharges to the POTW of any pollutants or discharges regulated by this division. The containment or curbing shall be sufficient to contain not less than one hundred fifty (150) percent of liquid polluting material stored or used, unless a lesser containment area or alternate control measures are approved by the city manager. The containment area shall be constructed so that no liquid polluting material can escape from the area by gravity through building sewers, drains, or otherwise directly or indirectly into the POTW. All floor drains within the containment area must be plugged and sealed. Spill troughs and sumps within process areas must discharge to appropriate pretreatment tanks. Emergency containment protection shall also be provided for storage tanks which may be serviced by commercial haulers and for chemical storage areas. Solid pollutants shall be located in security areas designed to prevent the loss of the materials to the POTW. Detailed plans showing facilities and operating procedures to provide the protection required by this section shall be submitted to the city manager for review, and shall be approved by the city manager before construction. Construction of approved containment facilities for existing sources shall be completed within the time period specified by the city manager. No new source shall be permitted to discharge to the POTW until emergency containment facilities have been approved and constructed as required by this section. The city manager may order an industrial user to take interim measures for emergency containment, if circumstances require. 
(9)	Posting of accidental discharge information. All industrial users shall permanently and prominently post a clearly legible set of instructions in the area where the user manages wastewater so that the applicable reporting and notice requirements (including telephone numbers) are made known and are immediately available to the user's employees. In addition, all industrial users shall instruct their employees on the applicable reporting and notice requirements of this section. 
(10)	Notice of accidental discharge. In the case of an accidental discharge, an industrial user shall immediately notify the city manager of the incident by telephone. The notification shall include available information regarding the location of the discharge, its volume, duration, constituents, loading and concentrations, corrective actions required and other available information as necessary to determine what impact the discharge may have on the POTW. A written notification providing the same and any additional available information shall also be provided by the user to the city manager within five (5) days of the incident. 
(11)	Slug control plan. The city manager shall evaluate each significant industrial user at least once every two (2) years, and other industrial users as necessary, to determine whether such user needs a plan to control slug discharges. If the city manager determines that a slug control plan is needed, then the plan shall contain at least the following elements: 
a.	A description of discharge practices, including nonroutine batch discharges;
b.	A description of stored materials;
c.	The procedures for immediately notifying the city manager of slug discharges, including any discharge that would violate any discharge prohibition, limitation or requirement under this division, and procedures for follow-up written notification within five (5) days of the discharge; 
d.
